TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to general business notice of motion No. 600 standing in my name.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 September 1993 the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was given the task of inquiring into the incidence and handling of sexual harassment or sexual assault in the Royal Australian Navy and the other armed forces. The committee took immediate steps to invite submissions. By the end of November, over 100 submissions had been received. It became clear from the evidence received that the committee had been given a very large and very important task. The committee began considering the written submissions at the end of last year. Unfortunately, the demands of the Senate in the final weeks of the last session of parliament meant that the committee was unable to commence its public hearings as scheduled.

PARA.TAB: The committee has now embarked on a comprehensive series of public hearings. Three full days have already been devoted to hearing a range of views and experiences of relevance to the inquiry. The committee has also been extensively engaged in ensuring that proper procedures are followed to protect the rights of all individuals to natural justice. It is clear to the committee that it will not be possible to complete its task in time to meet the reporting deadline of 28 February 1994. I therefore seek leave to move a motion for an extension of time for the tabling of the report.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on sexual harassment in the Australian Defence Forces be extended to a day on or before 9 June 1994.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the committee's report entitled The National Crime Authority and James McCartney Anderson, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This reference was given to the committee in the last parliament and presents an opportunity to remind senators and the public in general of the consequences of taking on any particular reference.

PARA.TAB: This reference was, in contrast to any other reference that this committee has had, quite an expensive one. The committee sought extra funding from the Department of the Senate so that it could have legal counsel advising it. That is no surprise, given the type of investigation that it was taking on. That legal advice, as I understand it, cost over $20,000: $20,000 of taxpayers' money was provided to assist a committee. One might say that in the sum of a lot of things $20,000 is not that much. I happen to think it is quite a lot. Witness expenses, I understand, went well over $10,000. So before we even add on the cost of senators going from one place to another, this inquiry has cost $30,000.

The inquiry relates to the authority's relationship with James McCartney Anderson, who was alleged to be a criminal and was used by the authority as an informant. The cost of that exercise is not calculated in this report, but it is fair to say that the report is critical of the arrangement that the authority entered into with Anderson as an informant. The consequences of doing that in terms of cost are quite obvious in the sense of relying on him as a reliable witness and then prosecutions possibly not being able to proceed because of that unreliability. Consequently, it is worth drawing this report to the attention of honourable senators who are interested in law enforcement in any way because it highlights the manner in which the authority was dealing with Anderson at the time. It points out that the authority would no longer deal with someone such as Anderson on the basis that it then did.

One might ask, `Why did you spend all the money and have this inquiry if you had an undertaking from the authority that it would not happen again?'. The reason is that the people who are on the authority now may not be there in two or three years time. In fact, law enforcement arrangements for the Commonwealth may well be very substantially changed as a consequence of the current review of Commonwealth law enforcement procedures and the authority itself may not exist.

This report really should be taken by people in the future not just as a report on the authority and its relationship with James McCartney Anderson but also as a highlighter to all law enforcement agencies as to the way they should deal with informants and the care that they ought to take. The consequences, when the incorrect path is chosen, can be very expensive for the community as a whole, in terms of law enforcement success or otherwise, and for a parliament which undertakes an inquiry into it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on the employment of visitors to Australia in the shearing industry together with submissions and transcripts of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This latest report of the rural and regional affairs committee provides a useful reference tool to an industry that, in recent times, has been beset by many difficulties. The wool industry today is recovering from crisis. Wool prices in the last few years have been at record lows. An industry that once employed hundreds of thousands of people and just about guaranteed year-round work is on its knees. The work and the money to pay the workers are not there.

PARA.TAB: The national sheep flock has fallen from 170 million in 1990 to 138 million last year—that is a 32 million drop in just three years. That alone would have been sufficient to cause large scale loss of jobs. However, low prices have forced many farmers to do their own shearing. Wives and children have become the classers, the shedhands and the rouseabouts. The reference for this inquiry has, as its basis, the recent difficulties faced by the wool industry. But the underlying resentment and the accusations go back many years.

The wool industry in Australia is one of the oldest, if not the oldest. It is steeped in history and tradition. Its shearing shed protocol is as exact and entrenched as many of our parliamentary procedures, although our procedures have been changed a little in the last while. Over time, strong union ties developed within the wool industry to ensure that shearers throughout Australia were employed on roughly equal conditions, notwithstanding the variation in sheds—their location and variation in employer attitudes to shearers—and also the type and style of sheep to be shorn.

In recent times change has come to the shearing industry, and to many the change has been unacceptable. The introduction of wide combs, largely by New Zealand shearers, some years ago caused unprecedented violence in the sheds. People were attacked, sheds were burnt and a lot of animosity was generated through the industry. There has always been a `them and us' attitude prevalent in the wool industry because the richest and the most powerful people in Australia's early history were woolgrowers. That is no longer necessarily the case; but the old attitude still prevails in many parts of Australia.

We took evidence all around Australia. It is fair to say that we were prepared to accept the evidence as presented and then to make a value judgment. Of course, a lot of the evidence was anecdotal. I am afraid that that evidence was not taken as pure, proper evidence because there were so many times we heard people telling us that this was happening or this was supposed to be happening. During our hearings the `them and us' resentment was evident in many witnesses. One witness summed it up thus:

SPEECH.PARA: Ten years ago the Australian shearers dictated the terms, to a fair extent . . .

PARA.TAB: Australian shearers today are just pleased to go to work to earn a few dollars for their family and themselves. The boot is on the other foot. Now the graziers are dictating terms to the Australian shearers and to New Zealand shearers.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the way it was. There have been no other rural industries so adversely affected by the recession and by inappropriate policy decisions of this Labor government than the wool industry. That is no light claim. All rural industries have suffered to an enormous extent in recent years, but quite literally the bottom has fallen out of the wool industry and times are very tough. That has resulted in widespread unemployment within the shearing industry which has led to widespread discontent.

PARA.TAB: Unions and individuals have searched for a reason, and New Zealanders seem to be an appropriate target. In 1992 shearers demonstrated outside Parliament House claiming that over 50 per cent of Australian shearers were out of work because, they said, of an influx of New Zealanders. They suggested it was made possible by the Australian government's unregulated, open-access policy on trans-Tasman travel. They also suggested that New Zealand shearers undercut Australian work rates and could afford to do so because of the favourable taxation arrangements. Calls were made for the government to apply the same work test and visa requirements for New Zealanders as apply to other visitors.

On that basis the committee determined to examine those claims, and it did so through a number of public hearings. As I said, there was much anecdotal evidence presented by individuals and by the Australian Workers Union. In particular, the Australian Workers Union anecdotal evidence did not stand up when it was closely scrutinised by the Taxation Office and other government instrumentalities.

Figures and statistics were bandied about; about 42 per cent seemed to be a popular figure. It was claimed that 42 per cent of the shearing work force were New Zealanders; that 42 per cent of the national flock is shorn by New Zealanders; that 42 per cent of Western Australian sheep are shorn by New Zealanders; and that 42 per cent of Victorian sheep are shorn by New Zealanders. There were claims that prior to 1982-83 two to three per cent of shearers in Australia were New Zealanders, but since 1983 the figure had jumped to 42 per cent. These figures just did not stand up.We also took evidence from the Bureau of Statistics and from farmers organisations across a wide cross-section of the rural industry.

The report concludes that there is little basis for any of the claims made by unions and by many shearers. High unemployment levels are more a result of the state of the industry than any New Zealand invasion. It is certainly true that New Zealand shearers work in Australia. It is also true that many of them are very good and that some woolgrowers prefer them to Australian shearers, and that is their choice. Many of those shearers are New Zealanders who live here in Australia; we saw many of them in the different places around Australia that we visited.

The evidence indicated that as far as taxation was concerned, for example, the double taxation agreements—particularly those applying to visiting New Zealand shearers as was claimed by the AWU—were completely misinterpreted by the AWU. The committee's review of the evidence made it clear that it was only in exceptional circumstances that the income tax of a New Zealand shearer working in Australia would not be subject to tax in Australia. Also, the claims that New Zealand shearers were receiving the dole were unfounded.

The conclusions in the report clearly show that there are problems in the industry that need to be addressed. The problems will not be solved by a `them and us' approach; there has to be a much better approach from the shearers and from graziers to make sure that in the future they get along well together within the industry.

In concluding, I would like to thank the committee secretariat for its continuing patience with those of us on the committee. I believe the secretariat does a fantastic job in making sure that we get these reports out quickly. It is a committee that gets its reports out quickly, and it has its inquiries in a succinct manner.

I believe this is a valuable report which does little more, to my mind, than confirm what many of us suspected at the beginning of the inquiry, but it provides useful reference material to overcome future allegations. The shearing industry needs to assess this report carefully and plan better for its future. It needs to make sure that the standard of our wool preparation and the training of our shearers here in Australia is actually better than it is in New Zealand. Australia cannot afford to live in isolation, and living with New Zealand and other countries with whom we share work relationships needs to be accommodated. I commend the report to the Senate. I know the chairman will be speaking on this report later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to comment on this report. I say, as a member of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, that it is one of the reports which our committee has produced which I am rather pleased with. The genesis of it goes back to 1992. Those of us who were here will remember that we had a demonstration by shearers outside Parliament House. At the same time, the Australian Workers Union made pleas on behalf of its members for the government to do something about what it saw as an invasion of New Zealand shearers into the industry here, thus putting a lot of Australian shearers out of work. As Senator Brownhill said, we had a severe recession and drought, and there is no doubt that a lot of shearers were out of work. Someone had to be blamed, so the so-called influx of New Zealand shearers got the blame. I am pleased that this report has been put together in a factual manner, and we have been able to put to bed a lot of the claims that have been made, quite wrongly, over many years, about shearers, particularly New Zealand shearers.

PARA.TAB: No-one doubts the ability of Australian shearers. There is no doubt they are still the best shearers in the world, particularly in regard to fine-wool sheep. Even though New Zealand shearers have come here to work, they have fitted in very well. It was revealed in evidence that the major reason why New Zealand shearers were more favoured in some areas is that they were not part of the `them and us' mentality that has evolved over at least 100 years in this country.

For the record, it should be remembered shearing has not changed in the way that a lot of other industries have changed. It is still very hard work. For instance, a normal shearer who shears his 200 sheep a day drags about 12 tonnes in weight across the board every day. Physiologists estimate the maximum amount of energy that a person should expend in a day is 4,900 kilocalories. In fact, Australian shearers expend well over 5,000 kilocalories every day. Obviously, they have to be very fit. Nothing has really changed except we have gone from hand shears to electric shearing to wide comb. That sums up the modernisation of the wool industry since the 1800s.

We travelled far and wide in this particular inquiry. I note that the chairman of the committee is present. He was with us when we visited Barcaldine. The shearing industry and the Labor Party go back a long way, and it is rumoured that Barcaldine is where the Labor Party has its roots because of the shearers strike which occurred there in the 1800s.

As Senator Brownhill has said, a lot of misinformation and exaggerated claims were made prior to this report. In fact, the AWU in Victoria initially alleged there were between 7,000 and 10,000 New Zealand shearers working in Australia. Upon investigation, it was found there were only 8,600 sheep shearers in Australia all up, and of those, 6.3 per cent, or 547, were born in New Zealand. So, to say that the claims were exaggerated is being kind. They were totally untrue, as this report found out.

We went on to ask for more information from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and found that, if we take into account the shedhands as well, the total number of people working in the shearing industry in Australia was 11,500. On census night, 763 of those were born in New Zealand. Might I say, we have received evidence and saw for ourselves that a lot of these 763 are actually, to all intents and purposes, now Australian citizens. A lot of them have lived here for 10 years at least. Particularly in the Muttaburra area and areas up in north-west Queensland, those shearers are a very important part of the local community.

It was gratifying to all of us to see the way that the New Zealand-born shearers have moved in and become an important part of the local community. They seem to have a great rapport with the local graziers in the area. I think it is a shame that the `them and us' attitude that has built up over such a long time is taking a little longer to break down. That is the advantage for the New Zealand shearers. They have been able to come in, see things and play things as they are, and therefore have not had the `them and us' attitude hanging over their heads. That was one of the major concerns that the AWU and the shearers had.

Another area of concern was the industrial relations side of things. One of the concerns put to us was that the New Zealanders did not observe award conditions and that was why they were being employed. We took a lot of evidence on this from union representatives and the industry. We found that there are employers, contractors and shearing workers, including New Zealanders, who do breach award conditions, but we came to the conclusion, based on fact, that there was no evidence that New Zealand shearers actually breached award conditions any more than did Australian shearers.

There was also a misconception that New Zealand shearers who came here, worked and left the country again were actually ripping off our taxation system. In fact, some claims were made to the committee that New Zealanders visiting here for less than six months received a 100 per cent refund on all the income tax they paid, and a lot of other wild claims were made. However, when we investigated this claim the Australian Taxation Office indicated that the tax evasion is not as widespread as the anecdotal evidence suggests and that, where it did occur, it was practised just as much by Australian shearers as by New Zealand shearers. The double taxation agreement came into effect in only very exceptional circumstances in Australia.

There was a bit of criticism about the trans-Tasman and CER arrangements between Australia and New Zealand and our investigation into that subject took up a fair amount of our time. I was rather impressed by the evidence given to us by Mr Ted Woodfield, the New Zealand High Commissioner, who stated that the trans-Tasman travel arrangements:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . go to the heart of the special relationship between the two countries which is the product of our shared heritage, geographical proximity and adherence to common values of law, justice, democracy and economic welfare.

On looking at the figures we can see that in 1991, for instance, Australian goods exported to New Zealand amounted to $2.674 billion and New Zealand goods exported to Australia, $2.268 billion. In other words, Australia had a $400 million surplus in trading with New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: We made some recommendations, as one would expect. The major one of course was that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) urgently establish a shearing industry task force to restructure the federal pastoral industry award, which we believe is way out of date; to push compliance in relation to award pay and conditions; and to develop compliance activities in relation to taxation and superannuation. We believe that the shearers are certainly not getting the benefit of superannuation that they should. Most of it seems to be taken up by the different life insurance company and administration charges. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1992 the Senate referred to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for inquiry and report the employment of visitors to Australia in the shearing industry with particular reference to: (a) social and economic implications for rural communities; (b) taxation arrangements; (c) immigration regulations; (d) international agreements; and (e) industrial relations. The inquiry arose out of concern about the presence of New Zealand shearers in Australia and their effect on job opportunities in the Australian shearing industry.

PARA.TAB: This matter was of particular concern to the Australian Workers Union, which represents shearing industry workers. The union maintained that over 50 per cent of Australian shearers were out of work because of an influx of New Zealanders, made possible by the Australian government's unregulated, open access policy on trans-Tasman travel. It was further alleged that New Zealand shearers are able to undercut award rates for shearing because of advantages conferred on them by taxation arrangements and the exchange rate. The union and others in the industry called on the government to amend the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangements by implementing a system of work permits for New Zealanders.

At the beginning of this inquiry, I emphasised—through an interview with the New Zealand press and also in a number of radio interviews—that this was in no way an exercise in Kiwi bashing, that it was only on the basis of sound evidence that the committee could finalise a factual report and make informed and fair recommendations to the parliament. The committee undertook an extensive program of hearings in several states in an endeavour to gather evidence from all sectors of the shearing industry. Notably, the committee held hearings in the woolgrowing districts of western Victoria and central Queensland at which witnesses from all sides of the debate gave evidence.

The committee recognises that the nature of the shearing industry makes it difficult for individual witnesses to gather and present first-hand, factual or statistical information. Nevertheless, the committee was somewhat disappointed that so much of the evidence received in this inquiry, including some of the evidence from the union, amounted to anecdotes and hearsay.

TALK.START.PARA: —You get a bit of that in this place!

—If the honourable senator would just be quiet, he will learn something. In spite of the difficulties imposed by the nature of the industry and the quality of the evidence, the committee was able to reach conclusions in relation to the major areas of concern in this matter, particularly the number of New Zealanders in the industry, taxation arrangements applying to New Zealand shearers and industrial relations. On the basis of these findings, the committee then addressed the need to alter Australia's bilateral relationship with New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the number of New Zealanders participating in the Australian shearing industry, the committee was told that there has been a significant influx of New Zealanders. A figure of 42 per cent has gained widespread currency in the industry, referring either to the percentage of the shearing work force who are New Zealanders or the percentage of the flock shorn by New Zealanders. It has been suggested that between 7,000 and 10,000 New Zealanders may be working in the industry.

The committee tested these assertions and has accepted the advice of the Australian Bureau of Statistics that New Zealanders comprise 6.6 per cent of the shearing work force. This evidence is derived from the bureau's 1991 census, showing 763 New Zealand-born shearers and shedhands present in Australia on census night. This was the most recent information available to the committee. The committee also found that the social and economic profile of New Zealand shearers in Australia is more complex than the simple picture of a transient population that was presented by several witnesses.

In relation to taxation, the committee was told that the Australian taxation system, and in particular the double taxation agreement with New Zealand, conferred unfair benefits on New Zealanders working in the shearing industry. It was commonly asserted that New Zealanders either pay no tax, or get all their tax instalments refunded when they return to New Zealand. But evidence from the Australian Taxation Office makes it clear that only in exceptional circumstances will the income of a New Zealand shearer working in Australia not be subject to tax in Australia. It was apparent from the evidence presented during the inquiry that the AWU and others have misinterpreted taxation provisions relating to the double taxation agreement and the taxation arrangements applying to visiting New Zealand shearers.

Most of the evidence to the inquiry concerned industrial relations. In this area in particular, anecdotal evidence was rife, with sweeping assertions frequently made about the work practices and attitudes of New Zealanders in the shearing industry. It was commonly asserted that New Zealanders do not observe award conditions and work for under award pay. The committee also heard that the number of New Zealanders in the industry has caused a glut of labour, leading to a general decline in observance of the awards. The committee is not convinced that the incidence of award breaches amongst New Zealanders is higher than amongst Australians, or that the presence of New Zealanders is the sole cause of a breakdown in award conditions in the industry. The committee was forced to that view because of the lack of solid evidence.

This conclusion is based on the committee's review of numerous statements and documents presented during the inquiry, as well as the findings of compliance activity undertaken by the Department of Industrial Relations. I would be somewhat remiss if I did not say to honourable senators that the department admits it is not an easy matter to run down breaches and problems because there can well be cooperation between the two parties to have people either work for under award wages or accept less than award conditions. However, there was no proof that could be tendered in that regard.

In the final chapter of the report, the committee addresses the calls for Australia to change the trans-Tasman travel arrangements that allow visa-free travel between Australia and New Zealand. That is quite different and is a much older practice than CER. Each stands on its own, even though in both countries one may have some influence in terms of attitude towards the other. The committee is not convinced that existing migration and travel arrangements with New Zealanders should be changed. The committee notes the views of the relevant government departments that imposing a visa regime on New Zealanders would be out of all proportion to the perceived problem and would not necessarily address concerns within the shearing industry, particularly in terms of industrial relations.

The committee recognises that there are problems in the shearing industry. It is convinced that these problems must be addressed by those within the industry and that the `them and us' mentality so obvious during the inquiry must be discarded. As a person who has had a long involvement in industrial matters, I would encourage the relevant parties to give priority to award restructuring. I understand that process is beginning.

The committee recommends the establishment of forums for consultation between the Australian Workers Union, the Shearing Contractors Association of Australia, the National Farmers Federation and other farmer organisations, and relevant Commonwealth and state government departments. These forums should develop strategies and co-ordinate programs for restructuring the federal pastoral industry award, and upgrading compliance activities in relation to award pay and conditions, taxation and superannuation.

I do not make this recommendation on the basis of an attitude of isolation, because if we look at some of the developments in industry throughout Australia—more recently in the news was the waterfront industry—there have been quite significant changes in work practices and the attitude to management. These have been beneficial to both sides in the short term, at any rate. We will have to see how they work out in the long term and in the interests of a nation. I am not suggesting that people do this in isolation but, rather, that they be part of the move towards change with mutual benefits to all and, at the same time, protecting the interests of employer and employee organisations. This will have to be done with the understanding that nobody will get everything that they want.

In its report, the committee also addresses the important issues of training and certification of shearer and shedhand skills. It is mentioned in the report, and it was brought home to us, that the training of shedhands in New Zealand is far superior to what is almost an absence of training of shedhands in Australia. The committee believes that, as in other industries where proper training is in place to provide a work force that is both competent and conscious of quality control and guaranteed quality, there is a necessity for people to be properly trained which will benefit this industry. Already comments have been made by producers in the industry, both publicly and privately, of their concern about quality and the need to lift their game so that their product is more desirable in the market place. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of New Zealand shearers was absolutely fundamental to this inquiry by the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs into the employment of visitors to Australia in the shearing industry. Clearly, many of the claims made in the first instance were exaggerated—even some of those originating with the Australian Workers Union. However, that does not negate the claims altogether and pages 82 to 87 record a number of breaches which are too significant to ignore.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly, as noted on page 90, there was strong resistance by a number of people to the notion that New Zealand shearers caused the breakdown in award conditions. Yet, at the same time, other evidence was given that New Zealand shearers were present in sufficient numbers to cause a change in work attitudes amongst Australian shearers. I draw the attention of the Senate particularly to pages 17, 35 and 36. Although on the one hand New Zealand shearers were regarded as almost not being present, on the other hand, in some instances, almost the same people—certainly people from the same side of the industry—were prepared to say that New Zealand shearers were able to effect beneficial changes in attitudes amongst Australian shearers. So one cannot have it both ways.

Pages 39 and 40 deal with the social implications for rural communities. I underline the comment there about the significant impact of the rural recession on rural towns, communities and families. Clearly, the recession is a serious factor in the loss of employment for shearing families. In a recession it is very easy to look for scapegoats—I guess we all do that—and certainly there was some of that in some of the claims which were made. Even if the shearing work force represented by New Zealanders is only six per cent, that is still six per cent of jobs which would not be available to Australian shearers. Whether or not New Zealand shearers should be present is another debate for another time. Certainly, the committee was of the opinion that there should be no change in the present arrangements which allow New Zealand workers to come to Australia. Nevertheless, it is easy to see how in times of social stress people do look for scapegoats, and so the claims are made.

Another critical question for debate at another time is whether shearers or other employees should accept reduced pay and working conditions to help employers mitigate the effects of reduced returns, particularly in the wool industry. Of course, I do not think they should. However, one of the inferences in the debate was that somehow or other when there is a downturn in the industry the employees should help pay for that downturn. I do not accept that argument; but it is part of the background to the whole debate and it needs to be addressed. It is an issue that is part of the debate and yet does not necessarily surface.

Reference is made on pages 116 and 117 to a number of breaches of superannuation obligations. In my conversations with a number of shearers it was pointed out to me that whenever they pressed their claims to try to achieve compliance they were unable to obtain further work and, hence, did not insist on their rights in this regard.

So the committee has drawn the attention of the Select Committee on Superannuation to this matter. It is part of the whole problem itinerant workers have in accessing government policy in terms of superannuation, particularly the superannuation guarantee levy. The superannuation industry obviously is not designed to take account of the special needs of itinerant workers. I simply wanted to underline that.

I believe that a number of shearers were disenchanted with the way the issue was handled by the Australian Workers Union, but I am of the opinion that the AWU certainly has been chastened in that regard. I hope that the negotiations which are suggested in the conclusions in our report certainly will operate at a much better level in representing the needs of the shearers.

The conclusions to the report are recorded on pages 134 and 135, and I think they are going to help this industry to overcome 100 years of history—certainly if they are taken seriously by the industry, the unions involved and the various government bodies. Then I believe we can begin to address a very deep division within our community that ought not to be there. I believe that our rural communities need both the shearers and the wool industry to work together to achieve the kinds of results that we all want so that this industry will continue to play an important part in the support of Australian families and communities, and of course the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in the debate on this report. Although I have had the report only since its tabling this morning, I certainly welcome it because it has borne out everything I have said about the shearing industry since I have been in this place—and before I came to this place. What is more, it has put paid to Senator Burns's assertions prior to this inquiry that New Zealand shearers were overrunning Australia and taking work away from Australian shearers. I was very happy to see him this morning rather contritely delivering his report on what the committee had decided. It has borne out exactly what I have known all the time. There were concerns that half—and Senator McKiernan can smile at that—
—I am laughing at you.

—Senator McKiernan can laugh as much as he likes. At least I know what I am talking about with the shearing industry, having had experience in shearing and employing shearers. But Senator McKiernan has never employed people; he has only helped to put people out of work. It was being said that half the sheep in Australia were being shorn by New Zealanders but this report says that only 6.6 per cent of shearers in Australia are Kiwi based, or come from New Zealand.
—It is more than that in Western Australia.
—There may be more than that in Western Australia, but there may be reasons for that, too.
—Like what?

—If Senator Bolkus listens long enough I will come to that. I asked why New Zealand shearers came to Australia. The reason was that opportunities were there. The Australian shearers could not handle the amount of work because of the increase in the numbers of sheep when the rather ridiculous wool reserve price scheme was around from 1984 to 1990.
—Blame the woolgrowers for that. They wanted a floor price.
—Yes, I blame Mr Kerin in this case. He wrecked the wool industry, and now the government has appointed him to wreck the meat industry as well.
—You asked him for it. He did only what you asked him.
—Call him to order.

—No, l can handle Senator Burns. He also owes an apology to Senator Troeth; when he can remember to give it. Those numbers went up from about 150 million to over 200 million. I think they reached 206 million at the higher stage. That is why more shearers were needed. New Zealand shearers saw the opportunity and came to Australia. The figures show that.

PARA.TAB: At that time there was also the highjacking of Australian woolgrowers by the shearers because of the shortage of shearers compared with the number of sheep. In some cases in high season shearers were demanding twice the award rate. Of course they had to be paid. Some of the time the farmers may have been able to afford those wages with the high wool prices; but the wool prices did not last. So that was the reason there was the opportunity for Kiwi shearers to come to Australia. There is the myth around that New Zealand shearers undercut the award rates. Senator Burns's committee did not find any evidence whatsoever of that. I always knew that that was not going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a ridiculous thing to say.

—I employ a shearing team of 20 shearers. I know that they will not shear for under the award, but the difference is—and Senator Burns cannot get it through his thick skull—that Kiwis are prepared to shear for the award. That was the difference at the time between the Australian shearer and the Kiwi shearer. The Kiwi shearers for the most part are prepared to shear for the award. That is the point.

PARA.TAB: Another myth that has been around is that New Zealand contractors employ only New Zealand shearers. That is totally false. Senator Burns's committee did not find otherwise. A Kiwi contractor will employ the best shearers and the best shedhands he can get at the time. I know that from experience. That is what they do. Another thing, too, which shoots Senator Burns's argument out of the water is that there are very few New Zealand-born wool classers around. So generally the wool classer who comes with a shearing team is an Australian. If Senator Burns is saying they are all New Zealanders he is wrong.

Kiwi contractors also introduced women on the board in the shearing work force. Senator Burns should know, because he has been around as long as I have, that there was a time when women were not allowed in the shearing shed. Can Senator Burns remember that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I sure can.

—Yes, and the trend was to keep them out. It was the New Zealand contractors who introduced women to the floor of a shearing shed. I have seen an odd woman shearer—not too many. The women are better on the shearing floor. I know that from the experience of seeing how they work. Even Australian women who work there tend to be better than some of the useless board boys that cannot even be woken up in the morning.

PARA.TAB: Then there was the case of the New Zealand shearers being blamed for introducing the wide comb. Once again this is a misconception that Senator Burns cannot get used to. The wide comb is an innovation that is just like using a bigger truck or a wider plough.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't let Aussie shearers use wide combs years ago.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Shearers can use a wide comb or a narrow comb, as far as I am concerned, as much as they like. I do not think Senator Bolkus knows much about shearing, so he had better keep quiet. They brought in the wide comb, which was an innovation.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Burns knew anything about shearing and shearers he would know that shearers do not shear more with a wide comb than with a narrow comb. They work easier. It is easier on their backs, and there are fewer shearing blows. A good shearer does not shear any more. It is a fact that a learning shearer shears less because he cannot handle the wide comb. It was an innovation that Australia fought for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What for? What is the merit?

—I told Senator Burns that the shearers work easier. It is easier on their body and on their health. As for Kiwi shearers coming and going and just taking their profits home, that is wrong. The committee found that out. Kiwi shearers are permanent residents of Australia. We had one Australian contractor for 23 years—that shows how hard we are to work with—and when he retired along came a Kiwi contractor and we have had him for about seven years. So I know both sides of the story. I know they are permanent Australian citizens.

PARA.TAB: Do Senator Burns, Senator McKiernan or anyone else have any figures which show how many Australian shearers are working in New Zealand? I do not think they do. I know there are a lot of Australian shearers working in New Zealand. In fact, there are Australian shearers working in the United States on a regular basis. They go there for two months and then come back. They are teaching that industry what to do. In most parts of America they still tie up a sheep to shear it. That shows how far behind they are. There are Kiwi shearers going to the United States as well as Australian shearers.

In conclusion, I am very happy that this report—and I have only breezed through it this morning—has borne out what I have said all along; that Kiwi shearers are not taking the bread out of the mouths of Australian shearers and this will be borne out more as time goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the previous speaker, I will dwell on the report before the parliament today on the employment of visitors in the Australian shearing industry. I commend the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs and, in particular, its chairman for bringing this report into the parliament.

PARA.TAB: This was a vexed question around this place a couple of years ago when we had large numbers of Australian workers demonstrating to protect, as they thought, their employment prospects in this country. The report suggests now that they were perhaps misguided and misinformed about the reasons why they had to camp out on the grounds of this building in freezing temperatures night after night. One could not but marvel at their commitment to protecting not only their jobs but also their children's jobs.

At the time that those demonstrations were taking place, I had some concerns which I expressed directly to the individuals and their union leaders when they approached us and lobbied us in the parliament. I felt that they were picking on a particular national group, and I did not agree with doing that be it Irish, Italian or Kiwi. I think in multicultural Australia we should seek to avoid such selectivity in blaming the victim for the ills of our society.

I commend Senator Burns and members of the committee. They have worked long and hard and travelled extensively throughout the land, not only sitting in offices in capital cities taking evidence but going out to meet the shearers, the shearing contractors, the cockies, the farming organisations and so forth. They also did something which I am not particularly in favour of—I was actually exposed to it myself—and actually worked on the weekend. They took evidence on the weekend, not on one occasion but on two. They did that in Victoria and in Queensland. They did it out of necessity because during the week the people were working and were not able to give evidence to the committee. So I again commend Senator Burns and those members of the committee who engaged in that weekend activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —No overtime, either.

—As Senator Burns says, no overtime. Speaking about the weekend activity, I am reminded of the debate that went on in this place in December of last year when it looked like we were going to be sitting on a Sunday. Some people did not want to sit on Sunday. They all forget that as politicians we actually do work on Sundays as well as every other day of the week. We do it in a variety of forms. One of the forms that this committee engaged in was the taking of evidence throughout the weekend, particularly on a Sunday.

PARA.TAB: I joined the committee in May of last year so I am not the full bottle on all of the evidence that was taken earlier but I was with my colleagues, Senator Brownhill, Senator Calvert, Senator Burns and others when we took evidence in Muttaburra, in outback Queensland, which we were told was a Kiwi town. Before we went there we were told that virtually all the residents of that town were of New Zealand extraction.

Whilst we were there taking evidence we certainly met some but they were not exclusively of New Zealand origin. Some of those who were of New Zealand origin were as much Australian as I or Senator Panizza, because they had made this wonderful country their home. That is something that has to be remembered in debates such as this one. Some of us are luckier than others to have been born in places such as Ireland, Italy, New Zealand or Zimbabwe. But either we or our parents make conscious decisions to settle here. Many thousands of New Zealanders have done that and are settling here.

I hope that the content of this report, particularly the statistical evidence, will put an end to some of the misinformation that has been abounding on this particular issue. It is not a hope that I am merely expressing in February of 1994; it is a wish and a hope that I expressed during the early part of 1992 when the demonstrations by the shearers first started. I expressed it in fairly forceful terms, directly to the organisers of the demonstrations and the individuals themselves and, indeed, within my own party's parliamentary forum in the caucus. I do believe that there is a concern that issues such as this can get out of hand and that individual national groups could be picked on, particularly in periods of depression. Australia has a history of doing that and it is something we do not look back on with a great deal of pride.

The report could obviously have been much longer, bearing in mind the weight of evidence that was taken from most states of Australia, from many towns and regional centres and from the industry representatives, government departments, shearers themselves and shearing contractors. In its present form the report can be easily read and I commend it not only to the parliament of Australia but most certainly and directly to the union more immediately involved in this particular industry, the Australian Workers Union.I have nothing but admiration for that union and its membership. It operates in very difficult circumstances in the remotest parts of this wonderful land of ours. In order for the organisers to do their jobs of representing the workers, they have to travel vast distances. I did not just come to know of that during the course of this inquiry; I have many friends in the organisation back in my home state of Western Australia. The name of Gill Barr comes quickly to mind, as a person who did an enormous amount of work in organising and protecting the workers in that industry.

As with any industry, there are goodies and baddies. There are perhaps goodies on the workers' side and baddies on the workers' side, but that is also the case on the employers' side. Some employers will exploit workers, but I would suggest that the majority of employers of shearers in Australia do the right thing by the workers providing the right thing is done back to them. I hope that that certainly will continue.

One very important recommendation contained in the report is that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy convene a meeting of all parties involved in the industry. I do not have the report open to pick up the exact words of the recommendation, but I believe it is perhaps the most important recommendation. The recommendation is looking to the future. It is a great industry for Australia. There are wonderful people involved in that industry and Australia as a nation will prosper as that industry prospers. If we take advantage of the initiative of the minister in convening a meeting, the skills, experience and goodwill that I am sure are contained on all sides of the debate can be blended together and the industry and Australia can move forward. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This morning, without my knowledge—no doubt fully my own fault—the National Crime Authority report on the activities and the relationship between the National Crime Authority and one James McCartney Anderson was tabled and dealt with without my having an opportunity to comment on that report. I seek leave to have this matter reinstated by asking that it be adjourned rather than resolved.

PARA.TAB: I do so because this is a reference which was provided to the National Crime Authority as a result of a resolution of the Senate that arose from a motion moved by me. Following the last federal election, I was required to leave the committee under the National Crime Authority Act, which precluded me as an officer of the Senate from also being a member of the committee. As a result of the new composition of the committee, the construction of the report in some way has been changed. None of the new members, including the Chairman, Mr Cleeland, have read the six weeks of evidence relating to the inquest into the death of Juanita Nielsen, nor have they read the thousands of pages of evidence that was taken by the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —You presume they haven't.
—I know they have not; they say they have not. In fact, they put a disclaimer in the report which says that they disassociate themselves from the findings because they are unable to make judgments.

PARA.TAB: At the time I left the committee, this report was in completed draft form waiting for no more than the members of the committee who had, save for one, unanimously agreed to the document in its then form. I see now that much of the material has been removed from the body of the report and it is now identified as appendix 1 and 2. Without disclosing the activities of the committee, I know Mr Cleeland, who had a personal view about the report without having read the evidence, was keen that certain parts of the evidence and certain parts of the report be deleted. In part, I see he succeeded because we now have appendixes 1 and 2.

I want to put on record that I stand vigorously by the original construction of the report. Anybody now reading the report and seeing appendixes 1 and 2 should take that to mean that the material is contained in the body of the report and supported by the overwhelming majority of the original committee. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (SEARCH WARRANTS AND POWERS OF ARREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 February, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My previous comments on the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill were interrupted at the point of the provision which deals with the entry to premises and the taking of fingerprints. For the record, I make it clear that the government has indicated that this provision deals with the taking of fingerprints from the premises and not from the person. That is contained in proposed section 3F(1)(b). If it were to extend to the person, I would vigorously oppose that.

PARA.TAB: I will refer to some other aspects of this bill. I preface my remarks with the comment that in the area of search and seizure by police there is a vivid example of the state possibly coming into conflict with the rights of the citizen. Therefore, the regulation of that encounter must be very careful and it must achieve a balance between the rights of the citizen concerned and, of course, the carrying out of the functions of the agency charged with looking after law and order.

It is with that in mind that I look at some of the provisions. I refer to proposed section 3F. I note that on page 18 of the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs the government members recommend that the bill as introduced be passed subject to some proposed amendments, two of which deal with proposed section 3F and relate to the right of the occupier to be present during a search and the fact that receipts are to be provided for all goods seized during the search. I can say to the Senate from experience that a good deal of argument at trial is in relation to items taken at the time of searching the premises. Often there are allegations by the accused that the evidence has been planted. Such allegations can be false or true.

The responsibility of this parliament is to ensure that the legislation which deals with this matter is as comprehensive and as workable as possible. I am of the view that, wherever possible, it is desirable that the occupier be present during a search. But I fully understand that in some searches the police find themselves in a situation of stress, urgency and possible danger. That is where they enter premises where there might be armed offenders or multiple suspects, and, of course, that has to be looked at in context.

Perhaps there could be some provision which states that, wherever practicable, the occupier be present during a search. Often I have represented people where the officers have detained the suspect in one part of the premises and conducted a search in another part. That has caused a good deal of discussion and argument at trial and a good deal of unnecessary cross-examination because, in the circumstances, that person could have easily been present during the search.

The issue of why a person was not allowed to be present during the search has been raised in the minds of juries that I have been involved with. That has been a question of comment in addresses to the jury. I stress that that should be tempered with the practicality of the process so that, if it is a search where there is no danger, where there are no multiple offenders, or where the police have absolute control, there should be some requirement for the person to be present during search.

I note that in proposed section 3K(3)(b) there is a provision which allows `the occupier or his or her representative to be present during the examination or processing' of various electronically stored information. That, quite clearly, canvasses the point I am making in relation to another matter. I ask the government to consider perhaps carrying that through to proposed section 3F.

In relation to a receipt for items taken, we should not demand police officers, during a stressful raid or search, to fill out and provide paperwork to the person they have just arrested. Picture a scene where we have a search being conducted, there is evidence on the premises and there are armed offenders. We could not contemplate officers having to stop and provide them with a receipt. I am saying that as soon as practicable after the search the police should make an inventory of things taken and provide it to the accused person or the occupier as the case may be.

I say again that trials I have been involved in have centred around aspects of what has been taken and, in my view, unnecessarily so in some cases. There have been cases where there has not been that stress or a situation at the time of search and seizure which would not allow such a receipt to be taken. But I say again that that has to be looked at in the context of the police carrying out their duties in a situation which might involve potential danger and trauma.

With respect to proposed section 3P, I note that the Democrats had some concern about police obtaining a warrant by telephone or other electronic means. I can fully understand that there may be urgent situations where that is required; but the Democrats requirement that the issuing officer be a magistrate only is not an unreasonable one in the circumstances. In this modern day of communication it is quite possible to get a duty magistrate. That could be a provision looked at rather than extending it to a justice of the peace as well.

I note that in the general provisions dealing with search warrants an issuing officer is either a magistrate or a justice of the peace. That provides some flexibility for the officers concerned and I see no trouble in that. However, something which is transmitted by electronic means could provide a problem if we, say, sent a fax to a justice of the peace who—as I know is the case in my home state in Western Australia—could be the local chemist or a person in a remote area. We would have that added assurance if it were a magistrate. I take on board the comments that Senator Spindler made. Perhaps that is a matter which the government could look at in the committee stage and I would welcome any comment that the government might have. That deals with my comments on the obtaining of warrants.

I have already covered the issue of identification parades. I do not think there is any need to take that any further. As for the requirement to furnish a name and address, as contained in proposed section 3T, I can understand the need for police to ascertain witnesses who might be at the scene. I would not go so far as to say that police be allowed to obtain the names and addresses only of people they suspect have committed an indictable offence. The commission of any offence would be sufficient.

In Western Australia there is a wide power for police to obtain the name and address of any citizen. From my experience, that has not been a situation of abuse. I certainly have not encountered it. There are other areas of police powers which could well be looked at. But, from my experience in Western Australia, that is not one which I have seen readily abused. I can understand that some people might say, `If you are just a witness, why should the police ask you your name and address?'. There is also the query, `If you are not going to provide your name and address, or you are going to prove obstructive, then you would not be a very good witness anyway'. Those perhaps are salient points to make.

The obtaining of information is an important power for police officers in the exercise of their duties. Therefore, I find that that is a question which labours itself somewhat with me. I can understand the concerns of people who say that it might be providing too much power for police to just ask anyone they think might be a witness or involved in some way to provide a name and address. I certainly have no problem, though, with a policeman asking for the name and address of someone who he has reasonable grounds to suspect has committed any offence because that is the first step in the investigative process. I would be interested in the comments on the Australian Federal Police in that regard. Perhaps that is something which can be obtained in the meantime until the committee stage is reached.

This bill is a reasonable bill in the way that it sets out the powers and restrictions on police exercising this very important part of their duties. The uniformity of it has merit. Perhaps it is unfair to expect policemen to labour under different regimes or schemes of legislation in a variety of states. We might have one situation in Western Australia and another situation in New South Wales. Some states are code states; some are not. Of course, I think that is a situation to be taken into account. It may be helpful if the government could look at those matters I have raised. Perhaps those matters could be sorted out in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill and summarise some of the concerns that the Greens (WA) have in relation to the new aspects that are being introduced at this time. This bill enlarges police powers without commensurate protection for those people who may be affected by those powers. The new parts of the bill that we are seeing and discussing today make provision for obtaining and executing search warrants—including telephone warrants, stopping and searching conveyances, arrest and related matters such as personal searches, taking and destroying fingerprints, holding identification parades and other identification procedures.

PARA.TAB: The matter that Senator Ellison just raised is the first one on a list of concerns. This bill creates an offence of not giving one's name and address to a police officer. I must say to Senator Ellison that I have had quite a deal of experience in our home state of Western Australia. I have had so many comments and allegations on the abuse of this power in our state that I begin to wonder whether there is not very substantial basis underlying it.

There certainly is a discriminatory capacity that can be established within certain police cultures. I am not saying that it exists everywhere or in all situations. In Western Australia, for example, a large group of the population has never seen the side of police culture that would abuse that power or take advantage of it. I know there are many people in Western Australia—and I among them—who have never had any problems personally with the police. They have always been very helpful.

On the other hand, through my work within the criminal justice system, I have seen that people on the other side of the poverty line or socioeconomic status have seen a totally different side to police behaviour. There has been a discriminatory capacity whereby people who already feel somewhat harassed or underprivileged in our society feel even more harassed when a policeman has the power to ask them information without having any correct basis. It can be used as an intimidatory measure and that is something which I do not believe we can afford to encourage in our society, especially when there is an absence of any independent police complaints process and we only have police investigating police. There are times when police culture can be such that giving them powers that may be abused under certain circumstances is very unwise. I believe there is an undue emphasis on allowing this within a state police force, and I am, therefore, concerned about it at a federal level.

Proposed section 3U(1)(b)(iii) is also an encouragement for police to arrest people rather than issue a summons. In this day and age, we should be encouraging alternative methods to detention. It is extremely costly, for one thing, to arrest people rather than to issue a summons. Issuing a summons is very reliable; there are very few times when it cannot be used. Arresting people is enormously costly to the people personally and in terms of social disruption. There is also a very great economic cost. It encourages police to have an arrest mentality instead of focusing on the positive influence they can have within our community. They can be assisted in their work by the incentive of an orderly approach in responding to a summons rather than using powers to arrest.

Proposed section 3ZK(7) creates an adverse assumption if a person refuses to take part in an identification parade. Senator Ellison presented the view, with which I agree, that there is an inconsistency here. There seems to be a creeping attack on the presumption of innocence—a presumption that is very important in our legal system.

It is my understanding that this bill was severely criticised before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I know that the government, the opposition and the Democrats are preparing amendments to the bill. Hopefully, they will remedy some of the defects that are of concern, and I will await those amendments before saying whether or not we are happy to support this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the debate on the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill, I begin by making it clear that the government is willing to make reasonable and balanced amendments to this bill. This will be pursued during the coming week, as Senator Chamarette has just foreshadowed. The government's decision to defer the committee stage of this debate until next week, which has been communicated to honourable senators, will provide further opportunity for others to comment on the bill and will enable proper consideration to be given to amendments proposed by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Senator Spindler, the opposition, or indeed by anyone else.

PARA.TAB: The Senate standing committee report was tabled only on Monday afternoon. The government members of the committee have recommended amendments, which the minister is prepared to accept, but the opposition has indicated that it wishes to further consider this matter. It would be helpful, obviously, if any proposals to emerge from that consideration were to be made available prior to the committee stage of this debate commencing. In the circumstances, there is no real utility in my seeking to address any of the substantive matters that have been raised during the debate. There will be ample opportunity to do that in the committee stage, and I respond accordingly.

Consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 22 February of House of Representatives message.
Schedule of the amendment made to which the House of Representatives disagrees:
Part 7, line 17 (page 51) to line 11 (page 57), omit the Part.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate—

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill requires full passage to implement beneficial changes to service pension assessment and maintain the nexus of pension assessment with the Social Security Act.

The Senate amendment prevents the managed investment amendments contained in the Bill. The Opposition wants to delay any amendment to the income and assets tests until the independent review of the income and assets tests for service and social security pensions hands down its recommendations.

The Government could not responsibly delay these amendments awaiting the outcome of the review to become law. The Government is keen not to make any major changes until the review has been reported, but the measures contained in this Bill benefit service pensioners.
In particular, the managed investment amendments are to the advantage of service pensioners with these forms of investment. The measures clarify the operation of the existing legislation by:
. ensuring that all losses from managed investments can offset profits from other managed investments;
. ensuring that where an interim rate of return is declared, that return is applied and not an extrapolation of that rate; and
. introducing a safeguard to prevent a change in the status of an investment company from affecting the assessment of investments made with that company.

In the current economic climate a number of friendly societies have changed status to life offices. No income is held on friendly society investments made before 1 January 1988 until the investment is cashed in or "realised" in some other manner. The existing legislation treats the conversion of a friendly society to a life interest as an action that "realises" the investment even though the pensioner has no control in the changes made to the friendly society and has not physically withdrawn the investment.
Aside from the managed investment amendments other beneficial measures in the Bill are:
. the introduction of a Seniors Health Card for non-pensioner retirees who meet an income test and certain residency requirements.

. assisting families in providing greater flexibility in the delivery of child-related payments (eg, the ability to redirect part of the veteran's child-related payment to his former partner where the custody of the child is shared but the former partner is the primary care-giver).
. the exemption as income of payments received from the NSW Medically-Acquired HIV Trust.

Failure to pass the Bill as a whole will result in a piecemeal and inconsistent approach to pension assessment by creating differences and maintaining anomalies between social security and service pensioners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the committee does not insist upon the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill requires full passage to implement beneficial changes to service pension assessment and to maintain the nexus of pension assessment with the Social Security Act. The Senate amendment prevents the managed investment amendments contained in the bill. PARA.TAB: The government is keen not to make any major changes until the review has been reported, but the measures contained in this bill do benefit service pensioners. In particular, the managed investment amendments are to the advantage of service pensioners with these forms of investment. The measures clarify the operation of the existing legislation in the following ways: by ensuring that all losses from managed investments can offset profits from other managed investments; by ensuring that where an interim rate of return is declared that return is applied—it is not an extrapolation of that rate; and by introducing a safeguard to prevent a change in the status of an investment company from affecting the assessment of investments made with that company.

In the current economic climate, a number of friendly societies have changed status to life offices. No income is held on friendly society investments made before 1 January 1988 until the investment is cashed in or realised in some other manner. The existing legislation treats the conversion of a friendly society to a life interest as an action that realises the investment, even though the pensioner has no control in the changes made to the friendly society and has not physically withdrawn the investment.

Aside from the managed investment amendments, other beneficial measures contained in the bill include the introduction of a seniors health card for non-pensioner retirees who meet an income test and certain residency requirements; assisting families in providing greater flexibility in the delivery of child-related payments—for example, the ability to redirect part of the veteran's child-related payment to his former partner where the custody of the child is shared but the former partner is the primary caregiver; and the exemption as income of payments received from the New South Wales Medically-Acquired HIV Trust.

Failure to pass the bill as a whole will result in a piecemeal and inconsistent approach to pension assessment by creating differences and maintaining anomalies between social security and service pensioners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be no change in the position of the opposition. For good reason, we opposed those parts of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) when it came through this chamber some week or two ago. We opposed them on precisely the same grounds as we opposed the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) just before Christmas, and I do not propose to canvass the arguments again. Simply stated, we will not be party to changes in retirement income until the committee set up by the government to look at the whole system reports to the government and we have a considered response from the government to that.

PARA.TAB: As I said in my speech at the time, there are winners and losers in the proposition. All we have heard from Senator Evans is the winners' side of it, but there are downsides as well as upsides in this bill. We accept that. We are quite realistic about accepting that there are some good points as well as some bad points in the bill. I would like to quote from the final paragraph of the Committee of Reasons, when it said:

SPEECH.PARA: Failure to pass the bill as a whole will result in a piecemeal and inconsistent approach to pension assessment by creating differences and maintaining anomalies between social security and service pensioners.

It is precisely that point about a piecemeal and inconsistent approach to pension assessment upon which our objection to the bill is based. It is wrong for the government to say, `You buy the whole bill or none of the bill'. It is the business of government to present legislation to the parliament, and it is for the parliament to decide what is fitting legislation and what is not. The parliament, in the form of this chamber, has spoken. It has said that we are quite happy to pass this bill, except for one or two clauses. It is quite possible for the government to accept the will of the Senate and to pass the bill as amended and get such things as the seniors health card and other benefits into legislation.

PARA.TAB: Another thing the government can do is to exercise the due process that it has already put in place—the committee of inquiry. There is no reason why the committee of inquiry, which is now fully set up, with appointees to the committee, cannot report before September. The people on it understand the retirement incomes field and could very well make their report, provided they were given the resources by the government, in quite a short period of time. I do not think a period of more than four to six weeks is unrealistic if the government is sincere about wanting to tackle this problem. If the committee reported within that time, it would then be possible for the government to introduce the legislation in the budget in May this year. Instead, the minister has said, in a very crude attempt to blackmail the parliament, `If you don't pass this bill it will be two years before we get around to doing anything in a legislative form to correct these anomalies'. The parliament is not going to be blackmailed in that way.

The government can also introduce different legislation that copes with the parliament's wishes. At the end of the day, it should be remembered that the bill, as printed, provides that the parts in contention will not come into law until 1 July 1994. It is only February at present, so the crocodile tears from the government that somehow or other we are being unkind to the community in general will not wash.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will also not be changing their position on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993. I support almost everything said by Senator MacGibbon, and in particular the emphasis that it really is the government's choice whether or not the good parts of this bill get through. The Senate has made it very plain that we only have a problem with one small section. As far as the Democrats are concerned, we will not be changing our minds on that issue.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the review that is now going ahead, I do have to disagree with Senator MacGibbon. I believe that it needs time; in particular, it needs time to consult. I do not wish to bring forward the reporting date because there is enormous interest in the community and a wide range of organisations are already in the process of getting together their submissions to that inquiry. It is, therefore, up to the government simply to accept the will of the Senate and to let the bill go through with the amendments that were passed last time. Therefore, the veterans will not be in any way disadvantaged.

That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (HOME CHILD CARE AND PARTNER ALLOWANCES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 February, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. This bill is a direct result of a Labor election promise—a pea and thimble type promise where it took with one hand and gave with the other. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in his announcement at the launch of the Labor Party's election campaign, said that women at home would get $30. I know for a fact that a number of women voted for Labor on that basis. Little did they realise that it would be the dependent spouse rebate transferred to the social security area with a very small increase which would then be called the home child-care and partner allowance. So the government gave with one hand, took with the other and, with a sleight of hand and a very small increase of something like $2.60, tricked people into thinking they would get $30 extra.

PARA.TAB: That was exactly the theme of the government's campaign: it either tricked the Australian public the whole way along or gave promises that were going to be broken. The Australian public remembers the broken promises very clearly and that message comes home strongly out in the community. This government made promises before the election and then broke those promises, and it made other promises which were really like this one—a sleight of hand. In its policy document the government stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, a Keating Government will increase the dependent spouse rebate and pay it directly to the spouse at home caring for children. The new Home Child Care Allowance will be $30 a week and will provide some source of independent income for women at home caring full time for children.
This initiative was heralded by the Labor Party as a major step forward for Australian families. In reality, for most families it meant no more than an extra litre of milk and loaf of bread a week.

PARA.TAB: This government's record in relation to families needs to be put into proper perspective. There are two million Australian families living in poverty; 400,000 long-term unemployed—we saw yesterday that those figures have tripled in the past four years; 300,000 families with neither parent working; and family breakdown at record high levels. Australian families will gladly accept the extra loaf of bread and the extra litre of milk—under Labor, many of them desperately need it—but this meagre initiative will not solve their problems.

In terms of helping families, the Keating government is very good at putting in one pocket while it takes from the other. As I said before, this is a prime example. On the one hand, the government has introduced a non-means tested home child-care allowance.
