On the other hand, since the election it has reduced the income and assets thresholds for family payment, extended the income definition for family payment to include employer fringe benefits, applied the family payment income and assets test to student families, limited family payment arrears payments, and sought to transfer 16-year-old Austudy recipients to family payment—a measure which was blocked by the Senate but which would have left two-thirds of affected families worse off if it had been allowed to go ahead.

Not one of these measures to tighten eligibility for family-related benefits was mentioned prior to the election. The government did not tell the Australian public about the tough things; it told them about the goodies and the pea and thimble tricks, and it made the public promises that it did not keep.All of the measures I have just listed have been forced onto an unsuspecting Australian public. In total, they will result in savings of in excess of $200 million a year. Senator Crowley informed the Senate committee which looked at this bill that the transfer to the home child-care allowance would cost $230 million a year. This means that the sum of the changes to assistance for families since the election has been basically revenue neutral. The net benefit for Australian families has been a big, fat nil.

But Australian families believed that they would be the great beneficiaries of Labor's largess at the last election. One must ask how long it will be before the hardheads of the Labor Party decide that the home child-care allowance will be means tested. Now that the work of dependent spouses is to be recognised through the social security system and not the taxation system, this new allowance will immediately become a prime target for income and assets testing. Of course, the government will vehemently deny that. However, one needs to look only as far as the family payment to realise that such assurances are totally meaningless.

The coalition recognises that a number of benefits will be derived from transferring families with dependent spouses and children from the dependent spouse rebate to the home child-care allowance. These benefits include: the home child-care allowance being paid directly to the parent caring for the child or children; the home child-care allowance being paid at a slightly higher maximum rate of $60 per fortnight; families whose tax liability was too low to receive the full benefit of the dependent spouse rebate being eligible for the home child-care allowance; parents leaving the paid work force to care for a dependent child perhaps being able to claim the home child-care allowance even though their income for that financial year may exceed the dependent spouse rebate income threshold.

However, we are concerned that a significant number of families with dependent spouses and dependent children who are currently eligible for the dependent spouse rebate will not be eligible to transfer to the home child-care allowance. The commitment by Labor prior to the election clearly indicated that all such families would be eligible to transfer to the home child-care allowance. This is clearly not the case. During the recent Senate committee hearing on this bill, Senator Crowley admitted that some will not be eligible.

Let me give the Senate some examples of some of the families who will not be eligible for the home child-care allowance as a result of the transfer from the taxation system to the social security system. Families in which either the claimant or the child is out of Australia for a period of over 13 weeks will not be eligible for the home child-care allowance as a result of the differing residency requirements under the social security and income tax assessment acts. Under tax law, it is only necessary to be a taxpayer to be eligible for the dependent spouse rebate. It is envisaged that academic families, aid workers, exchange students and missionaries will be disadvantaged as a result of this anomaly. Interestingly, Australian government officials are effectively protected as they generally receive allowances to compensate them for payments that they are ineligible for because they are overseas.

Those families in which the youngest child is a dependent student aged 18 to 25 earning less than $1,875 a year will not be eligible to transfer to the home child-care allowance. This is because the allowance will cut out at age 18 or when the youngest child leaves secondary school, whichever is sooner. Previously, the dependent spouse rebate was paid to families of dependent students aged 18 to 25. Families of prescribed students will also be automatically excluded from the home child-care allowance. Currently, they are not automatically excluded from the dependent spouse rebate but any prescribed student payment, such as Austudy, is considered as income under the separate net income test.

Differences in the definition of `spouse' and `partner' between social security and tax legislation may mean that some families are unable to transfer to the home child-care allowance. The tax law includes `estranged spouse' in the definition of `spouse' that applies to the dependent spouse rebate; the Social Security Act does not. Tax law does not require that an eligible couple be of the age of consent; the Social Security Act includes such a requirement.

An unknown number of families will be excluded from the home child-care allowance due to differences in the definitions of `income' between the social security and taxation systems. Under the Social Security Act, the definition of `ordinary income' for the purposes of the home child-care allowance includes deemed income on bank accounts, any notional capital gains on shares and managed investments, and any deemed income from disposed assets, loans and gifts. Separate net income for the purpose of assessing dependent spouse rebate entitlement refers to a dependent's gross income less expenses incurred in earning that income. It does not include any of the abovementioned examples of income under the Social Security Act. The coalition is concerned that the more onerous income test under the Social Security Act will advertently disqualify from the home child-care allowance families who are qualified for the dependent spouse rebate.

During the committee hearing on this bill, coalition senators attempted to find out the number of otherwise eligible families that may be prevented from transferring to the home child-care allowance as a result of differences in residency and age requirements, prescribed student exclusions, and the difference in spouse and income definitions between the taxation and social security systems.

Neither the tax office nor the Department of Social Security could provide details of the number of families likely to be affected. All we were given were bland assurances that the number of affected families was likely to be low. That is not good enough. It shows a distinct lack of effective planning by the government in the development of this initiative as well as a worrying disregard about its possible adverse impact on individual families. Accordingly, I foreshadow that I will

SPEECH.PARA: move a second reading amendment that consideration of this bill in the committee of the whole be postponed until the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) tables amendments to ensure that families are not unjustifiably prevented from transferring to the home child-care allowance from the dependent spouse rebate as a result of differences in the definitions and other relevant provisions between the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Social Security Act.

PARA.TAB: This bill also represents another extension in the use of tax file numbers for purposes outside the taxation system. When the tax file number was first introduced, the then Treasurer—the current Prime Minister—said that it would only be used by the Taxation Office for tax purposes. Since then we have seen the insidious creep of the use of the tax file number, of which this is another example. A significant number of dependent spouses will be required to provide their tax file numbers to the Department of Social Security for the first time. Some will be required to obtain tax file numbers from the tax office for the first time. As I said, the coalition remains concerned about the ever-widening use of tax file numbers under this government for non-taxation purposes.

Another issue of concern is the fact that the government is merely paying lip service to privacy and the opinions of the office of the Privacy Commissioner in the development of initiatives such as the home child-care allowance. Documentation provided to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs indicates that the Privacy Commissioner was given one day in which to respond to the department in relation to this bill. That is not good enough. The Privacy Commissioner was appointed to protect the privacy of the Australian public in issues such as this. As a parliament, we should also be vigilant in matters going to the privacy of the Australian public.

Here we have the Privacy Commissioner being given one day to comment on a bill where there is provision for the extension of the use of tax file numbers. I ask the minister to ask the department—or to ask the government because that is where the buck stops—why the Privacy Commissioner only had that one day to look at this bill. On behalf of the opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion for the second reading, add: ", but that consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be postponed until there is laid on the Table of the Senate by the Leader of the Government, amendments to the bill to ensure that families in the following circumstances are not unjustifiably excluded from the Home Child Care Allowance as a result of differences, in the relevant definitions and other provisions, between the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Social Security Act 1991:
(a)families that comply with current residency requirements for taxation purposes but in which the claimant or dependent child is overseas for a period exceeding 13 weeks;
(b)families in which the youngest dependent child is aged between 18 and 25 years, in full time education, with an income below $1,785 a year; and
(c)families which would be eligible for the Home Child Care Allowance were it not for the automatic exclusion of `prescribed' students".

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 introduces two new allowances—the home child-care allowance and the partner allowance. The home child-care allowance replaces the dependent spouse rebate. It is only for couples who have children being cared for at home. The maximum rate of the allowance will be $30 a week, an increase of $2.60 a week over the maximum rate of the DSP. The allowance will be reduced by $1 for every $4 of income earned over $282 a year. This means that carers with incomes of less than $10.85 a fortnight will receive a full payment. The payment will phase out completely when the partner's income exceeds $250 a fortnight or $6,500 a year.

PARA.TAB: I would like to spend some time talking about the partner's allowance. Essentially, it splits JSA, newstart, special benefit and sickness benefit so that the partner of the recipient gets a proportion of the benefit. The Australian Democrats share the concern about the actions of any future government—not necessarily this government—to move to work test or assets test the second part of the benefit, or in some way to apply additional tests that the partner must meet. Today, I will deal only with what we have before us and express the hope that this is not the beginning of further restrictions on the partner of a recipient.

The income that the partner will receive will be the amount over and above the single rate of benefit, and I am very pleased to see this measure introduced. When I came to the Senate in 1990 this was one of the first issues raised with me by people working in various welfare organisations—particularly the Sisters of St Joseph in Adelaide, who pushed strongly for the splitting of the benefit into two equal parts. While the bill has not gone quite that far, this move will certainly be welcomed by them.

Their shared concern was that some families are unable to come to any sort of reasonable arrangement when it comes to working out how much money should be set aside for essentials, such as food and clothing—particularly for children. Unfortunately, and for a variety of reasons, the money is often spent—in most cases, by the male partner—on non-essentials, with charities then having to supply the essentials for the female partner and children. The measure proposed in this bill goes a small way towards guaranteeing those women their own income.

I acknowledge that with many families the money will still go into a joint account. As reported in the newspaper today, the vast majority of Australian couples have a joint account. However, with this measure, women will receive money in their own names and that sends the significant message: the partner is also of value and her work in the home is valued. She is entitled to receive this money in her own name and, if she so desires, to move it into an account held in her own name.

The Democrats took up this suggestion from a number of agencies, in particular the Sisters of St Joseph in Adelaide, and have included it in each of our subsequent alternative budgets. While we did want the payments split down the middle, I acknowledge that the way the government has done it in this case is certainly better than nothing.

I have noted the comments that the home care child allowance is some sort of trick or sleight of hand, but it is no more than replacing one benefit with another, with a very slight income increase in the process. This legislation replaces the dependent spouse rebate, but the fact that we do not consider the amount to be enough does not mean that we should not support something that is a small step in the right direction. It is a long overdue shift in government policy and recognises the value of the work done by those who remain at home. It is about acknowledging the importance of the contribution made by those people, mostly women, who stay at home and care for children.

Hopefully, once this work is better recognised and acknowledged by the community, we will have a few more men who are comfortable about sharing that role, with more couples seriously considering taking turns to move in and out of the work force or taking a proportional share of the load of working outside the home as well as doing a fair share of the work that needs to be done inside the home. It is a very small step but a necessary one towards formal recognition of the value of what has been unpaid work.

This bill is more than just cosmetic. It represents a shift in both philosophy and community attitudes. It signals a willingness to see the role of carer as being an important and valuable one in its own right and one which we should reward financially. It is a major improvement on the old system of the dependent spouse rebate. Under that rebate, the person in employment—the recognised breadwinner—received the actual benefit. There was absolutely no way of guaranteeing that the partner knew the value of the benefit, let alone saw any specific increase in the amount of money going towards the family budget on a weekly or a fortnightly basis. The family as a whole received the money but, unfortunately, not always did that flow through to benefit members of the family other than the breadwinner.

This bill ensures that the person who is caring for the children receives albeit a very small amount of money but nevertheless money intended for that person. In other words, such people can get cash in hand, in their own name, and not have to rely on their spouse's goodwill. Both the child-care allowance and the partner allowance make that important distinction, and it is a crucial distinction which has not been recognised until now. It is crucial because, as a direct payment to the partner who is staying at home, it acknowledges the personal costs of caring for those children—costs which are usually borne by women.

In Australia at present, the birth of a child signals a clear divergence by gender in what we can best call life opportunities. For women, motherhood generally means an interruption to their paid career, and statistics show that it is often very difficult for them to get back into that career. It also signals a dramatic increase in the amount of domestic duties they have to perform. For men, fatherhood means longer weekly hours of paid work but rarely, if ever, a significant increase in their unpaid work. That discrepancy immediately reduces women's capacity even to keep up to date with their careers and it limits their ability to participate in a whole range of other activities in the community, whether social, sporting or recreational. It is a very heavy price to pay and, as a community, we should be acknowledging that price.

I believe that this allowance is a very small but significant step along that road. It is also an important step towards creating more flexible employment opportunities for both men and women. As I said before, I hope we will now see more men thinking twice before automatically assuming that it will be the wife who makes that career choice on a long-term or permanent basis.

We have to make these changes. Such changes are critical if we are to rethink our definition of work. We have to think again about work patterns. In the long term, if we do not do that, these patterns of work will lead to higher levels of unemployment and increased divisiveness and polarisation of our community. If we are going to avoid those outcomes but still get rid of the gender gap in both paid and unpaid work, we will need to look at strengthening two areas: firstly, more flexible and adequate child care options; and, secondly, the recognition and support of unpaid work.

For many years the Democrats have called for some formal recognition of the work done by what has been called the invisible work force, most of whom are women. During the last election we called for a taxable means-tested primary care-givers allowance of $80 a week. Under our proposal, dependent partners earning less than $38.50 a fortnight, or $2,000 a year, would receive the full payment of $160 a fortnight. The payment would then be phased out on a dollar for dollar basis, cutting out completely when the dependent partner's income exceeded $235 a fortnight, or $6,100 a year. In other words, we were more generous than the government in terms of the amount of any allowance and the income test limits; but, unlike the government, we felt that the payment should be taxable in order to reduce the benefit to middle and very high income earning families.

While we have a difference of opinion with the government as to the amount and structure and, particularly, the level at which it should be paid, this is not sufficient reason to move in any way against this bill or to seek to delay or oppose it. I find it interesting that so many people have suddenly jumped on the carers bandwagon and, in some cases, are calling for quite spectacular amounts to be paid. I worry about some of these claims because I think there is a real danger that in moving to pay spouses who are staying at home while their partners work we may be overlooking the financial needs of several other groups within the community, in particular those families where neither parent is able to get into the paid work force. That includes sole parent families and carers of aged and disabled people. In many cases, those people are struggling to make ends meet, with the enormous loads they carry.

If we increase the amounts we pay to those caring for children at home, we have to be careful that we do not leave behind a range of other groups in the community who are also in need. It is all very well for us to talk to the media about payments of $130 a week. We have to be very clear about who is going to get that payment, how it is going to be targeted, and how we are going to pay for all of it.

On that point, I note that Senator Minchin will be speaking after me in this debate. Having read the Sunday Mail last week and noted his call for a universal tax credit for people who stay at home, I ask him whether he could reconcile that call with the comments made on the same day by the shadow Treasurer stating that the Liberals would not support any tax increases in this year's budget and that they would not support any increases in taxes before the next election. Claims such as that for a universal child-care tax credit raise the question: how does the Liberal Party propose to pay for these measures?

I acknowledge that Senator Minchin has made some very interesting points. It is good to see more and more people coming out in support of women who stay at home. But if we are not going to raise taxes or introduce new taxes, how are we going to compensate for losing that pool of money from the tax system? We need to be far more honest when we are talking to the community about taxation and equate it with services, because the two go hand in hand. If we are looking for additional support for people who stay at home, we have to acknowledge that the money has to come from somewhere.

Another alternative is to cut services. Senator Minchin might tell us whether there are any particular services he would like removed. I have no objections to his aims—indeed, the Democrats have continuously called for acknowledgment of unpaid work. However, we have to be honest and say where the money will come from.

When talking about these allowances we have to be very careful—and I have tried to be careful during my speech today—that while talking generally about women, we should not give the impression of trying to entice women out of the work force to make way for men. I believe that in talking to the media all honourable senators have a responsibility to make it very clear that we are talking about paid versus unpaid work, not women's work versus what was traditionally seen as men's work. I hope we do not get into a situation where we support that very small number of groups in the community whose hidden agenda is to go back to the `good old days' where women stayed home and did the `right' thing by not getting in the way of men's careers.

The Democrats will support this bill. It is about giving choice, certainly nowhere near the amount of choice we would like to see; but it is a very small and tentative step in the right direction. We have to move a lot faster and further if we are to give women real choice about whether they stay home and care for their children or whether they try to hang on to a career. As one who made that choice and found that after a few years of child rearing the opportunities to get back into a career were closed, I can certainly speak from first-hand experience and say that we need to look very carefully at how fast we move in this direction and where we go. I stress again that this allowance will not give most families a real opportunity to have one or other partner stay at home.

I cannot sit down before commenting on Senator Patterson's very strange set of amendments. In nearly four years here, I have never seen an opposition refuse to pass a bill until the government has drawn up its amendments. This bill was originally due for debate on Monday. I cannot remember any time when it has taken me more than two days to have amendments drawn up by the Clerks, unless the amendments were so complicated and relied so heavily on other provisions that they involved some enormous legal technicality. I cannot understand why we have not even seen any attempt at draft amendments and why the government is being asked to plan the opposition's amendments. We see no reason for delaying this bill which needs to go through today. We have already had several days of delay, so we will not support this attachment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Lees on the tenor of her remarks. I will refer to some of the questions she raised about positions I have adopted on this issue. The Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill establishes a home child-care allowance to replace the dependent spouse rebate—in principle, a welcome move. It publicly provides some recognition of an enormous contribution made to society by principally mothers who make the sacrifice to stay at home to care for their young, particularly pre-school children.

PARA.TAB: I guess we are all aware of the dreadful housewife syndrome that exists in Australia which most manifests itself at dinner parties where a male will say to a woman, `And what do you do?'. If the woman replies `I am a housewife', the male immediately turns to somebody else to have a conversation. It is one of the most disgraceful aspects of Australian society. By staying at home mothers make an enormous contribution to society. Probably the most important job in our society is the nurturing and care of children. Mothers who sacrifice their careers to perform that unpaid task need all the recognition and value that we can give them, and this bill goes some way towards that. As Senator Lees said, the other virtue of the bill is that the allowance is a direct payment to the primary carer—to the mother and not to the taxpayer. I think that is a good move.

Senator Patterson has indicated opposition amendments. In response to Senator Lees, I make the point that it is for the government to deal with the problems we have identified on this bill and we expect the government to come back with the answers to those problems.

It has to be acknowledged that the home child-care allowance is not some great act of generosity by the government. We are talking about a mere $2.88 a week for those eligible for the DSR, the dependent spouse rebate. We are not talking about some Santa Claus act by the government—it is a very small amount. The change to the home child-care allowance, welcome though it may be, highlights the very real problem of government policy discrimination against the very people that I have been talking about—those mothers who sacrifice an income to care for pre-school children.

The bill shows that the government knows it has a real problem in discrimination between mothers who go to paid work with young children and who put them into child care, and those mothers who do not but who stay at home to look after their children. This was particularly highlighted by the introduction of the act covering the child-care rebate. That aroused great controversy and was very controversial within the Australian Labor Party. The very act of bringing in that child-care rebate and promising it meant that the government knew it had a real problem.

Having run a lot of election campaigns, I can imagine the thought process. Campaigners during the last election would have said, `If we bring this child-care rebate in, as generous as it is, we will have a very big problem with all the women in society who will not be eligible for this because they are staying at home to look after their children. How will we cope with that in an election campaign environment?'. Someone had the brilliant idea of saying, `Let's just turn the DSR into an allowance. It's not going to cost us much—a couple of bucks a week on top to make it look like it's all right and bingo, we satisfy that political problem'. That was a classic campaign manoeuvre. It probably paid some dividend for the government but it was, to us, a recognition that the government knew it had a problem in the discrimination between different types of mothers. The reality is that this bill does not deal with that discrimination at all. That discrimination continues to exist.

The discrimination is most significant in the following aspects. First, the child-care rebate is not means-tested at all; whereas there is a very significant eligibility test for the home child-care allowance. So that is a very significant element of discrimination. Secondly, they are paid at very different rates: for a mother with two children the difference is 100 per cent. A mother at home with two children gets $30 a week; but a mother who goes out to work gets $60 a week. There is simply no basis for that sort of discrimination.

Regardless of income, there is a child-care rebate of up to $61 a week available to parents with children in external child care. Our response to that was to advocate an income test for the child-care rebate in an attempt to minimise the discrimination in current policy on assistance to mothers with children. But the government, for its own reasons, rejected our proposition. However, the failure to income-test the child-care rebate has manifested this extraordinary inequity with regard to mothers who sacrifice an income to stay at home to look after their children.

I have been very interested in the recent responses received by my office from mothers who find themselves in this position. The government will probably say that we are just inflaming the situation and stirring things up. But the fact is that this situation is turning mother against mother. It is building up a lot of resentment in the community among those mothers who choose to stay at home. They know they are being discriminated against; they do not understand why. They feel resentful to the government, to politicians, to mothers who put their kids in child care and go out to work, and that is very sad. It is one of the most unfortunate consequences of this most peculiar difference in treatment in which the government is now engaged.

The home child-care allowance is income tested. A mother cannot earn more than $282 a year before she starts losing this new benefit at a rate of a dollar for every extra $4 that she earns. So a woman who earns $282 a day or $282 an hour, which some female solicitors probably earn, can get $61 a week for child-care costs. For putting her children into child care the government will, in effect, give her $61 a week. But a woman at home with two children and earning $282 a year will start to lose her benefit.

It is an unbelievable discrimination against those women. It really is inequitable. The fact is that the government right throughout, whatever it says, is biased towards those mothers who make the choice to put their children into child care. There is no doubt about that. We can read all the speeches. The government talks about making it as easy as possible for women to get back into the paid work force and says, `We will look after all the child care for you. If you choose to stay at home, that is tough. Sorry, we are not going to do much for you'.

Now there is the home care allowance. We have talked about that. But there is no doubt the bias is in favour of women who choose to go back into the paid work force. This bill does not disguise that. The difficulty with the government's attempts to disguise this problem is that we are getting into the most extraordinarily complex approach to the whole business of assistance to mothers with young children. It is becoming an unbelievable administrative shemozzle. The administrative costs in the Child Care Rebate Act are a scandal in themselves. This will now be administratively complex. The DSR is going to continue for some couples and not for others. In our proposed amendments we have highlighted problems in relation to administration.

So this whole area is becoming unbelievably complex because of the political shenanigans that the government is involved in. I set out the principles that, in my view, should operate in relation to government policy for assistance to parents with young children. The system, whatever it is, obviously should be as simple as possible. Parents with young children find life difficult enough as it is without having to wade through an extraordinary maze of bureaucracy to find out what benefits they are entitled to. That is the current position.

The most elementary principle should be that of fairness among different mothers in different situations. There should be equity among mothers in relation to their children, whether they are in child care or not. The government should be neutral in its approach to this situation. It is for mothers to decide whether they put their children into child care or whether they care for them at home. That is a decision the mother should make without the government getting involved one way or the other in the making of that choice. So the policy should be neutral in its treatment of mothers in that situation.

My final principle is that of providing the greatest possible degree of choice for mothers in this situation. We should make it possible for mothers to choose what course they will adopt and what is best for the children in their family situation. I do not believe the government should seek to influence that choice one way or the other. There is no doubt that at the moment government policy, whether consciously or unconsciously, influences that choice in one direction and not in another; and that is towards placing children in external child care. I will not go into all the issues of whether that is good or bad for children. That is a debate in itself.

The fact is that in this area living standards for most Australians have declined over the last 10 years. Life has become tougher, particularly for young parents with young children. The interest rate saga of a few years ago devastated people in this situation, and they are still paying some of the highest real interest rates in the world.

That has led to a situation where the government's own agency acknowledges that at least 60 per cent of mothers who have young children and who are in the paid work force would prefer, if they could afford it, to be at home looking after their children. Whether the government's advisers like it or not, that is what they would prefer to be doing; but economic circumstance forces them to go into the paid work force.

The only fair approach is for the government to treat all mothers equally. That is the only way that a government should attempt to deal with this issue of assistance to mothers with young children. For some time I have advocated a universal approach. That approach should be based on the fact of having young children; not on the fact of whether or not they are in some form of child care that is external, or whether it is with grandparents or the mother. That just leads to the enormous complexity we are now getting into. It is soaking up so many tax dollars simply in administration and not getting through to the people we really want to help. So the only approach is to base it on the fact that a young mother or carer has young children; and make the payment or the benefit according to that criterion—and no other.

I have advocated that this should be done as a universal tax credit or benefit that is uniform and flat; and it is paid to mothers or primary carers with young children on the basis of a per child payment. I do not see any other way around it. It is then for the mother or primary carer to choose the form of child care that most suits that carer, whether that be by way of making it more feasible for the mother to stay at home, or whether the mother chooses to spend that money on external child care—grandmother or next-door neighbour or professional child care. I cannot see why the government is so ideologically opposed to such an approach. It seems to be the only fair approach to avoid the awful situation we are getting to in this area.

Senator Lees fairly asked the question, `How could society possibly afford such an approach?'. It is a matter of making choices, but it could be done without increasing government expenditure in this area. The fact is that the government is now spending around $8,000 million on assistance to families with young children—$8 billion. There are about four million children in Australia under 15. If we take the age to 15, the number is four million. Obviously the simple mathematics of that is that, without spending an extra dollar, the government could provide $2,000 per annum for every child in Australia under the age of 15 in the form of a benefit for those not paying tax, or a tax credit for those who are paying tax.

For example, even if it is the high-income female solicitor we are talking about, if she is paying $20,000 a year tax, the credit would equate to provide her with a tax bill of $18,000. The mother who chose to stay at home and look after her children would get $2,000 benefit in tax credit in her hand for every child that she has, thus making it more feasible for her to make that choice to stay at home. But it remains her choice.

So in answer to Senator Lees, what I am proposing would not involve additional expenditure. It would be nice if, as a community, we could afford to make it more than $2,000. Those are choices that society would have to make. I would probably be one for advocating reductions of expenditure in other areas to make it a more feasible proposition to go to a higher level. But it could be done now in a way that would provide real material benefit and real choice to mothers with young children, without increasing government expenditure.

This bill, while in principle we welcome the principles of it, does highlight the current inequities in the government's treatment of mothers with young children. The government needs to deal with it because the problem is only going to get worse.

In conclusion, I cite the Sunday Mail of 20 February which, by dealing with this matter in an editorial and giving it front page treatment, shows that it is becoming a community issue. The government is going to have a real problem in this area unless it does something about it. The Sunday Mail said:
This scheme—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the home child-care allowance—

is nothing more than a clever sleight of hand. It is an objectionable demonstration of the lip-service this Government places on family values and the work and recognition of homemakers in the International Year of the Family.
It went on to say to the government:

PARA.TAB: Stop the rot, the waste and bandaid subsidies and distribute the money fairly to give families back their choice. Let families choose whether to spend the money on child care or to alleviate financial burdens. Women who want to work have every right, as do men who want to stay home to care for their children. But it must be their choice.

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse the words of the biggest selling newspaper in South Australia, and commend them to the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow Senator Minchin, and be both complementary and complimentary in my words.
—Read Hansard closely, Senator Herron.

—I am sure it will get it correct. I, too, have done some work on this. I have the figures that support the statement that Senator Minchin made, that it is possible to abolish the various allowances and introduce a homemakers allowance—a phrase that has been used previously—and produce revenue neutrality. I will be happy to supply that to Senator Lees. The year 1994 is the International Year of the Family, a time to stand back and look at what the family really is and perhaps, more importantly, what the family will be.

PARA.TAB: In some ways I feel that 1994 comes too late to be asking ourselves, `What is the family'? For many reasons the International Year of the Family will be a history lesson: a time to reflect on what the family was; a time to realise what we have lost; and a time to compare the family of yesterday with the stark contrast of what this government has left for the family unit of today. In the aftermath of the worst recession in 50 years, brought about by the Labor government—the Senate will recall the Prime Minister saying it was the recession we had to have—it is a wonder that families have survived. Divorce has become a fact of everyday life for nearly half of all Australian families. We have witnessed an alarming rise in the rate of reported cases of child abuse, spouse abuse and teen homelessness. Combine these factors with the harsh burden of the economic recovery, and the toll of modern life falls hardest on the innocent and the helpless—the children.

In this year of the family we have already had the social engineering by the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, and her child-care accreditation guidelines. This is just another case of government deciding what is best for the children and totally ignoring the views of the parents. What a way to start before we have even begun!

The home child-care and partner allowances were yet another carrot the government dangled in front of a hungry electorate in the lead-up to the last election. They were yet another example of an ill conceived and deceptive election promise that will end up costing a fortune to implement and bring very little comfort to the people that matter—in this case, the carers and their children.

The coalition does not seek to oppose this bill. On the contrary, anything that can help sustain Australian families and give them the much needed support that this government has failed to provide for them over the past 11 years is something the coalition gladly welcomes. The coalition welcomes this as much as we do the final admission by this government that it has failed to address the serious consequences of its decade of economic and social policy mismanagement.But, just like every promise we have heard from this government, a quick look at this proposal reveals a hasty and ill conceived piece of election propaganda that translates into a hasty and ill conceived piece of legislation.

The claim by the government that this new set of allowances will bring vast sums of money to more Australian families is simply false. The fact remains that the income of most families under these new allowances will not change, for these allowances are not so much an increase but a redistribution of funds. Certainly we will see some new recipients receiving allowances under these new programs, but at the same time it is estimated that over 116,000 families will simply stop receiving benefits. We have this complex and intricate legislation which requires us to pass an amendment just to close the loopholes and flaws present in the earlier legislation.

This is what I mean when I say that this is but one of the ill conceived and precipitous promises that the government makes to the weary electorate, ignoring the costs involved. Ignoring the obvious cost of such failed promises on the public's perception of government and parliament, we have the cost of the intricacy of this legislation that will feed a ravenous bureaucracy, ready to consume some $200 million in administration costs. A simpler and more equitable solution would be to provide the at-home parent with the allowance and avoid the bureaucratic monster that consumes so much of our social welfare payments. Let us avoid the means testing and all the complexities that beset such programs and focus on getting the money quickly and directly to those who need it, as Senator Minchin mentioned—that is, the carers and their children.

I welcome the words of Senator Lees that this legislation has not gone far or fast enough. The most important career in and for society is the nurture and care of young children, and yet there is discrimination in this legislation against those who stay at home and care for young children.

As I mentioned, the coalition does not seek to oppose this bill. We had referred it to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs to look at the shortfalls of this legislation, and there are many. In 1994, we have the opportunity as legislators, as parents and as children to ensure that the year of the family is not just another token 12 months to political correctness. I have said that 1994 is a little late to be focussing on the issues of the family when our most important social unit is feeling the burdens of modern life more than ever before.

Let us ensure that the year of the family is not just a bandaid for the suffering that Australian families have been enduring. I see this legislation as one such bandaid. Let us make certain that we use our resources and the precious time left this year to encourage a society in which the families of today can grow and strengthen so that they, in turn, may lay the foundations for a secure and stable society for tomorrow. That begins by helping those mothers who wish to stay at home and care for young children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to comment on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. I support the amendment moved by Senator Patterson. The bill is not urgent to be passed today, as Senator Lees indicated. It could be withdrawn and sent back to those who have drafted it for the amendments which clearly ought to be included in it to make the bill cover the range of people who ought to be covered by what the government is doing for a few. I think the way that has been proposed is totally appropriate. I hope that the government will do that, although I sense it will not.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about a bill that one would have expected to have been received quite enthusiastically and supported, and perhaps not even to have attracted much debate or attention at all, but there are some very good reasons why it is that it needs to be exposed for what it is. Senator Lees saw it as—I think I am quoting accurately—a small and significant step along the road towards recognising carers. She referred to it as being a shift to recognising the carer. So it is, up to a point, but it goes much further than that when it is compared with the child-care rebate, and that is what we must do to fully understand the philosophy of the Labor Party towards women and children by what is exposed in this act.

It was, as has been indicated, a promise from the Labor Party during the last federal election. It also is an idea that came from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, when it inquired into equal opportunity and equal status for women in Australia. It too recommended that the dependent spouse rebate be replaced with a payment directly paid to the parent caring for children. That is recognised in this legislation.

But the actual amount being paid has been withdrawn totally from so many families, as has been pointed out. I do not think anybody at the time of the last election realised that that fishhook was in the promise. It was, I think, genuinely perceived to be a replacement for the dependent spouse rebate—as it was—that would be paid to the person caring for the children. It was only a minuscule increase to $30 a week. But I think most people saw it as a genuine attempt to recognise the role of the carer, even though the amount being paid was virtually no different.

It is the fact that so many families have lost this allowance that comes as a real shock to a lot of people. I do not think they realised exactly what the government was attempting to do. That is the most significant aspect. It is to be means tested on the income of the recipient—I recognise that—and the person at home caring probably does not have a very high income, but it is means tested on an income of $282 per annum. To set up the infrastructure to be means testing this for an amount of $282 a year just seems absolutely incredible.

It indicates quite clearly that the government's attitude to minding children is an issue of welfare. It is in stark contrast to the attitude to the child-care rebate which was debated in this place not long ago. To receive the full $60 a fortnight the parent who is caring for the children has to be in receipt of less than $10.85 a fortnight. The amount of $60 a fortnight gets cut back, up to an income of $250 a fortnight.

So a mother who has two pre-school children in care can receive $63 a week no matter how high her income. The mother who is at home looking after her children will receive $30 a week, no matter how many children, means tested at the rate I have indicated. I have two daughters with one child each and it so happens that they fall one into each of these categories. Why they should be treated in this fashion and why one's contribution should be discriminated against to such an extent leaves me almost speechless—but not so speechless that I was not able to get up today and express my views on it.

I am not suggesting that there should not be a child-care rebate, as introduced, but the manner of these two payments, the attitude towards them, is absolutely staggering. Leaving aside even the amount, it is the attitude to women and children and the government's picking of models of families who will or will not be supported that I find absolutely incredible. This says an enormous amount about the Labor Party's attitude to children and to carers. The Labor Party has really exposed itself for what it is with this piece of legislation. All carers—whether of children, old people or whomever—should take note of the real attitude.

This payment is means tested and is a welfare payment. The child-care rebate is paid by the Department of Family Services through its children's services program—a much more costly system because it is a new system being put in place, whereas social security could have dealt with that as well. It distinguishes between types of people. A woman at home caring for her child is a welfare recipient of a means-tested pittance—the home care allowance we are referring to today. A woman at work may receive a child-care rebate. She may be earning $100,000 a year but she is still eligible to receive it because it is her right, and it is not means tested. I do not see how the government can possibly justify to the women of Australia dealing with women and children in these two discriminatory fashions. One is a welfare payment; one is a right. One family is treated cheaply; one family is treated generously.

The rhetoric of the International Year of the Family is exposed, I believe, by the comparison between the home child-care allowance and the child-care rebate. I can recall in days gone by Senator Button talking about the government not playing favourites when it came to industry and not supporting one or the other. One would have thought that, in legislation such as this, neutrality towards the status of women and children would have been maintained. If for a period a woman wanted to remain at home and care for her young children, that would be recognised as a reasonable, honourable and decent thing to do. If she wanted to be in the work force and have her children cared for commercially, that too would be an honourable, decent and worthwhile way of doing it. It is not a question of picking one or the other,

However, the Labor Party does just that, and it discriminates enormously against one type of woman. The favoured model of family for the Labor Party is being rewarded. Why is the other model of family not similarly rewarded? Both should be administered by the same department and both should be treated in the same way, that is, not means tested. Perhaps they should both be receiving the same amount of money, but that is getting into another area again. There are two other things that ought to be cleared up before one even starts thinking about that. I urge the government to withdraw this piece of legislation and bring it back in a way that is reasonable to the women of Australia who have young children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill. We heard recently the remarks in this chamber by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) about this being the International Year of the Family. Obviously, child care is an issue critical to all families. It is because of this that I wish to take the opportunity to speak briefly about the substantial increase in assistance to over 800,000 families throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I turn my attention to the home child-care allowance component of this bill, which is a major initiative in this special year and is indicative of the government's commitment to ensuring that families are regarded as an important entity requiring assistance, especially where children are involved. The focus of this allowance is the substantial contribution in the majority of cases made by mothers in the care of their children. This bill recognises and redresses this vital work, which for far too long has been looked upon in the traditional family as secondary to the work performed by the breadwinner or income earner.

This allowance is the balancing option to the government's assistance to child care, which is provided through income-tested fee relief to working parents who use approved services. The essential features of this new allowance, which replaces the dependent spouse rebate for couples with dependent children and which will be paid from 29 September, are as follows: a regular fortnightly payment will be made directly to the dependent partner of a couple with a dependent child or children. The maximum rate allowed will be $60 per fortnight, which is approximately $6 per fortnight higher than the current maximum rate of the dependent spouse rebate. In fact, a total of $1.37 billion will be spent on the home child-care allowance. This amounts to an increase of over $230 million. I stress that, because it means that not only will there be an increase for current recipients of the rebate but also a larger number of current recipients are expected to receive the maximum payment rate under the new legislation.

Another big plus in this bill is the fortnightly basis on which payments will be made by the Department of Social Security instead of the yearly tax concession under the current rebate system. That will allow a greater flexibility in meeting the week to week needs of families looking after children at home. The allowance will be subject to an income-based test only on the income of the partner caring for the child or children. It will not affect the dependent spouse rebate for couples without children or the sole parent rebate. Importantly, the allowance will not be subject to an assets test.

The dissenting report from the coalition senators raises the point that under the Social Security Act families that are absent from Australia for longer than 13 weeks will be excluded from the allowance. It is important to note that as soon as the recipients return they qualify to receive the allowance from the date on which they return. The dissenting report also raises the requirement for a tax file number. In a number of cases, this will need to be acquired from the Taxation Office. There is no doubt that in the overwhelming majority of cases most families would have already provided their tax file number. It is disappointing that the dissenting report has used this requirement as a basis to knock the legislation when there are in place very strict guidelines under privacy principle No. 10.

In summary, this allowance means more in the pocket of the dependent partner, with the added advantage of the fortnightly payment. In a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) dated 7 April 1993, the National Secretary of the Women's Action Alliance said:

SPEECH.PARA: We also congratulate you on converting the dependent spouse rebate to a direct payment to women who are caring for children at home. Women's Action Alliance has called for this measure since our inception in 1975.
The letter goes on:
This is an important breakthrough for those women because for too long they have been defined as out of the workforce when in fact they are performing vital work in our society.

I move briefly to the relevant section involving partner allowance. Additional payments previously made to recipients of job search allowance, newstart allowance and sickness allowance will be paid directly to the dependent partner as a partner allowance. This can be described as a fairer way to distribute such funds.

PARA.TAB: Let me mention some of the other essential factors in the paper. The bill will not impose any activity requirements on the recipient of partner allowance. The additional amount of allowance currently payable in respect of a dependent partner or persons in receipt of job search allowance, newstart allowance, sickness allowance or special benefit will no longer be available. The person will need to lodge a separate claim for partner allowance. The person will need to be an Australian resident in order to qualify for the allowance. Finally, the allowances will, appropriately, be able to be paid to the recipient in this important international year.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill, Senator Denman referred to a letter, which I assume all honourable senators received, as I did, from the Women's Action Alliance to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I would like to have that letter incorporated into the proceedings of this parliament so that the suggestions made by Women's Action Alliance to improve this measure should be part of the record. Senator Denman quoted the WAA as congratulating the government on converting the dependent spouse rebate to a direct payment to women who are caring for children at home. In the same letter, the WAA was trenchantly critical of the effective amount that is going to be paid for child care in the home. I believe the parliament is entitled to see the whole of this letter, so I seek to have it incorporated in Hansard.
—May I see it first?

—I ask that a copy be shown to the minister.This measure, which will abolish the spouse rebate and replace it with a home child-care allowance, is really a $2.85 insult. The allowance of $30 a week would give families only $2.85 more than they are already getting through the dependent spouse rebate. As I calculate it, that is worth $27.15 a week. That is the maximum rebate for a dependent spouse with children and the maximum for others is $22.63.

PARA.TAB: As I will point out during the committee stage, this legislation is going to rip off amounts of money that families are already entitled to. That was never promised at the time of the election. The people of Australia never knew that this measure was going to rip off money from families that are already receiving the amount through the DSR.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were tricked!

—Exactly, Senator Patterson, they were tricked. In general terms, what it also means is that the workers are going to be $27.15 a week worse off. They are going to find in September that they are going to be short of 28 bucks, and they are going to wonder what the heck is going on and where it has got to. The wife will receive 30 bucks from Social Security, and then they will realise what a three-card trick this is.

PARA.TAB: Let me go to what was stated by the Prime Minister in his election promise to pay mums at home. We saw the advertisements: $30 a week to be paid to mums at home. How is that going to be financed? The government has got it all sorted out. It is going to be financed by taking it out of the wages of the spouses that work, whether that be a male or a female, and placing it into the hands of the person who is caring for the children. In normal circumstances, that will mean taking money out of the hip pocket and putting it into the purse. There is nothing wrong with that, but let us be straightforward about it. That is not a home child-care allowance. It is going to mean $2.85, irrespective of the number of children who are cared for. Honourable senators should compare that to the amount of money that is spent on institutionalised care and to the millions of dollars ploughed into institutionalised child care.

This measly sum offered to mothers who care for their children at home is a joke. It is, in my view, discriminating against mothers who care for their children in the home—absolute discrimination. It is going to be virtually revenue neutral—and, as I said, I will come to that question in the committee stage. If we look at the amount of money that has been ripped off workers to be paid this, the amount of money that is going to be ripped off families—and some families are going to be worse off under this measure—then we will see that it is likely to be revenue neutral. In fact, the Prime Minister did admit that this was going to be revenue neutral. People can shake their heads as much as they like. I will get the statement where the Prime Minister said it would be revenue neutral.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Senator Harradine; I wish to interject at this point. My point of order is this: I have been sitting here through Senator Herron's speech and Senator Reid's and now Senator Harradine's, and Senator Harradine is the first speaker to pick it up, although Senator Herron did confirm it to me. It seems again that those in the advisers box of Senator Crowley again continually seek to involve themselves in this debate. I particularly point out that the first adviser, with her head down now—shamelessly, of course—has continually frowned and shaken her head. I cannot hear what she is saying, but it is not advice to Senator Crowley. She is involving herself in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The last time I raised this matter about an adviser of Senator Crowley's, the previous President intervened and by letter assured me that he would be speaking to every minister on this matter. To that end, the Standing Orders are quite clear: should someone from the advisers box interfere in the debate, as this particular person has during the speeches of three speakers and now picked up properly by Senator Harradine, they should be ejected from the chamber. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to take my point of order that this adviser is interfering in the debate and the standing orders should be upheld.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak on the same point of order. I was going to rise a few minutes ago on the same point of order when my friend Senator Harradine was speaking but I did not want to interrupt his train of thought. I fully support what Senator McGauran has said. I spoke once before on the actions we asked to be taken on advisers taking part in debate and Senator Crowley laughed at them, but I fully support what Senator McGauran has said. As I said, I would have got up on a point of order if Senator Harradine had not been speaking.

—Again on the point of order: just for your confirmation, Mr Acting Deputy President, I mentioned it to Senator Herron—so this goes back three speakers—and he confirmed it. We can call him back into the chamber. He confirmed it. He did notice it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Minister, do you want to speak to the same point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I certainly do. I am not aware, and I have heard nothing that could possibly indicate it, of any one of the advisers in these boxes participating in the debate. The advisers are, from time to time, offering me comment; sometimes that advice is passed across the gap here which is by definition a very wide division. It has been a problem for any number of people since this place was designed. I would have to suggest that, if the changing moods or facial expressions on people are taken as contributions to the debate, we are really stretching the definition of contributing to the debate to a new level. I might then wonder why it is Senator McGauran smiles so often. Would he say that this was a contribution to the debate? Of course it is not. I think that the contribution—
—He is allowed to smile.

—He is allowed to smile. I think that Senator McGauran would say that, whether he smiles, or whether he frowns, or whether he is sober, it is not a contribution to the debate. If the rule is that all people sitting in the advisers boxes are to be absolutely impassive of face, demeanour and expression, and are only to speak if I should advance to them, that they cannot pass me notes—which of course they can do—I think we would be making a ruling about the place or the contribution of advisers to assist the minister at the table that I think would be ridiculous and restrictive. I think there is a clear ruling from Mr President that advisers do not enter into the debate. I do not feel that the advisers in any way have entered into the debate. But if it is—
—Especially if you weren't looking.

—I think it would be a very good idea if we did not make too many comments about expressions on people's faces from time to time. I thank the senator for that smile. I think if we start defining facial expression as an equal and legitimate contribution to the debate in this place it is becoming a real farce. It is certainly not understood to be a contribution to debate and it is, I think, quite within Mr President's ruling. It is certainly proper that advisers do not speak or make comments or address themselves in any way into the debate in that way. I think that the advisers are well aware—certainly I am—of the advice given by Mr President in his ruling when this matter was raised previously. I think there is no justification for that point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, Minister Crowley seeks to make light of this matter. It is not a light matter and it is not a question of whether the adviser was participating in the debate. The question is one of the conduct of an individual. There is a very clear understanding and there is a very clear set of guidelines laid down in the standing orders that people who enter this chamber should act in an appropriate fashion. That means they should show due respect, not just for individual senators but for this Senate. That applies whether the individuals are in the public galleries, whether they are in the chamber—that is a senator—or whether they are in the advisers boxes.

PARA.TAB: It is a special concession in this Senate that advisers are allowed on to the floor to sit in the advisers box. Therefore, special standards of conduct are expected of those advisers. The conduct which we have witnessed today and which we have witnessed on previous occasions shows a contempt for the Senate. More particularly, it shows a contempt for the honourable senator who was speaking. I do not wish to take much further time on this, but it is very clear that conduct alone which is contemptuous or fails to show due respect and decorum should not be permitted. Therefore, we of the opposition believe that the adviser in question should be asked to leave the advisers box forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same point of order: I just wanted to ask Senator Crowley whether it would be possible, given the length of this debate on this point of order, that the Senate show some indulgence towards Senator Harradine and extend his speaking time for the length of time we have taken on this point of order.
—I point out, Senator Patterson, that this time has not been taken out of his speech. The clock has been stopped while the point of order has been under discussion.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, if I may offer some assistance to you. The last occasion this occurred was, of course, another one—
—Senator McGauran, I think I have had enough assistance to determine the issue.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, am I permitted to speak, since it is after a quarter to one?
—Yes, Senator Harradine.

—On the same point of order, I had not thought of raising the questions that have been raised by Senator McGauran and his colleagues. But I am glad that they have been raised because obviously I would not have said `and people need not shake their heads'. The adviser nominated by Senator McGauran was, in fact, not smiling but vigorously shaking her head when I indicated that the Prime Minister, before the election, had admitted that this proposal was revenue neutral. I do care, in the sense that it has been raised on the point of order, that she shakes her head, but if she ever comes before a committee of which I might be happily a member, it would be interesting to ask her what was the basis for her shaking the head. In the most unlikely event that that will take place, I think that the standing orders of this chamber should be observed by advisers. In this case, on my observation, they were not.
—I think I have taken enough advice on this matter.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a couple of points and comment—
—No, I am going to make a ruling, Senator Crowley.
—I would certainly like to make a couple of points—
—Senator Crowley, resume your seat.
—Is it possible that I am not allowed to speak again, as every other colleague has been allowed to?
—I think I have enough advice to make a ruling.
—I am not wishing to give you advice, Mr Acting Deputy President. I wish to make comment on the two points raised by Senator O'Chee and Senator Harradine, and this is not necessary to—
—But my responsibility is simply to make a ruling on the point of order raised. I am in a position to do that.
—I would certainly like the opportunity to continue my comments, brief as they will be. Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Do you wish to seek leave?
—I am standing to speak to the point of order a second time.
—Senator Crowley, I have indicated that I have enough information before me to make a ruling on this matter. Would you please resume your seat.
—I have been asking, Mr Acting Deputy President, what way may I be able to—
—You can seek leave if you want to make a comment. I have indicated I have enough information to make the ruling.
—Can I please ask under what rule I have to seek leave when other honourable senators were able to speak twice?
—I was taking information from them with relation to the point of order. I have sufficient information to make that ruling.
—I seek leave.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the point of order that has been raised, the President, when this issue was raised on a previous occasion, ruled that any behaviour such as was alleged by advisers in the advisers benches, or by any person in any of the galleries, is grossly disorderly; and the chair may order the withdrawal or removal of any offenders; and that advisers who are assisting honourable senators from the advisers benches have a particular obligation to behave with complete decorum.

PARA.TAB: My ruling is that facial expression is a matter of decorum and, therefore, it is not simply a matter of verbal involvement and debate, but facial expression would come within the President's ruling as previously made. However, I personally did not observe the facial expressions of the advisers that have been alluded to in the point of order. But I take the points that have been raised. In view of my own inability to have observed that behaviour, at this stage I will simply warn the advisers that they should not enter into the debate and that they should at all times maintain appropriate decorum. If there is a repeat of that behaviour, then I will have those advisers expelled from the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a comment that I was not allowed to make before your ruling.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised the matter a minute ago that the advisers are in a very difficult situation in here. They are certainly not easily able to speak across the division or to call my attention to a matter that is being raised. The adviser was making it clear to me that there was a disagreement, and that she would like to advise me on what Senator Harradine was claiming. That is a legitimate and appropriate thing for an adviser to be doing for the minister.

PARA.TAB: It is very difficult for the advisers to sit here in this open box, and then have the efforts that they make to contact me or to give me advice misconstrued and taken to be applied to the whole chamber: they are not. They are clearly messages. The advisers were not making any verbal contribution to the debate. They were letting me know that there was a point of difference.

I take very strong issue with Senator O'Chee suggesting that these advisers have been anything less than utterly in support of the dignity of this chamber at all times. Many things are said in this place that are probably far more offensive to the decency and protocols of this place than anything that these advisers have been accused of doing by colleagues opposite.

I shall certainly take note of what the Senate has ruled and of your comment on this matter, Mr Acting Deputy President. The advisers will not need to be worried by that advice: they have behaved with decorum, but I take note of the chair's ruling. The advisers are giving me information and I find the contributions of those opposite very unhelpful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! It being past 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on a matter of public interest, since Senator Crowley was so ungracious as not to give me leave when we gave her leave. The issue that was raised here was in fact an important issue. Senator Crowley said that the advisers were giving her advice. I would ask Senator Crowley to ask the advisers to give advice in such a way that it is not off-putting to the speakers. When advisers are shaking their head when someone is speaking, one begins to think that there is something wrong with what one has said. They might disagree on terms of policy, but it is totally inappropriate. I think it was an inappropriate response from the minister to the issue that was debated. I think this is an issue that will be debated again and we will watch very carefully how advisers behave in the box.

—I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a case commonly known as the 14 Western District farmers v. NIAA Corporation in receivership. The Western District farmers are being sued by liquidators for Ernst and Young for debts totalling almost $1 million of a Warrnambool stock agent, Mr Murnane. The Warrnambool agent was assigned to collect the farmers' debts and pass them onto NIAA Corporation Ltd. For example, Mr Brophy, one of the farmers, paid $77,000 to Mr Murnane, which was kept and not passed on to NIAA Corporation. The liquidators are suing him for the money stolen, plus interest and charges totalling $148,000.

PARA.TAB: While I do not seek to go into the intricacies of the case, it is sufficient to say that the case will be fought over whose agent was Mr Murnane. Was Mr Murnane the agent for the farmers or was Mr Murnane the agent for NIAA Corporation Ltd? The liquidators, Ernst and Young, are claiming that the Warrnambool stock agent was the agent for the farmers, so they will be able to claim that the debt was never received. However, the opposite is clearly true and it is the just point of view.

I refer to an opinion given in March 1992 by Mr D.L. Harper QC, who now sits in the Supreme Court. It answers this question. In Mr Harper's opinion, every test for a principal and agent relationship between the collector of the farmers' debts, Mr Murnane, and NIAA Corporation was satisfied. It should also be noted that it is alleged that the liquidators, Ernst and Young, were in control of the failed finance company and were aware that the agent, Mr Murnane, was operating illegally, yet they did not pass this knowledge on to the farmers. So it is alleged that they failed to exercise their duty of care.

The upshot of all of this is that the farmers are being asked to pay their debt twice, and they simply cannot afford to do this. We have seen situations where farmers have been dragged from their land for not paying their debts. Now we are seeing the quite bizarre situations where farmers will be dragged from their land for paying their debts.

Yesterday it was announced that the National Farmers Federation will intervene in what now has developed into a bitter row between the farmers and the liquidators, Ernst and Young. The NFF's president, Mr Graham Blight, will meet the liquidator, Mr Geoff James, of Ernst and Young in Sydney in a bid to settle the matter before it reaches the New South Wales Supreme Court next Monday. The NFF agreed last week to recommend to the trustees of its fighting fund that, if a settlement cannot be struck, $125,000 will be released to help fund the court battle against the liquidator. The support of the NFF is most welcome. I note that Mr Bill Bodman from the Victorian Farmers Federation was a very strong voice in securing the fighting fund money and I wish to congratulate Mr Bodman on his good judgment and genuine representation of the farmers.

Moreover, I believe that the support given by the NFF, its president, Mr Graham Blight, and its executive director, Mr Rick Farley, signals a renewed determination by the farmers federation to help, to fight for and to represent every member. It is comforting to know that the NFF, with its powerful resources, is still watching over the farm sector, striking at issues which are of core concern to farmers, issues which expose them to predatory practices of individuals or groups which would otherwise prey on their vulnerability—their financial weakness. As only the NFF can, it has struck out at those who sit in their marbled central business district offices. In the past, the NFF has not been without its critics, but this case shows that the skills and presence of the NFF are still much valued by the rural sector.

I note that the liquidator from Ernst and Young, Mr James, was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 22 February as saying that he had great sympathy for the Western District farmers. I hope that this is a very genuine empathy. From my dealings with Ernst and Young over this issue, I wonder whether that is the case. However, if it is, events will prove it to be so, and there will be an amicable, generous and agreed settlement before this matter proceeds to the courts.

I will make a few points in closing. I believe that the Western District farmers and the liquidator from Ernst and Young have fallen through a legislative trapdoor which should not have been left open in the very first place. We now see the farmers fighting for justice, as they see it, and for their livelihoods. We now also see an accounting firm with one of the most readily identifiable corporate profiles in this country caught up in very wasteful litigation and headed for conflict with the nation's premier farmers' representative body.

This has come to pass because the law, as it is, allowed for such confusion and conflict to happen in the first place. There is nothing to stop this terrible case from happening tomorrow, next week or next year to another group of farmers. Others will fall through the trapdoor until the law is changed. The farmers and the liquidators are not going to claim any victories from this regardless of the outcome of the court proceedings.
