The farmers have wasted their finances, taken out extra loans, put their families at even greater risk in an effort to win what they see is a matter of principle and one on which the livelihoods of all farmers hinge. They have done this at enormous personal cost and it should never have happened.

As a member of the parliamentary corporations and securities committee, I believe there should be an amendment to the Corporations Act to protect vulnerable individuals or groups and to avoid the wasted round of conflict and litigation which has swallowed up the farmers. This is not a very difficult request; it can be done with ease and some careful drafting so the expectations and responsibilities in cases like the one I have outlined are not repeated. The vacuum in the law caused this to happen.

In view of this, it is the responsibility of legislators to ensure the law is changed and the community shielded from needless reruns of the whole issue. Farmers should have recourse to law when they are confronted by those in a much stronger financial position. Firstly, they should not—as is the position now—be put in a situation where there is no law and where they have to plough all their personal resources into the court system in order to clarify their legal standing. This is not the farmers' responsibility; it is the parliament's responsibility to get the law right in the first place.

Secondly, the whole system of stock agents' relationships with farmers requires review and reform. This, of course, is principally an issue for the states. Thirdly, we should also have a look at the stark inadequacies of the bank code. If we had an effective and legislated bank code, or at least a set of working principles to head off conflict and manage farm debt, we would never be in the combative environment we are in now re the Western District farmers.

In conclusion, this case has much to do with the mopping up of the reckless 1980s and a need to cover ourselves in law so such issues may never again rise to the personal detriment of the lives of many farmers or, for that matter, the detriment of the community standing of the financial institutions in which there is already dwindling public confidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that I should follow Senator McGauran here today because I want to raise the same kinds of problems that he has just addressed. I make reference to a question I asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) yesterday. I certainly thank him for the answer that he gave because it was comprehensive and addressed the questions I asked to a certain extent.

PARA.TAB: Of course, as one would expect, he mentioned a number of government programs which were part of the answer to the question. What I want to do today is to point out the problem as I see it as being much deeper than simply addressing specific issues by a program here and a program there. Most of the programs mitigate the effects of rural decline rather than arresting or reversing it. For instance, the rural adjustment scheme is really about helping people get out of farming. Much of the counselling which has been very much appreciated is also towards that end. The programs in these instances do not stop or reverse the decline, and that is what I am concerned about.

Other programs do address specific problems, but it seems to me that that approach is piecemeal. What the Australian Democrats are calling for is a total approach to rural and regional development, for a political commitment which really is prepared to address the climate of decline in rural Australia and say, `We have a political commitment to reverse that, to restore resources and people and hope to the bush'.

In his answer to my question yesterday, the minister mentioned the ABARE conference held earlier this year, in which the assessment was made that the decline in the viability of rural industry had bottomed and it was now on its way up. However, the minister also admitted that much of that improvement is based on further increasing the size of farming properties. Of course, this will mean a further decline in rural population.

The slogan `Get big or get out' is still the basis for much of the operation of our primary industries. But that slogan is in fact part of the problem. It is part of what has caused the debts for many family farmers, and is the reason that they are now being foreclosed. The high interest rates of the 1980s represent nothing less then usury. In fact, it is the reason that many family farmers find themselves in this situation.

Some time ago I made mention of contacts that I have in some small country towns in Queensland—St George, Mitchell, Injune and Biloela. These are places where family farmers are facing the end of two, three and even four generations of residency and working on the land. I believe we are facing something that cannot be dealt with by piecemeal programs. It is something that needs an overall political commitment that says, `We want to see rural Australia and rural communities survive'.

A few weeks ago I visited a small community near Mount Gambier in South Australia and met with a group of women who call themselves Rural Women for Social Justice. They told me stories of domestic violence in families which had never experienced that kind of situation before. They told stories of suicides that are reported as vehicle accidents, but which are deliberate acts by people who can no longer cope with the situation they are in, and of families where they can no longer afford for their children to go to school.

I am talking about the human face of the statistics that we are so prone to play with from time to time. I want to quote from a press article this week. The heading of this press article is enough—`After the death of Letona, the rot sets in'. The article tells the story of a family farmer, Mr Lou Martinello, 37, who has grown 100 tonnes of peaches on his Leeton property. Mr Martinello said:
This year would have been my year of glory, being debt free from the bank.
But now I will have to walk with my head down low for a few years more.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same article, another farmer, Mr Sergi, said that he was dirty with the government for letting valuable markets slip through its fingers in deciding to close the Letona cannery. He also said:

PARA.TAB: They're letting other countries take our trade.
We had a Scandinavian market and now that could be taken by the South Africans.

SPEECH.PARA: I am trying to say to the Senate and to the people of Australia that we are not asking for programs; we are asking for a political commitment to the people of Australia and especially to the people of rural communities.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to another press article which is headed `We let you down: Goss'. The Premier of Queensland, Mr Goss, is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Some recent Government decisions had let down people in parts of regional Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —You support him.
—I support him, do I, Senator O'Chee? What is the honourable senator's evidence for that? Mr Goss said:

SPEECH.PARA: I feel we let regional Queensland down last year in terms of some of the decisions we made, and the clear message to myself and all Ministers is that we have to take much more interest, and be seen to be taking much more interest, in regional Queensland.
The problem is much deeper than just a few decisions made last year. It is to do with the closing down of railways, the closing down of schools, and the closing down of court houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The raising of taxes.
—According to Mr Goss—and I have not checked the figures—he has not raised taxes in Queensland.
—No, but this government has, and you voted with it.

—I am not debating that at the moment. It also has to do with the closing down and the sacking of department of primary industries staff. All of these are the reasons why rural industry and rural communities are declining.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the articles in the Australian magazine of 12 and 13 February. Again, the picture which is presented is a very depressing one of what is happening to our rural communities. Not only is the impact a domestic one, not only is it something which is happening in Australia, but also it has international implications. Let me quote, again from this article:

SPEECH.PARA: More serious even than the local impact of such a decline—
Professor Taylor says—

is its possible international ramifications. `I think we are sending a message to the world that we aren't interested in inhabiting most of our country. After nearly 200 years of deliberate government policy of trying to populate it, now, in the name of rationalism and internationalism, we're encouraging the population to pull out. For all the wrong reasons, we are undoing everything the nation has stood for over two centuries. We are making it a country without a heart'.

I believe that sums up exactly what I am trying to say. I believe that what we need here is not programs and is not simply help to people to get out of rural industry. What we need is a political commitment which says that we really do believe in the bush; that we do believe in the country areas of Australia; that we do believe in rural industry; that we do believe in rural communities; and that we are going to make the commitment which will enable them not only to survive, but to grow and to make the contribution which we know they are capable of making to this great country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter of very great concern to me and, I think, to quite a number of Australians, judging by the interest in this particular case. It concerns the sacking of two housekeepers at the Lodge, almost five months ago now. This issue continues to cause community concern and continues to attract media interest, I think for the simple reason that people want to see some justice and fairness done.

PARA.TAB: As the Senate will recall, last October two housekeepers at the Lodge received a phone call on a Sunday night and were told that they were not to report for duty the following day. Therein, of course, lies the dispute. In a subsequent hearing of a Senate estimates committee the department raised some concerns about some of the issues of conduct of the housekeepers. The housekeepers, for their part, totally reject the allegations of the department.

There is an issue here of justice and fairness to these people. They feel that they performed their duties appropriately, and indeed the department issued a certificate of service which in effect says that. There is certainly plenty of evidence around, both verbal and written evidence, that they got on very well with Mr and Mrs Keating. In fact, Mr Keating, I think yesterday, on the Midday Show said that he had no complaints against their service in the Lodge and that it was a matter for the department.

My point in bringing this issue to the attention of the Senate today is this: in order for these two housekeepers to attempt to right what they see as an injustice, they have sought to bring their case to the ombudsman. It causes me great concern that the ombudsman decided yesterday not to take up this case and has said that it is not appropriate for her to do it because it would be, in effect, reviewing the decision of a minister, in this case, of course, the Prime Minister, who in effect, according to the ombudsman, technically made the decision.

The Prime Minister, on the other hand, says it is a matter for the department. Mr Keating says, `I got on well with these two housekeepers. This whole issue of their retrenchment is a matter for the department'. So this is the dilemma the two housekeepers are faced with. On the one hand, the ombudsman says that she cannot take a role in this because, in a sense, it is a matter for the Prime Minister and he, in a technical sense, was responsible for their retrenchment. On the other hand, the Prime Minister says it was not his responsibility; it was the responsibility of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the officers involved in that department.

So the housekeepers are faced with a major dilemma. Where can they put their case? Where can they receive what they see as a chance to have an independent opinion on this issue and see whether there are any matters regarding possible compensation and a possible setting to right officially of their record in the Lodge? The Prime Minister, despite his nice comments about the housekeepers, seems to me to have washed his hands of the issue and, indeed, so has Philippa Smith, the new ombudsman. I think that is a pity. The dilemma is what now happens five months after this particular event.

I have no profound opinion on what should be done. All I know is that these people feel that a wrong has been done and would like to see whether, in some ways, it cannot be righted—at least to their satisfaction. I just wonder whether this is not a matter that Mrs Keating might take an interest in. The Prime Minister has certainly decided it is not for him; the ombudsman has decided it is not for her; and I really wonder whether Mrs Keating herself may wish to take a particular role in this matter.

I do not wish to say that I am across all the facts involved here. All I know is that they feel that they want to have this matter looked at in an independent sense, to see whether these issues cannot be resolved. So I hope that this whole issue can be closed off and finished to the satisfaction certainly of the housekeepers and, I hope, to the satisfaction of all those concerned. I wonder whether one particular way out of it may be for Mrs Keating to take a particular interest in this and see whether she cannot use her influence and good offices to assist in the resolution of what is, in my view, a most unfortunate matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received through the office of His Excellency the Governor-General from the office of the Governor of the state of Tasmania a notification of the choice by the Houses of Parliament of Tasmania of Eric Abetz to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Brian Roper Archer. I table a copy of that notification.

PARA.TAB: Senator Eric Abetz made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer to an interjection by the minister yesterday during a question put to Senator Gareth Evans on the Labor government's broken promise not to put up taxes. I remind the minister that he interjected, `That wasn't the government promise'. The minister was somewhat embarrassed because, of course, he was supporting our case. How is it that this interjection was recorded correctly in the Hansard pinks issued late yesterday afternoon, but by the time the daily Hansard was delivered to parliamentary offices this morning this remark had been substantially changed in its content and meaning to read, `That wasn't the government promise'—additional words—`It was the burden of taxes'? This is quite serious. Is it in fact the case that the minister has attempted to deliberately falsify the Hansard record so that his embarrassing gaffe of yesterday was not recorded for posterity?
—This is a pathetic and facile issue.
—I will answer the question when I have a moment of quiet.
—You are trying to think of an answer, that's why.

—That is not true. When one speaks the truth one does not have to worry as Senator Knowles might have to. I can frankly say to the Senate that I have no knowledge of any change in the Hansard. I did not even look at my pinks yesterday, and I ordinarily do not. I do not have an affectation about always making sure that the written word is right. My staff normally review the pinks, and if a change has been made—
—You are blaming your staff.
—I am not blaming my staff.
—You blamed your staff last time.

—I do not, and I have not; and I have not been consulted on any change about the pinks. If the words are now recorded differently, all I can imagine is that the full content of my interjection is now properly before the Senate in the Hansard record. I might say as a matter of fact—
—You changed the record.
—I did not, and that is a lie. As a matter of fact, I do recall making an interjection along the lines that have now been referred to.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think it has gone from bad to worse. Is the minister saying that the record that now appears in Hansard, which apparently includes words added by his staff, correctly records what he said in this place? If he is saying that, he knows as well as I do that he is lying to this chamber—that the Hansard pink correctly recorded what he said.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Senator Hill knows perfectly well that is utterly unparliamentary, as well as being utterly false. I was sitting here yesterday and I heard Senator Cook utter just those words or something very similar to them. I heard it, and I stand by that.
—Order! Your point of order has been made.
—He uttered those words, or something very similar to them. He is fully entitled to correct the Hansard to ensure that the full content of his interjection is heard.
—Order! Your point of order is upheld. Senator Hill, you will withdraw the allegation of lying. Have you withdrawn?
—Yes. I ask the minister in the supplementary question whether he will tell the Senate what, in fact, were the terms of his interjection yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the interjection as I recall making was along the lines—
—Along the lines.

—It was along the lines of replying to an opposition misstatement of the facts—and that was along the lines that we had not undertaken to introduce new taxes; the undertaking of the government was about the burden of taxation. There is ample evidence that what I am saying is absolute truth. I refer the Senate to the Treasurer's remarks on 19 August 1992, when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The point is that the tax cuts can be funded without any new tax whereas in your case the only way you can provide tax cuts of a comparable form is to tax people—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. It is entirely beside the point and utterly irrelevant to know what someone else might have said on another occasion. Senator Cook is being asked here: were the pinks correct? If the pinks were not correct, who decided that and in what circumstances? You ought to ask him to come clean on what he really said yesterday.

—On that point of order, Mr President, Senator Cook is absolutely entitled to refer to other comments he has made and other quotes to prove that what he was saying yesterday was entirely consistent. Senator Alston is not entitled to redefine his leader's question.
—The answer was perfectly valid within the context of the question.

—On the point of order, Mr President, perhaps it would assist Senator Cook if he could point to where Mr Keating or one of his colleagues said they would raise taxes, because that is exactly what they have done, and that is what they propose to do further.
—There is no point of order, Senator Kemp, and you well know that.
—On 16 September 1992 the Treasurer said, `We will not increase the overall burden of tax', and that is what I was referring to.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. What Senator Cook has been asked is not what the Treasurer said on this, that or the other day; it is what Senator Cook said yesterday, and that is the only relevance that he ought to be addressing himself to. He is not addressing that, and I ask you to bring him to answer the question that was put to him.
—Order! If you had been listening before, you would know I have already ruled on that.
—Mr President, on the point of order, if I may—
—There is no need. I have already ruled on it. Continue your remarks.
—What is being tried here is an assassination of my integrity and I firmly, frankly and utterly deny any basis for such attack at all. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. By way of preface, I refer to the question which I asked the minister last night at the meeting of Senate Estimates Committee A regarding the possibility of a review of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. Is the minister able to inform the Senate whether he has given further consideration to any inquiry into ASIS? If so, what view has he formed?

—Last night at the Senate estimates hearing I indicated that the government had been giving consideration to the question of a comprehensive external inquiry into the operation and management of ASIS and that I retained an open mind on that particular question. I am able to say now that the government has decided, in principle, to set up a judicial inquiry into the operation and management of ASIS. It is our intention that it be headed by a judge, but it is not yet possible for me to make an announcement as to who that person will be. Similarly, questions relating to the specific terms of reference, to the powers of the inquiry, its mode of operation and matters of that kind are currently being addressed. I would expect to be in a position to make an announcement soon, hopefully as early as next week, in that respect.

PARA.TAB: I do envisage that the sorts of issues to be addressed by the inquiry would include, first, control and accountability mechanisms, including the question of a possible legislative charter for the organisation; secondly, questions of administration and management generally; thirdly, and more particularly on the management side, the operation of grievance mechanism and complaint resolution structures, and whether there is any need for attention there; and, fourthly, the whole question of the protection of intelligence assets.

The opposition might be minded to say this is a response to the call made yesterday by Mr Peacock for a judicial inquiry. Let me say a couple of things about that and about some related matters said yesterday and in the press this morning. For the record, I quickly say that the position as I have expressed it does not amount to any kind of turnaround, either last night or today. Yesterday, in answers I gave in question time and elsewhere, I studiously avoided the whole question of a judicial inquiry. I was asked about a parliamentary oversight process, about which I expressed some reservations. I was asked about data collection systems. I said nothing substantive then or at any other time on the question of a judicial or other form of external inquiry.

More importantly, perhaps, the question of a comprehensive inquiry into the factors I have mentioned has been under active consideration by me for some little time now—certainly for several weeks. It did completely pre-date—notwithstanding what anyone might be minded to say—the Four Corners report on Monday night. I said a little about the reasons for that during the estimates hearing last night, but let me repeat them. The reasons for that were essentially these considerations: firstly, there is a case for regular root and branch review of organisations that, by their nature, are necessarily very closed and secretive. Such reviews would focus, in particular, on questions of control and accountability. The last such review was conducted nearly 10 years ago by Mr Justice Hope.

Secondly, there is the consideration that the Cold War is over. That has led to a lot of thinking about the character of these organisations, and it raises questions here, as it did in the United Kingdom, about the desirability of a legislative charter rather than the kind of executive direction which has been regarded in the past, particularly in a Cold War atmosphere, as appropriate for that kind of organisation. Thirdly, there has been some significant increase in ASIS's funding over the last couple of years, and a change in the configuration of its operations—a change that has been made in parallel in this respect with other organisations in the intelligence community, again associated with the end of the Cold War. I had the view that it was desirable to focus accordingly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you say this in question time yesterday?

—Because no final government decision had been made. I was, I repeat, studiously neutral on this subject yesterday. There is a question under those circumstances as to whether management systems do need any attention. Finally, I think there is a need to consider, in the light of the end of the Cold War and perceptions associated with that, whether intelligence protection mechanisms, legislative or otherwise, need any attention.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former distinguished Senator Don Chipp, the foundation leader of the Australian Democrats. I welcome him on behalf of senators, and hope that he will not participate in the debate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Only six months Senator Gareth Evans said that the government would not `go down the path of introducing any new taxes'. Just two months ago, the now Treasurer, Mr Willis, said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . obviously the Government has no plans to raise taxes.

I ask the minister to clarify the government's position in respect of the budget on the following matters. First, will the government introduce any new taxes; secondly, will the government introduce any new revenue measures; and/or, thirdly, will the government increase any existing taxes?

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait and see!

—I think the short answer is that which was offered by way of interjection: wait and see the outcome in the budget. I am glad to see that Senator Short has at least learned something since his question yesterday. There are several different questions rolled up in this question of whether there is any inconsistency in what the government has said.

PARA.TAB: The first part of the question is whether or not we will introduce any new taxes. A lot of the consideration there depends on what one chooses to characterise as a tax and whether it is in fact a tax or revenue measure. I said it is perfectly well understood, as a matter of constitutional law and legislative practice, that revenue measures may be on the one hand taxes; on the other hand, they can have the character of fees, charges or levies. In that particular context, as I said yesterday, there is an unresolved question as to whether or not the government would go down the path of introducing a jobs levy. That matter has been canvassed as a possibility; it has not yet been resolved.

As to the part of the question referring to any other new tax, I do not think there is any question of the government doing that because that has been said on a number of occasions as not to be within the realm of possibility. But I put the jobs levy to one side as still a possibility, whether or not one chooses to call it a tax.

As to the question of increases in existing taxes, of course, as the Treasurer has said, as finance ministers have said and as governments have said from time immemorial, one cannot rule out that possibility as part of the overall consideration of the budget. That kind of consideration is always on the table. But what we will not do—this is the nub of Senator Cook's interjection yesterday—is increase the overall burden of taxes. We will not increase the overall burden of taxes in the sense of taxation as a proportion of GDP, which is down now to a lower level than it was through most of the 1980s, and that remains an election commitment and one that we are firmly attached to. But, apart from that, all these questions are highly speculative, hypothetical and premature. These are issues that will be resolved in the budget context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the minister's continued refusal to answer clear and precise questions on whether the government will repeat in this year's budget its habitual pattern of broken promises on tax and on a huge range of other issues—the basis on which it lied its way back into office at the last election—the Senate can only assume that the big lie is on again. So I give the minister one last opportunity to refute that by again inviting him to tell the Senate whether or not the government will be introducing new revenue or tax measures or will be increasing existing revenue measures in the budget.

—What we will get in the budget is an honest and responsible reaction by the government to the needs of this particular country. Neither honesty nor responsibility is something that we have learnt to expect from the opposition. The government will be absolutely consistent in the positions it has adopted on these matters. But as to the detail of how these questions are juggled and balanced out, that remains to be seen, as it always does, in a budget context.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise the Senate of the significance for the economic outlook of this country of the figures just released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in particular those on profit share and motor vehicle registrations?

—I thank the honourable senator for asking an economic question of importance for Australia. The ABS today released two sets of data pertaining to the pace of economic recovery currently under way in Australia. The first set was the preliminary figures on new motor vehicle registrations for January. Motor vehicle registrations have evidenced considerable volatility in recent months; nevertheless, the increase in January of 6.4 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms now sees the level of registrations some nine per cent above that of a year ago. More importantly, the trend estimates are some six per cent higher than for January 1993—cause, I might say, for continued optimism that the recovery already evident in other sectors is beginning to be reflected in the motor vehicle industry.

PARA.TAB: The ABS also released figures on company profits for the December quarter of last year. These show a four per cent rise in trend terms over the September quarter. This is the tenth consecutive quarter of growth in company profit numbers, which are now some 26 per cent higher than in the December quarter of 1992 and are at their highest level since this ABS series began.

These figures come on top of mounting evidence from a number of sources that the pace of economic activity, which clearly accelerated in the second half of 1993, is continuing to gather momentum. Strong increases in the major job vacancy series suggest that the employment growth, which has seen an increase in trend terms of 155,000 in the seven months to January 1994, should continue to be robust. Consumer and business confidence measures in recent months have reached levels not seen since the late 1980s. In volume terms, retail turnover increased by 1.9 per cent in the December quarter, the highest rate of growth since September 1991. Despite the subdued levels of economic activity in much of the rest of the world, net exports have continued to provide a strong contribution to growth.

All this is clear evidence that the government's economic policies are working and that Australia is now well placed to reap the benefits of the significant transformation this government has achieved in the structure of the economy. A key part of the government's policy framework is the medium-term deficit reduction strategy, aimed at ensuring that Australia is able to fund the necessary pick-up in investment in new productive capacity that is crucial to ensuring that the recovery in activity and jobs is a sustainable recovery, and to finance a larger proportion of it domestically.

The fundamentals are now particularly encouraging for investment. Not only is corporate profitability at an historic high, but also interest rates are at a 20-year low and inflation is at a 30-year low. This has underpinned a quantum improvement in Australia's international competitiveness. In the face of all that, there is further evidence that spare capacity is beginning to fall notably.

The figures are beginning to show the nature of the change and the improvement. Underlying business investment in plant and equipment increased by six per cent in the September quarter, underpinned by the upward revision recently announced by the Treasurer of the government's forecast for 1993-94 from one-quarter of one per cent in year-average terms to 4 1/4 per cent. It is now up to the business sector to step up and meet these challenges and the opportunities posed for Australia's improving economic circumstances and to take advantage of the favourable investment climate we now have. One should not overvalue these figures, but they clearly show that the recovery is gathering pace, the prospects for the economy are brighter, and the prospects for people looking for employment are better.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Recent government statements have indicated that assistance for the long-term unemployed will be an important part of the May budget—and rightly so. I ask: how will the government be defining long-term unemployment? It seems to us that a bit of shifting is going on. Will it use the long-accepted definition of more than 12 months unemployment? Will it use the green paper redefinition of long-term, which is more than 18 months unemployment? Is this redefinition part of a government strategy to conveniently redefine out of its budget calculations the 140,000 Australians who have been unemployed for between 12 and 18 months?

—The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Crean, has informed me of the factual position. According to the ABS, in December 1993 there were 344,300 persons unemployed for more that 12 months. Although long-term unemployment is likely to respond slowly to employment growth, the government does not believe that the ABS long-term numbers will reach the suggested 500,000 that was in a recent Canberra article. Since August last year, 123,000 new jobs have been created. Over the 12 months to December 1993, 188,000 new jobs were created. We accept that this is in the short-term area, and that long-term unemployment is the slowest area to respond to the growth in the economy. However, we do not accept some of the alarmist stories that have been reported recently in the press.

PARA.TAB: As far as the definition of long-term unemployment moving from 12 months to 18 months, as is mentioned in the green paper on unemployment, Senator Kernot would know that that paper is now before the government for cabinet consideration. Mr Crean has already indicated that that paper is before the community for consultation so that the government can receive submissions on such issues as long-term unemployment. If there is to be any change in the definition, or if it is to be left as it is, that will be announced at an appropriate time in the near future when the government responds to the report. I have no information that there is any specific plan before the government at the moment to take up that suggestion to change the definition. We await that consultation with the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, as the minister responsible for uranium and nuclear issues. I note the comments by the South Australian minister for Aboriginal affairs that Aboriginals have been prevented from participating in the clean-up of the Maralinga test site in South Australia. Can the minister inform the Senate of the accuracy of this claim and the processes in train for the clean-up in general?

—I do understand Senator Foreman's concern about this issue, as he is from South Australia. Dr Armitage did make a statement in the South Australian parliament yesterday—I am somewhat at a loss to understand how he could have made it—attacking the Commonwealth government and alleging that the Maralinga Tjarutja people have been completely excluded from the Maralinga test site clean-up. The claim is totally without foundation. In fact, no contracts for the clean-up site have been let and we are not even close to letting contracts. So nobody has been excluded from this process.

PARA.TAB: I can only hope that the South Australian minister's comments stem from a genuine misunderstanding and not from mischief. Following this government's acceptance in principle of a 20 million pounds ex-gratia payment offered by Britain as a full settlement of the Maralinga issue, my predecessor, Mr Simon Crean, established the Maralinga Rehabilitation Technical Advisory Committee to advise on technical aspects of the clean-up and how to proceed with it. The South Australian government is a member of that body. The clean-up is essentially a very large earth moving and engineering exercise. The government intends to appoint a project manager to supervise the job.

The role of the project manager is to complete the detailed engineering design, to develop a schedule and budget for the program and to tender out the works to complete the program. As I said before, we have not appointed a manager yet but are still at the stage of selecting that person. We will probably be able to make a decision by April. So we are not at the stage of awarding contracts for any specific tasks. No one has been excluded from anything, and the South Australian government, because of its direct formal role in this process, should be well aware of it.

The position of project manager was advertised publicly in the national press last September. Thirty six organisations expressed an interest in doing the job and a short list of three has been made. All potential project managers have been informed that, in their planning, they will need to be aware of the views of the Maralinga Tjarutja Aboriginal people.

Since the agreement was reached with the British government in June last year, there has been regular ministerial and departmental contact with the Maralinga Tjarutja representatives in relation to the clean-up. At no time has the government sought to exclude the Aboriginal people from consideration of the clean-up. They were fully involved in considering the clean-up options. Their agreement was sought by the government on the preferred option prior to negotiations with the British government on a clean-up settlement.

It is intended that the government will continue to involve the Maralinga Tjarutja people as fully as possible during the clean-up without, of course, compromising the clean-up itself, which is to be undertaken and must be undertaken in the most expert manner possible. It goes without saying that the Maralinga Tjarutja people will have the option of tendering for any of the component parts of the clean-up should they wish to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. We welcome the minister's announcement today of a judicial inquiry into ASIS. But in light of the increasing concerns in the community about the operations of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, I ask: can the minister confirm or deny that personal material, based on hearsay and rumour and secret psychological reports, has been used as evidence against several ASIS officers and their spouses? Has the minister denied these officers access to this material as well as to other files on them held by ASIS?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not denied access of anything to anybody. The grievances Senator Gibson is talking about have been the subject of exhaustive examination over a considerable period of time by the institution that was established by the parliament to deal with just these sorts of situations—and that is, of course, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.

PARA.TAB: I am not aware of the details of the particular material that he might have taken into account. I am certainly aware of the substance of his reports at various stages of that affair. I have seen absolutely nothing in those reports, or in any of the complaints that have been made to me about the process, which would make me think that there was any inappropriate response by the inspector-general in any way. Inevitably, when dealing with people with personal grievances of one kind or another, lots of claims and allegations are made, and there has been no exception in this particular case.

I do find fascinating what the opposition might say about these sorts of accountability and grievance control mechanisms, given the reservations that the opposition expressed at the time of the debate on the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security back in 1986. In particular I refer, because it is very relevant to this particular answer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order. It cannot be relevant to the question.
—It is very relevant. Why don't you listen?

—Because we heard it from you last night—it is totally irrelevant. The question concerns the way in which investigations have taken place and whether officers of ASIS have had access to their personal files. We know that the inspector-general found that investigations have been conducted improperly and in breach of natural justice. Therefore, it is a reasonable question that requires a sensible response. It does not require a debate on the basis of whether or not the inspector-general's action had been passed.

—You are starting to debate the issue now, Senator. I have no way of assessing whether it is relevant or not. Even when one has heard the arguments, it is difficult to assess whether they are relevant or not. It is certainly impossible if one has not heard the arguments.

—I was not proposing to range at large over the opposition's response to that legislation. I was proposing to focus on one very specific contribution to that debate by Mr Spender, which went squarely to the kind of matter that has been raised here today. That is to say, whether or not there has been any infringement of human rights, natural justice or anything else in the way in which the organisation conducted itself, and in particular in the way in which the inspector-general acted. Let me quote Mr Spender in this respect:

ANSWER.PARA: As to inquiries into practices alleged to be contrary to human rights, it is perfectly absurd and quite obnoxious that that kind of inquiry should be directed against an intelligence organisation.If that is the Government's view of an intelligence and security organisation, it may as well scrap it and go back to playing marbles. . .
That is the kind of democracy there is on the opposition side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The minister is not answering the question that he was asked. He knows as well as we do that there were findings by the inspector-general of improper conduct and breaches of natural justice.
—Order! You are now debating the question.
—What is he now seeking to hide? Why will access not be provided to the officers that have a grievance?
—There is no point of order.

—I can understand Senator Hill being deeply embarrassed by that kind of question being asked on his own side, because the performance of the opposition in 1986 on this whole subject was deeply embarrassing. The honourable senator comes out now and hypocritically sheds crocodile tears about failures or weaknesses in accountability or grievance mechanisms, yet he opposed the weight of the proposal in 1986 to provide for effective such machinery; he wanted to weaken it; he expressly wanted to rule out any kind of applicability or have any inquiry into human rights breaching behaviour by the organisation; he, through his leading spokesman on that particular legislation, wanted to rule out that as an improper, unwelcome and overobtrusive interference with the operation of an intelligence and security organisation. When all that stuff is on the record, for him to come in here and wave himself around as a pretended defender of human rights and natural justice against these sorts of organisations, is so hypocritical and so pathetic as to be positively sick making.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister has said that he has not stopped these officers being given access to this material, will he assure the Senate that these people will be given access to the material and to the files held on them?

—I am not aware of any material of the kind that the honourable senator is referring to that has been denied to these people. At one earlier stage of the proceedings, one particular report was withheld for reasons that were fully explained to the person in the circumstances of the case. It was subsequently decided, through the course of this process, that that particular material—and I will not go into its nature, because it is highly personal in character—should have been handed over. To the extent that there was some improper process at one early stage of the process, it was corrected at a later stage of the process.

PARA.TAB: I remain totally confident that, under the machinery that we set up, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security has done everything—and more—that any reasonable institutional process or any reasonable human being could do to deal with the particular personal grievances of these people. I repeat that, and will go on repeating it. There is no sense in which any lack of confidence in that process lies in any way behind the announcement that I made today of our intention to go down that track. They are completely separate issues, and they ought to be understood as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the Law Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China, led by Mr Xue Ju. On behalf of honourable senators I have much pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate, and I hope that your visit will be both productive and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Can the minister assure the Senate that his department and the Defence Force have consistently adhered to Australia's obligations under the inhumane weapons convention which the government ratified on 20 September 1983? In particular, will he indicate whether the ADF trains with, or has plans to use, booby traps of any type, and have any landmines been modified for ADF use as booby traps? If so, can the minister give details?

—Yes, we do adhere to the convention. I do not have any knowledge of whether any landmines held in the ADF inventory have ever been modified. It has never been brought to my attention. May I say on the general issue of landmines that Australia does share some of the concern that is expressed at the moment over the use of landmines, and particularly the irresponsible use of anti-personnel mines in Afghanistan and Cambodia—and in many other parts of the globe.

PARA.TAB: In these sorts of recent internal conflicts anti-personnel landmines have been used indiscriminately in civilian areas and left unexploded at the end of hostilities, their locations unmarked and unrecorded, and causing unacceptable civilian casualties. The deliberate targeting of landmines at civilians or the indiscriminate use of landmines so that they injure civilians, contravenes fundamental principles of law of armed conflict and should be effectively banned.

Australia is a party to the 1980 inhumane weapons convention which imposes limited restrictions on the use of mines. We want to see more countries become party to the convention and we have been making representations to our regional neighbours urging them to accede to or ratify it. Australia has also been at the forefront of calls for a review conference to strengthen the convention. We will participate in meetings of a group of experts commencing in March 1994 to consider possible amendments.

Problems of landmines being targeted at civilians or left unexploded at the end of hostilities may be addressed by measures short of a total ban on the use of landmines. They include the effective marking and recording of mined areas, the use of self-neutralising or self-destructing mines, the use of detectable materials and verification and compliance mechanisms, and an extension of the convention to internal conflicts. Our view is that the convention should also contain restrictions on the production and sale of landmines which have the effect of enforcing the other provisions by only permitting the sale to countries which use mines in accordance with the strictest rules.

Australia is not a producer or an exporter of landmines, but we support those countries which have imposed a moratorium on the sale of mines to states which are not party to the inhumane weapons convention. Unfortunately, landmines are relatively easy to produce and therefore a moratorium will not completely solve the problem, which is why we seek a wider accession to, and compliance with, the convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In that case, will the minister guarantee that we will not export such devices to states that have not ratified the convention? I know he said `under the strictest rules' but he has not specifically stated that we will not export to such states that have not ratified the convention.

—I thought Senator Margetts would have taken it as a given that the answer to that is yes, we will ban that, because we are encouraging other countries not to export landmines to countries that have not acceded to the convention. It would be grossly hypocritical if we then breached that sort of approach, so we will not.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer again to the decision of the government to engage the discredited former Comptroller-General of Customs as an adviser to DITARD at a salary equivalent to that of the Secretary of the department, and his answer in the Senate that he did so because:

QUESTION.PARA: There was a legal obligation to recognise the rights of a statutory office holder.

To avoid any ambiguity, is Senator Cook saying that after the resignation of Mr Kelly from the statutory office of Comptroller-General of Customs the government was legally obliged to employ him in the Public Service at a salary of $126,760?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not saying that, and I did not say it at the time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If there is no legal obligation, why has the Public Service Commissioner signed a determination pursuant to section 82(d) of the Public Service Act to set out the terms and conditions of Mr Kelly's employment, including that his basic salary be set at $126,760? Why has the Minister gone to all this trouble? Is the reason that this is a special deal for Mr Kelly?

—This is well ploughed ground. My colleague Senator Schacht has answered questions relating to this matter in considerable detail. The first part of this question is: why did the Public Service Commissioner sign a declaration? I suggest Senator Ferguson asks the Public Service Commissioner that or the minister representing the Public Service Commissioner because I am not in a position to answer why he did it.

PARA.TAB: The facts of the matter are well understood in this chamber. This is an effort to try to distort the facts. The facts that are well understood bear repeating, however. They are that the Comptroller-General of Customs is a statutory position and Mr Kelly was a statutory office holder.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he resigned.

—He resigned in certain circumstances. I might also add that my office today indicated to Senator Ferguson that I would be adding further to my answer that I gave him the other day. I propose to do that immediately after the conclusion of question time. It would save him fossicking around over this issue, which is clearly an effort to beat up something that is of no importance.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The minister would be aware of the article in the Australian Financial Review on 17 February describing the growth in Monash University's international education program. Does Monash University's experience of international education programs reflect the general growth in Australia's educational exports? What is the current value of these exports? What action is the government taking to remove remaining impediments to the future growth of Australia's tertiary education exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there was recently an article on this in the Australian Financial Review written by Mr Peter Roberts. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: One of the most enduring . . . of John Dawkins' reforms of tertiary education has been the creation of the sector as a vigorous exporter of high value services.

To amplify that, in 1986 Australia earned only $50 million from educational exports. As a result of the reforms to tertiary education introduced by this government, the education industry earned $1.2 billion in 1993. Overseas students spend in the order of a further $750 million in Australia on their living and other expenses while they are studying here.

PARA.TAB: Many of Australia's universities have benefited from this growth in recent years. Senator Carr is right to point out that Monash University has been a leader in this. For instance, some 3,500 fee-paying overseas students earned that university about $36 million last year. That is an outstanding achievement by that university.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is on the council?

—I can tell Senator Patterson that I pay tribute to the council and to Professor Logan, the Vice-Chancellor. The point is that the council of that university could not have attained those achievements without the changes that were introduced during the 1980s by the then minister for education, Mr Dawkins.

PARA.TAB: Further to that step, the government has decided to substantially increase its commitment to promoting international education and training through the establishment of the Australian international education foundation. This is to be a genuine industry and government partnership, with an expenditure of over $18 million over the next three years.

In addition, government to government liaison is playing an increasingly important role in developing opportunities for Australia's education and training services. The governments in the region have signalled that they want the Australian government to take a stronger role to integrate education and training with broader issues of regional economic development and foreign relations. The foundation will undertake market research and intelligence to guide Australian education and training providers, and facilitate access of Australian providers to key markets. The establishment of the foundation will result in Australia being better placed to meet the needs of our international clients.

I conclude by pointing out that it is expected that export earnings in the education sector will pass $2 billion by the year 2000. International student expenditure in Australia could generate nearly 20,000 new jobs by 1997 and many more by the year 2000. This is a success story of which the government is duly very proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Are Australian students disadvantaged by such programs?

—I have received no substantial information at all that Australian students are disadvantaged by this program. I would think that the added international dimension for our tertiary institutions is useful for Australian students to participate in. We have no evidence that Australian students are disadvantaged, and we believe this is a major significant reform to the advantage of Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Following the minister's admission the day before yesterday that the Prime Minister's piggery owes Mr John Brown's company millions of dollars to be paid at the discretion of directors and subject to future profitability, are the Australian people entitled to know how the Prime Minister's company's debt—which was shown in its accounts for 1991 lodged with the Australian Securities Commission on 2 December 1992—of $4.45 million was reduced to the $2.76 million that he has now admitted? Has Mr Brown's company actually been paid this $1.8 million difference, despite the Prime Minister's half-owned piggery company incurring multimillion dollar losses during this period?

—The first reply to Senator Baume is the one that I offered the other day: it is none of his business and he would be better occupied spending his time on his defamation defence in the New South Wales court system. The second point I make is that the relevant figure for the amount of the loan, or the amount in question, is the audited figure. The previous figures, or the other figures that he has quoted from time to time—and he is just muckraking again because he has been over this a dozen times before—were unaudited figures and do not represent a proper assessment by a firm of independent auditors of the kind that was finally produced for the year ending 30 June 1991; that is, the audited figures from Peat Marwick. The figure is $2.76 million.

PARA.TAB: The third point that I made the other day I make again for the record: the amount in question is, in a sense, not really to be construed as a loan at all because it is wholly payable at the discretion of the directors of the company concerned. It is in the nature, essentially, of a kind of goodwill payment; a goodwill payment that was to be dependent upon, in terms of its assessment and its payability, the judgment of the managers and directors of the company of whom the Prime Minister is not one. That is the final point.

This particular arrangement was determined by the former directors of the company in question before the Prime Minister became a shareholder in it and before the Prime Minister was involved, in any way, in the company. The decision as to whether the amount will be paid is one for the current directors of the company of whom Mr Keating is not one. So would Senator Baume mind getting off his horse again on this particular issue because he has made a dick of himself for the umpteenth time in raising this particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. That is an offensive comment.
—The minister will withdraw that comment.
—Delete `dick'; substitute `fool'.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware, or was he deliberately refusing to note, that the audited accounts to which he refers in fact show that the $2.76 million he claims is the debt to Mr Brown is only the residue remaining after more than $1 million was applied in the same audited accounts to pay off this subordinated loan? Has this money actually been paid to Mr Brown, or is it just a book entry, or has Mr Brown forgiven $1.8 million of this debt owing to him by the Prime Minister's piggery? Would the minister stop personally abusing me and for heaven's sake will he tell the Australian people the truth about exactly how much the Prime Minister's piggery company really owes Mr John Brown and not give us fiddled, fixed bookkeeping entries that change the amount really due?
—Senator Baume will continue to get the responses he deserves so long as his hands continue to drip with muckraking slime. As to the—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. That is a clear reflection and I ask that he withdraw it. In addition, he is not answering the question. If the minister cannot understand the conflict of interest between the Prime Minister owing a multimillion dollar sum to a lobbyist and the legitimacy of such questions, then he should not be in this place. He is being asked serious questions about the extent to which the Prime Minister is compromised by his indebtedness, the indebtedness of his company, to a lobbyist of this place. That is a serious question and it requires an attempt at a serious answer.
—On the first part of your point of order, I ask Senator Evans to withdraw that remark in the interests of Senate harmony. On the second part, I do not see that it is a point of order.
—I withdraw, Mr President. As to the first part of the question—

—On a point of order, Mr President, I wonder whether you can clarify your ruling in that respect. Are you saying that the only reason Senator Evans should withdraw those remarks is that it would be in the interests of harmony, or are you agreeing that it was an improper reference?
—On the point of order, Mr President, Senator Evans did not refer to Senator Baume in particular terms. He said that what he has got on his hands is a particular thing.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not at all. Judge Roy Bean here has already made a ruling, of course. The hanging judge has already given a ruling instead of the President. He is off and running. I think your ruling is absolutely right, Mr President—to say that, for the harmony of the place, it is best that Senator Evans withdraws his comment, but not on the basis that it is unparliamentary.
—I did not take it as parliamentary, although it was robust language. I have heard more robust language from both sides of the chamber, to which I have turned a deaf ear.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I am still not sure what your ruling is—whether you are saying that you regard that language as unparliamentary, that it was an unparliamentary imputation against another member, or whether you are just making some general comments about what you have heard in the past. What is your specific ruling on that type of reference?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr President, to be specific, standing order 193(3) states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator shall not use offensive words against either House of Parliament or . . . any member of such House . . . and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on those Houses, members or officers shall be considered highly disorderly.

I hope we have not yet reached the point where the likes of those on the other side can get up and talk about people's hands wringing with slime and that not somehow be regarded as a reflection on the improper motives of others. I would have thought it was an open and shut case. Mr President, if you are interested in this chamber running according to the rules, you ought to be prepared to rule in accordance with that standing order. This sort of language and behaviour are just not on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. We have here the most monumental example of the double standards that beset this place, where people feel at liberty to say anything under the protection of the standing orders about any other citizen. They can say that someone is an axe murderer, and that is perfectly legitimate. I had another letter very recently from a citizen complaining about what one member of the opposition said about her—I suspect correctly—but not in circumstances where she has access to the Privileges Committee to protect her. Nevertheless, those opposite are seeking to interpret in the most narrow and obsessive way anything that might be said about them.
—Mr President, can he go on forever? This is a debating point. Why do you shut us up on this side and not him?
—Order! Complete your point of order, Senator McMullan.

—Mr President, your ruling is entitled to say that it is reasonable to interpret the remarks that Senator Evans made as not being in breach of 193(3), if we are to continue to interpret our right about what we say about others as generously and as liberally as we do.

—On the point of order, Mr President, I urge you to rule that Senator Evans's language is not in line with parliamentary standards. We are very anxious that the low standards that Mr Keating uses in the other place are not imported into this Senate by Senator Evans. I urge you to rule Senator Evans out of order.

—It is my task to preside over this chamber and to try to keep some sort of order. It seemed to me that the best way of overcoming that was to ask Senator Evans to withdraw, which he did. Parliamentary language is set by precedent over time and changes with time. I do not believe that language of that sort, or of the sort that is continually contained in interjections from my left, is acceptable in this chamber, and I would like to stop all of that. But if we are to have robust debate these things are likely to happen. I have asked Senator Evans to withdraw; he has withdrawn. I ask him to continue his remarks, but speedily.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. Have you ruled that unparliamentary or parliamentary? If I were to say to you, Mr President, `Would you take your muckraking, slimy hands out of this?', would you regard that as parliamentary or unparliamentary?
—As I have already said, I regard all of that language as unparliamentary.

—As I only have time to make a short point about this matter, very simply, it is this: the fundamental premise upon which all these questions are based about a potential for conflict of interest is a premise which is fundamentally misconceived. It is misconceived for this reason: Mr Brown has absolutely no leverage over the company or its shareholders because any funds that might be dispensed to Mr Brown from this particular arrangement that was entered into before the Prime Minister even became a shareholder in the company is entirely a matter for the company's discretion. If that is so, where on earth is any possible leverage or conceivable conflict of interest?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer to the announcement he made on the tenth anniversary of Medicare regarding the charter of patients' rights and ask: will this charter have a specific assurance of the maximum length of time a patient will spend on a waiting list for elective surgery? I refer him to the British charter, which guarantees admission for treatment no later than two years from the date of being placed on a waiting list. Finally, if he is going to have such a clause in our charter, is two years a reasonable period or can we do better than that?

—I think we have to do better than that. As Senator Lees would be aware, from first getting the job I was anxious to convince the states that we needed nationally consistent data on waiting lists so that at least we would know how many people were on them and how long they were waiting. The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has been working with the states, particularly over the last few months, to try to standardise that data. A report will be released towards the end of this year which I hope will give us much more information so that we can determine what appropriate times are.

PARA.TAB: So far, the estimates I have received are that there are between 103,000 and 112,000 people around the country on waiting lists at the moment for so-called elective surgery. That is less than three per cent of Australian hospital admissions, which are about four million annually, and translates roughly into a couple of weeks of hospital throughput, which is not much. But when it comes to looking at those 103,000 to 112,000 people and how long they wait, we see that approximately one-third of the patients wait for less than a month. So approximately one-third move in and out of the hospital system very quickly. At the other end of that scale, another one-third have been waiting for more than six months. For those people, specialties such as ENT, some general surgery applications and orthopaedics are heavily represented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Orthopaedics, not general surgery.

—That is what the report shows; it is a fact. What we then have to work out is whether it is two years, one year, six months or whatever. The only way we are going to be able to do that is to look at what is clinically appropriate in each instance. I am not sure that what is clinically appropriate is going to be translatable into a general charter. Certainly, there ought to be some sort of minimum guarantee to all patients in the public system. So I would like to do that. Of course, that also begs the question that we will need a proper definition of `elective surgery'. I am not sure that we have ever had that, either.

PARA.TAB: Between now and when this report comes out at the end of the year, I intend to be discussing that with the states to see whether a result can be obtained by the end of 1994, and then in 1995 perhaps we can move towards adding some kind of guarantee into the charter. Most of the states would be happy to do that provided it is workable and we can translate it from clinically appropriate times for whatever conditions people are waiting for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Watson asked me a question concerning sports grants and the role of the Department of Finance. I have an answer to that question which, since it is reasonably lengthy, it might be appropriate for the Senate to agree to incorporate in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: SUBJECT: Finance action in relation to Auditor-General's report (No. 9 of 1993-94) on the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program.

QUESTION:Was the administration of Minister Kelly's grants consistent with the accountability prescriptions within the Audit Act, finance regulations and finance directions? What action did the Department of Finance, as the responsible policeman, or the Government's relevant minister take in response to the Auditor-General's report? Question asked by Senator Watson of Senator Cook on 22 February 1994.
SUGGESTED RESPONSE:
The Community Cultural Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program is a non-statutory program, the finance for which is provided by annual appropriation.
The program dates back to 1988 and the Executive at that time determined that grants should be subject to guidelines agreed between the Minister for Finance and the portfolio minister.

The program is subject, like all programs, to audit by the Auditor-General, normal reporting in Program Performance Statements and evaluation as part of the Government's continuing evaluation program.
Relevant Finance Regulations and Directions are Regulation 44A and Directions 13(10) and 13(12). In addition, general legislation covering the expenditure of public moneys applies.
Finance is not aware of any breach of the Finance Regulations or Directions.
Program administration and management are the responsibility of the department concerned. Finance does not have the role of a policeman.
The Auditor-General has the audit responsibilities, including compliance auditing with the Guidelines, Regulations and Directions.

The CCRSPF Program and the Audit Report have been the subject of further investigation by the House of Representatives Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Finance is awaiting that Committee's report.

Finance is a member of the Steering Committee for the evaluation of the program which is being conducted during 1993-94. Discussions commenced in November 1993 and are continuing with the Department of the Environment, Sport and the Territories on the Terms of Reference for that program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 February, I received a question from Senator Ferguson concerning Mr Kelly, the former Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service. In answer to that question, I said that it was my understanding that the decision on salary was made by my departmental secretary as my delegate. I am now advised that the correct position is that the determination was made by the Public Service Commissioner. I have a detailed recapitulation of those events, which is lengthy. I ask whether that also can be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As leave has not been granted, I will read it into the record. In order that the position is clear, let me recapitulate my understanding of the events. Following receipt of the Conroy report on the Australian Customs Service, the Minister for Science and Small Business had discussions with the Comptroller-General of Customs, Mr Kelly. As Senator Schacht has said, after these discussions Mr Kelly agreed to stand down from the position of Comptroller-General. Mr Kelly expressed his interest in moving to another position within government.

PARA.TAB: The minister acknowledged that Mr Kelly did have expertise which may provide opportunities for him elsewhere in the Australian Public Service—for example, in providing advice to the government on issues related to regional trade liberalisation, including the outcomes of APEC. The Minister for Science and Small Business referred Mr Kelly to the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and to the Public Service Commissioner for discussion of the terms of his separation from the position of Comptroller-General. The minister also informed the secretary to my department of the suggestion of work on APEC. The secretary responded that this would be a worthwhile project for an officer of Mr Kelly's seniority and background, given the importance APEC ministers had assigned to work on customs harmonisation, and subsequently developed a proposal which was agreed by the minister and Mr Kelly.

Following consultation with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Public Service Commissioner, and approval by the Minister for Science and Small Business, the secretary to my department informed Mr Kelly on 4 February that, although his resignation as Comptroller-General of Customs would have the effect, in the formal sense, of his reverting to his substantive Public Service level, the Commonwealth wished to continue to employ him as a special adviser until the end of 1995, on equivalent terms and conditions to those he had had as Comptroller-General.

On 8 February, the Public Service Commissioner agreed that a personal rate of pay determination for Mr Kelly was an appropriate course of action in this case and executed the determination which enabled Mr Kelly to be paid salary at the same rate as the salary he had been receiving as Comptroller-General of Customs. In other words, proper procedure was followed in determining a salary for Mr Kelly for a fixed and finite period appropriate to the role of special adviser and acceptable to both the government and Mr Kelly in the context of his resignation from Customs.

The position has been put by some honourable senators that, instead, the government should have dismissed Mr Kelly. In line with what the Minister for Science and Small Business has said here before, I make the following key points about that: even if the government had been so minded, Mr Kelly, as Comptroller-General of Customs, was a statutory office holder and the grounds for dismissal by the parliament and the Governor-General under the Customs Administration Act 1985 did not exist. Even if, theoretically, this had happened, Mr Kelly would have reverted in any event to a Public Service position at deputy secretary level.

The government's conduct in this matter provides the opportunity for new senior management in Customs, while at the same time treating Mr Kelly in a way that is fair and allowing his experience to be drawn on in an important project of benefit to the government and to the country.
That is the answer I provide in further answer to Senator Ferguson's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in question time today I received the first question from Senator Hill, who asked me about an interjection recorded in Hansard yesterday. Senator Hill in his supplementary question accused me of being a liar in my answer. He subsequently withdrew, upon your ruling, that unparliamentary expression. Mr President, I denied at the time, forthrightly and straightforwardly, that I knew anything about the issue. That is the true position. I resent the fact that my answer was not believed and that the opposition maintained that I am not telling the truth. It is a reflection, I believe, on my integrity and on my honesty.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I have now caused a check of all the circumstances to be run. The fact is that my office did not receive or see any Hansard pinks relating to the question that Senator Hill asked me about today—

TALK.START.PARA: —Relating to the interjection, I mean—nor should it have.
—You don't get pinks of interjections!

—The question yesterday was addressed to Senator Evans. My interjection was recorded. My office received no pinks of the question and answer yesterday—the subject of the question from Senator Hill to me today—nor should it have because the question was directed to Senator Evans and the pinks are distributed to the minister who answers the question. Needless to say, I or anyone else on my staff never approached Hansard, had no knowledge of the issue or made no representations in any form.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, Senator Gareth Evans's office advised me that it received the pinks in the usual way. It made no approach to Hansard at all on the issue, nor did Senator Evans. The allegation made by Senator Hill—and backed up by Senator Short by interjection—is therefore disproved, and disproved beyond reasonable doubt. The truthfulness of my answer is confirmed.

Since Senator Hill's question today, my office has checked with Hansard to find out how it came to include my interjection in full. Hansard has advised my office that the daily Hansard, as published, is correct. Hansard says that at the time of the interjection there was general hubbub in the chamber. My interjection was made in two parts. Hansard checked the tape of the Senate proceedings and rightly included the full interjection.

Mr President, it is clear that Hansard has conscientiously done its job; that no representations were made by me, by Senator Evans or by anyone from our staff; and that Hansard has been published accurately. I presume that there is a copy of the tape and Senator Hill and Senator Short could listen to it.

In all those circumstances, as I have said, my truthfulness is confirmed. There is now, I believe, an obligation on Senator Hill and Senator Short—who, through his interjection, made a similar imputation against me—to withdraw their allegations and apologise. Failure to do that will cause any fair judge to form an opinion about their credibility and integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans.
—Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement in answer to the minister's invitation.
—You'll have your opportunity later.
—No, no! I have sought leave—
—You've misbehaved. You just sit down and wait your turn!
—Senator Hill, I called Senator Evans before you stood.
