—My colleagues would like to get back to doing some real work. If Senator Hill has anything more to say, he can do it later at the proper time through a motion to take note of answers.

—Yesterday Senator Hill asked me a question seeking information about the holding by ASIS of files on Australian citizens. I answered him yesterday to the best of my recollection. I said that I would seek further advice and information and, if it was possible to do so, I would put that on the record. I now do just that.

PARA.TAB: I add as follows: ASIS's prime task is the collection of foreign intelligence. ASIS holds no charter to collect intelligence on Australians. It does not do so and does not hold files for that purpose. Files that are held by ASIS on Australians relate to its own staff or potential recruits, and people who have substantive dealings with the organisation or who are otherwise connected with its operations. The number of such files is less than a fraction of the so-called `tens of thousands' mentioned on Four Corners. As to the question of access to files held by other government organisations, including Telecom, the Department of Social Security, Medicare and the Australian Taxation Office—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, when this gang of rabble comes to order and listens to what I am trying to say in response to Senator Hill, I will be happy to continue.
—Order! Senator Evans.

—As to the question of access to files by other government organisations, the situation is that ASIS is no different in this respect from any other department or government agency. It is bound by all the restraints and protective measures that are presently generally applicable for guaranteeing personal privacy. In that respect, the 1984 Hope royal commission reaffirmed that the director-general and ASIS should comply with the law not just in relation to these questions of files and so on, but in respect of any activity carried out in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the arrangements for the oversight of privacy and other human rights considerations, as far as ASIS is concerned, centre on, as I said yesterday, the Office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. That inspector-general has full and unrestricted access to ASIS's records and is able to examine the organisation's holdings at his discretion and choosing. That confirms what I said yesterday in that respect. IGIS—the inspector-general—has, in fact, conducted two spot checks of ASIS's personal records since these allegations were first made late last year and has found in each case valid reasons for all the records held which he so checked.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to a question asked yesterday by Senator Campbell concerning the community cultural, recreation and sports facilities program. His question related to a development at Altone Park. He asked whether other grants had been supplemented with additional funds from general revenue. I am advised that no other projects received capital funding from general revenue through Mrs Kelly's portfolio. However, some projects may well have received operational or other funding from some other government agency. The Altone Park project was a specific election commitment. As such, it was separate from the grants considered under the community cultural, recreation and sports facilities program.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell also asked me to confirm when the $250,000 allocated for the program was announced. As I indicated yesterday, the grant was announced at the same time as all other Western Australian grants in November 1992. Senator Campbell also asked me whether the Minister for Finance or the Prime Minister had knowledge or approval of the $750,000 specifically referred to. The $750,000 was allocated in the 1993-94 budget and therefore went through the normal budgetary processes, which obviously involved both the Minister for Finance and the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was also asked a question by Senator Knowles. I gave an undertaking to provide further information as to why the South Fremantle Football Club requested a $4,000 grant and was given $50,000. Mrs Kelly has provided me with the following information: the House of Representatives Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts has already received a response from the department concerning this grant. I understand the response was given to the committee on 23 December last year and was authorised for publication by the committee. Clearly Senator Knowles should have researched this better before raising it here. She would have then known that the South Fremantle Football Club actually requested $64,000, not $4,000. The project was to light the oval to enable night use of the ground. It was a worthwhile project and met the needs-based criteria applied by the minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I want to ask you a short question—I am happy for you to take it on notice, if necessary—about the conduct of senators in committees. I draw your attention to an article in the latest Sunday Telegraph by Senator Loosley which is highly critical of the deliberations of the Senate Select Committee on the Print Media but which fails to disclose the highly relevant fact that the writer is also a member of the committee. Is this a conflict of interest pursuant to standing order 27(5) or, at the very least, dishonest or unethical use of a regular column without revealing the writer's personal connection with the subject matter? Furthermore, despite the fact—

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did he not have the guts to say so in his article?
—It is a matter of public record and notoriety.
—Your average mug punter and reader does not know that.
—It shows you're a mug; that is what they know.
—That sounds like a tautology to me.
—Order! Get on with your question, Senator Alston.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We are having constant problems with the language of Senator Gareth Evans in his foul temper. Could you ask him to withdraw the comment he just made about Senator Alston.
—Mr President, on the point of order, can I draw your attention to a comment about Senator Kemp made by Mr Warden in the Canberra Times on 8 February, which relates squarely to his interjection:

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp is unaccountably unpopular on the Labor side of the Senate. Other than his bumptiousness, his transparent love of his own voice and his deeply held conviction that his interjections are very witty and insightful when they are nothing of the sort, it is hard to see what anyone could hold against him.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an abuse of parliament.

—He may have been abusing the point of order but he was also making a fairly pertinent point. Both sides are using language that is inappropriate for adults in this chamber and at this level of government, or anywhere. It is very hard to create a situation where one is blamed for it the whole time. That was robust language but not unparliamentary language and I will not ask Senator Evans to withdraw it.

—Thank you, Mr President. Might I say in passing that Senator Evans's totally unresponsive answer was, in effect, a direct challenge to your authority in this chamber. If you are going to continue to allow that, then we are into a different ball game.

PARA.TAB: I conclude the question: furthermore, despite the fact that all members of the committee received written advice that the United States Supreme Court has ruled that the Congress retains its powers to deal with contempt, the article falsely claims that Congress has abrogated this right. In these circumstances, will you closely examine what appears to be seriously misleading and deceptive behaviour on the part of a member of this Senate and advise the Senate in due course on what action you propose to take?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is extraordinary!
—And I would not bother with you.
—I take it that that question was to Senator Evans.
—No, it was a question to you, Mr President.
—Mr President, I seek enlightenment on a matter of order in relation to that question. Do I take it that Senator Alston is purporting to raise a matter of privilege?
—I sought leave to ask the President a short question concerning the conduct of senators and committees. You, in a very rare burst of good grace, granted me leave, and I am very grateful to you.
—I am sorry, I was not listening clearly to the question. I will have to take that on notice and look at it in the Hansard.

—Mr President, on a point of order. It is a rather unusual point of order because I should be asking you to withdraw a reflection on Senator Kemp. You may explain to the Senate what you meant when you said that Mr Warden had obviously made a pertinent point in answer to the little bit of amusement that the minister was having.

—I am happy to explain it. Interjections have been occurring from both sides of this chamber. Answers to questions from my right-hand side and constant interjections from my left-hand side have used language that is inappropriate for this chamber. I did not finger anybody. I did not mention Senator Kemp. I said that it was happening on both sides. In fact, the person who asked the question used the very same word that was used in response by Senator Evans—he used the word `mug'. I will not be placed in a position where I start to punish one side unequally to the other.
—I take it that you do not think it is necessary to withdraw that reflection.
—I do not.
—That is interesting to note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Senator Cook) to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the Hansard record of question time on 22 February 1994 and tax increases.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister, in his answer to the supplementary to the first question, and in order to explain the inconsistency between the proof and the pink of the Hansard, said that in fact he did say, `That wasn't the government promise. It was the burden of taxes'. It was to that that I responded that he lied. You made me withdraw it, Mr President, but I responded in those terms because all of us who heard his interjection yesterday know that that simply was not so. He knows it too, because he was highly embarrassed by his interjection. Let me explain. What was occurring was that Senator Kemp had raised a point of order. Senator Kemp's point of order was:
The question was very clear and specific: whether the government would stick by its promise not to introduce any new taxes.

The minister got ahead of himself and interjected, `That wasn't the government promise'. Of course he was highly embarrassed by it; everybody laughed, and that was basically what happened. Senator Evans had to turn around and admonish him, and that was the end of that matter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just listen! It was so recorded, and appeared in the pink in those terms. In the proof of the Hansard apparently the words, `It was the burden of taxes' were added immediately following what he had said; that is, `That wasn't the government promise'. Then `It was the burden of taxes' appears, which was the explanation that Minister Evans was seeking to make. But that sequence of interjections simply did not occur in that way. Minister Cook knows it, and Minister Evans knows it; and I think anyone who was close to Senator Cook knows that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: I have now learnt during the course of question time that the additional words were added to the proof copy by Hansard because they had been separately recorded by the Hansard staff officer who makes the additional notes of interjections. Whether he added those words later, I do not know, because I did not hear that, but if that was recorded by the Hansard officer I am not disputing that he added those words at a later stage.

But as it is recorded in Hansard it is clearly misleading, because that was not the interjection that was made by Senator Cook. That is why I said it was a lie, because he stood by, knowing what was in the proof copy, and decided the best course of action open to him today was to say that that is what he said in those terms—and that was not true.

I do accept that Hansard added those words without an intervention by the minister. He has made that point, and I accept that. I was not aware of that, but as the Hansard records the interjection at the moment, it is wrong. Senator Cook knows that it is wrong, and that is what ought to be corrected.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the motion to take note that has been moved by Senator Hill, my clear recollection of the situation is that Hansard is right and Senator Hill is wrong in saying that this does not accurately record the sequence of events. It does accurately record the sequence of events in the following way: Senator Cook interjected, `That wasn't the government promise'. He was interrupted immediately by a roar of guffaws, horse laughs, rhubarb, and boo-boo noises from the other side.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I turned around because he had been interrupted in mid-flight by a roar of noise coming across at him. He then said, `It was the burden of taxes'—or it was about the burden. It was a variation on that theme. He used the word `burden' immediately after. In other words, he meant, `That is what I am trying to say'.

PARA.TAB: That is exactly what Senator Cook said today. He said it by way of interjection before I had got back to my feet or before Senator Kemp had got to his feet to continue with his next bit, as I was saying before. There was an interruption. Maybe, ideally, that could have been recorded by a little bracket saying `laughter, uproar, boo-rah from the opposition', as sometimes happens, or `interjections or jeers' in the italicised bracket between the two sentences. Maybe that would have been a better way of recording it, because there was a gap of time, as Senator Cook said. But he definitely used that expression. I was sitting here. I heard him use the expression `burden of taxes'—it was precisely that sentence or some sentence very much like it.

Those are the words he used. That was understood as the next relevant interjection to occur in the general hubbub. It was said and it was recorded before the next substantive contribution from the next speaker—or the next contribution, I should say, because it came from Senator Kemp and to describe that as substantive would be unduly generous. Be that as it may, the sequence was accurate, it has been accurately recorded and I endorse what Senator Cook said that it is up to Senator Hill to be a little more gracious than he seems capable of being on this occasion, and acknowledge that he made a mistake—that he made an outrageous allegation against Senator Cook—and withdraw and apologise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a couple of words on this matter because Senator Cook mentioned my name along with Senator Hill's—and I endorse the comments made by Senator Hill. Regarding Senator Evans's comment, I hope Senator Evans will listen to this because, quite frankly, what he has just said is at the very least the gilding of the lily. Senator Evans might care to listen to this because after the interjection by Senator Cook that is recorded in Hansard, Senator Kemp picked up further on his point of order, to which Senator Evans came back and, because he was answering my supplementary question, said:

SPEECH.PARA: What we have said consistently is that we will not be increasing the burden of taxation. That is no doubt what Senator Cook was thinking of a moment ago.

In other words, Senator Evans was giving an interpretation of what Senator Cook had not said, and if Senator Cook had made the interjection `It was the burden of taxes' that is now in Hansard at that time, then there would be no earthly reason for Senator Evans to make that statement that Senator Cook no doubt was thinking about that. I ask Senator Evans, when he has the grace eventually to wander back into the chamber or to read the Hansard, whether he can explain why he made that statement, because it has really just compounded the confusion and concern—some would say the felony—that has been committed.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans was also wrong when, in that supplementary answer yesterday, he said that the government `will not be increasing the burden of taxation'. If by `the burden of taxation' he means the proportion of taxation—the total taxation take—to gross domestic product each year, and I am sure he does, on the government's own figures in the budget documents last year, the proportion of tax to GDP goes up each year of the period to 1996-97 that the government has forecast out to. Not only that, but in the mid-year review that was released just a couple of weeks ago, even the 1993-94 figure has been increased. So the budget figures are an under estimate of the degree of increase that we will be seeing in the incidence of taxation over the next four years. There is no doubt that Senator Evans and the government need to come back and make an apology to this Senate for yet another totally misleading and incorrect statement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, they weave, they dodge, they squirm and they manipulate what they said, but the facts are that no approach was made to Hansard by me or Senator Evans or any of our staff. The allegation made was that we did. That allegation is wrong.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I am surprised that you called Senator Cook. He has already spoken on this matter.
—He has not spoken on taking note.

—Those opposite interrupt to deny the facts, but the facts are that no approach was made to Hansard and that it acted of its own volition after listening to the tape. Therefore, the allegation made against me is proven to be false. It would be an uplifting event in parliamentary life, and particularly in this chamber, if those opposite would simply be honest, tell the truth, not try to distort the facts and come clean. They are caught absolutely and straightforwardly.

PARA.TAB: It is not an allegation those opposite can make against us. In fact, what they are saying is a slur on Hansard and the accuracy and propriety with which Hansard goes about its business of recording truthfully and accurately what is said between senators in this chamber.

I repeat that no approach was made to Hansard by me or my staff, or by Senator Evans or his staff. Hansard acted after listening to the tape. It may well be that those opposite do not like that. It is clear from their demeanour that they do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is there any responsibility on any minister in this place to tell the truth? The minister has been told on no fewer than 10 occasions by all of us here that he is wrong that we listened to the tape. How many more times is he allowed to stand up here and blatantly say something that is incorrect? Will you pull him to order?

—I have no way of knowing what is correct and incorrect about the tape. I can assist the Senate by providing honourable senators with some information from Hansard, but it mentions nothing about tapes. I will read that to honourable senators afterwards.

—That was no point of order. It was simply an effort to try to disrupt what I was saying. It may well be that what I said is inconvenient for the opposition. The real truth of this matter is that those opposite do not like the facts as put out properly and dispassionately by me in that interjection in the Hansard. It is clear why they do not. They are trying to use taxation as some sort of issue in the current political circumstances, and there is now no evidence for them to be able to do so.

PARA.TAB: The circumstances as I am advised are, as I have truthfully reported to the Senate, that there was absolutely no contact between Hansard and my office or Senator Evans's office. On that fact alone, therefore, the allegations put against me cannot be sustained and, if there was any honour, would be withdrawn.

I am advised that one of my staff spoke to Hansard and was informed that Hansard got the information from the tape. On that basis my innocence in terms of this allegation is not only proved but is proved beyond reasonable doubt. In those circumstances, the fair and honest thing to do is to come clean, be honest for a change, tell the truth, stand up and apologise and withdraw the allegations.

There seems to be no desire by anyone in the opposition to do that. I have heard their explanations. They are empty, threadbare and facile. I am met with a constant barrage of continuing allegations and am questioned as to why I do not believe those opposite. The reason why I do not believe them is that, when confronted with irrefutable facts, they still maintain a position that has no credibility. That reflects on their integrity, their honesty and their standing. They are not entitled to be believed if they will not accept the truth. From this point on, I might say, any comments that they claim to be true should not ever be accepted by this government, until such time as they are properly investigated, analysed and then replied to.

This is a disgraceful event in the Senate. It reflects no credit on the opposition at all. In particular, it reflects no credit on the main players in this game. It is really, obviously and blatantly an occasion on which a wrong once perpetrated is being persisted with in the face of overwhelming evidence.

This is a shocking and disgraceful event. It is a terrible reproach to the conduct of the opposition and a terrible reflection on this parliament. It is in the hands of the opposition to correct all those circumstances, simply by standing up and, in the case of these two individuals because of their gender, being men and being honest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Senator Cook) walks away. He does not want to hear the truth. He will hear the truth whether he wants to hear it or not. The video has now been examined and the soundtrack listened to and I can tell the Senate exactly what occurred. What in fact happened, as I said, was that Senator Kemp interjected:

SPEECH.PARA: The question was very clear and specific: whether the government would stick by its promise not to introduce any new taxes.
Then there was an interjection by Senator Cook which, apparently, is recorded clearly on the video. He said:
That wasn't the government promise.

That was the moment of high embarrassment, as we remember, when everyone laughed and Senator Gareth Evans turned around and looked somewhat annoyed at his fellow minister. There was a lot of laughter and so forth. A further clear interjection was picked up from Senator Kemp. He said, `Oh, what a joke'. The minister is then seen mouthing an additional set of words which may well have been, `It was the burden of taxes'. If he said that, it was clearly an afterthought. It was clearly in response to the interruption and, in particular, to the further interjection of Senator Kemp that was not recorded. What that all means, when we put the picture together, is that Senator Cook did mislead the Senate today when he indicated to the Senate that his interjection was as appeared in the proof copy and not in the pink. In fact, it would have been accurate for him to say, `As it was in the pink was correct, then there were further interjections, particularly from Senator Kemp, and I added a few words as an afterthought'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gareth told him what to say.

—After Gareth had told him what to say. Unfortunately, it seems that the correction was not totally right; but the additional words were added by Hansard because they were recorded by a separate Hansard officer who added those words into the transcript later in the day. I accept that. I do not accept the explanation by Senator Cook during question time that what appears in the proof copy is what he said in the form that appears in the proof copy because that is simply not so.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) to a question without notice asked by Senator Knowles on 21 February 1994, relating to the allocation of sports funding.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that no matter how much Senator Richardson wants to bully his way out of this exercise, and tell me that I should have done further research into this answer that was given to the House of Representatives committee last November, it does not alter the situation one jot. The fact of the matter is that here are 42 pages of the applications for government grants under the sports rorts system. Page 6 refers to the South Fremantle Football Club, registration No. WAU/4/037. It gives a total project cost of $128,000 and states that the grant sought was $4,000.

PARA.TAB: Another document that has been provided refers to the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program 1992-93 and it lists the grants that were given. This document, yet again provided by the government, says that the South Fremantle Football Club was given $50,000. I am quite happy to believe that the South Fremantle Football Club realised it had made an error when it put in its original request. But at no stage does this government or this minister have any accountability, whatsoever, of where that second lodgment is. Why does it not provide the documentation? I challenge it to provide the documentation on the basis on which it increased this grant by $46,000. It is not by the opposition or the pixies at the bottom of the garden; it is by this government.

Senator Richardson, as I say, can bully his way through anything. But the fact of the matter is that these documents, to which I refer today, have actually come from Minister Kelly's office. If these documents are wrong, I challenge the minister to tell me where the right ones are. I can tell the Senate that there are other grants on this list that have been given that are not on the lists of requests. Three grants that have been given are not on the lists of requests—one for $10,000; one for $50,000; and another for $10,000. These do not even appear here. Who has the correct list and when will we see it?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Senator Cook) to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson this day, relating to Mr Frank Kelly, the former Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for my asking that question today was brought about by a response that Senator Cook made on 21 February in answering my interjection. I said:
Was there a legal obligation to employ him—
referring to Mr Frank Kelly—
at that salary?
Senator Cook's response on 21 February was:
There was a legal obligation to recognise the rights of a statutory office holder.
In answer to my question today, Senator Cook said:
No, I am not saying that, and I did not say it at the time.

And that raises the question, is Mr Kelly's appointment as an adviser to DITARD in line with his legal entitlements or is his salary level of $126,760 above his legal entitlement, meaning that he has been given a special deal? Senator Schacht, in answer to one of my questions on 9 February, said:
This appointment was made in accordance with the procedures and rules laid down by the Public Service Act, and there is nothing untoward about it.
In taking note on the same day, he said:

I do not think people opposite should get too carried away about the fact that Mr Kelly has gone to this position. He would have been entitled to be paid a substantial amount of money on the unattached list.

Senator Schacht's answers are right. There is nothing legally untoward about a determination being issued under section 82D of the Public Service Act so that Mr Kelly can continue to get $126,760 a year. The question is whether the government was obliged to issue this determination. I believe the answer is no. Under part 4 of the Public Service Act, which relates to mobility, when Mr Kelly took up the position of Comptroller-General he became unattached at his substantive level which was that of Deputy Comptroller-General, only an SES band 3 position.

PARA.TAB: The question is also one of morality and rewarding public servants who could be seen to be incompetent. If the government does not have a legal obligation to pay Mr Kelly any more than the maximum basic salary of around $102,000, why go to the trouble of issuing a section 82D determination to raise his salary to $126,760? Was this part of the deal to induce Mr Kelly to resign as Comptroller-General because, as we all know, the only way to sack him is by a vote of both houses of parliament. This raises a second question of when this adviser's position was created and was it created especially for Mr Kelly?
On 9 February, Senator Schacht said:

SPEECH.PARA: After discussion with Mr Kelly, he agreed to stand down from that position but he made the decision . . . not to resign from the Public Service. Therefore, when he stood down, whatever position he may or may not have been appointed to by me, he would have been unattached at a senior level of the Public Service, even if we had not given him a job to do.
Senator Cook, on 10 February, said:

As a consequence of the APEC meeting in Seattle late last year, there was an agreement between all of the participating nations in APEC that we would set up committees to work towards the harmonising of standards, particularly of customs standards and practices . . .

PARA.TAB: Consequently, there was obviously an identifiable need for an expert in this field and, as a result, when Mr Kelly became available, the department appointed him to that position . . .

This was not a position created especially for any individual. It was a position thrown up by the needs of this country . . . it is a position for which very few people have qualifications, and Mr Kelly is one of those very few people who is appropriately available.

SPEECH.PARA: So, I ask, when exactly was this position created? Senator Cook stated that the need for this position was identified following the APEC summit in November and it was not created especially for any individual.

But Senator Schacht said, `Whatever position he may or may not have been appointed to by me'. He also said, `Even if we had not given him a job'. Either this position was identified and created with a view to gazetting or advertising it, or it was created as a result of the consultations which took place before Mr Kelly's resignation. It would be an incredible coincidence if the position was created, nothing was done to fill it, and then miraculously Mr Kelly resigns from Customs and Senator Schacht appoints him.

PARA.TAB: Because I am not sure that the information that has been provided to this chamber in the past two weeks has been correct—in fact, it may have been misleading—I will be pursuing these matters most vigorously tomorrow at estimates.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take notice of an answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume this day relating to the Prime Minister's investment in a piggery.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans gave the usual abusive answer, and none of the minister's continual pattern of personal abuse of me will prevent me from seeking the truth about the Prime Minister's piggery half-ownership. I want to say that I do not deal in false accusations or unsubstantiated muck. I deal in accounts that have been filed at the Australian Securities Commission which Senator Evans is either unable to understand or refuses to admit are factual, despite the fact that I have tabled them in this place. There is no excuse for Senator Evans's disgraceful behaviour today.

PARA.TAB: These accounts, from which Senator Evans very selectively quoted today, show $2.76 million that he claims as the outstanding debt to John Brown by the Prime Minister's piggery company. The facts are that those accounts also show that $662,650 was applied to pay off that debt to John Brown in 1991 following a similar allocation of $475,000 in 1990. A total of almost $1.1 million was revealed in those accounts which Senator Evans magically was unable to detect when he came to this place and quoted from the accounts.

Because of the potential for conflict of interest, I asked a simple, uncomplicated question, and I will repeat it: are the Australian people entitled to know how the Prime Minister's company's debt, which was shown in its accounts for 1991 lodged with the Australian Securities Commission on 2 December 1992 at $4.45 million, was reduced to the $2.76 million that Senator Evans now admits exists? I was given an inadequate response to my first question which was: has Mr Brown's company actually been paid this $1.8 million difference? That is the essential thing. Has this $1.8 million difference between an admitted debt to Mr Brown and the statement that Senator Evans says is now the debt to Mr Brown been paid or has it not? What happened to it?

In my supplementary question I said that there were clearly some options available. I asked: has this money actually been paid to Mr Brown, is it just a book entry, or has Mr Brown forgiven the $1.8 million of this debt owing to him by the Prime Minister's piggery? We naturally got no answer to a very proper question relating to the level of indebtedness of the Prime Minister to a lobbyist, former colleague and someone who is appointed to government boards. It was a very proper question relating to the potential for conflict of interest. It was described as unsubstantiated muck, when it is all quoted from ASC documents saying clearly that there was $4.45 million. We simply want to know the facts. The Australian people are entitled to know how much is this Prime Minister under an obligation, protected by the corporate veil naturally, to a lobbyist, Mr Brown.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I was out of the chamber when note was taken of Senator Cook's answer. I would like to make a short statement on that. I noticed on the closed circuit television that Senator Cook demanded an apology from Senator Kemp. I would entertain Senator Cook asking for such an apology were he prepared to do the same with everyone else he has offended and misrepresented in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: A few years ago I asked a question about a pulp mill in Western Australia. There was a complaint in Perth, the unions took part in some action, and I asked a question of Senator Cook. Senator Cook said that he would take it on notice and come back. The next day in the chamber he said, `Senator Panizza should have declared his interest or his shareholding in Riverhouse'. At the time I explained that I never had any shares in Riverhouse, that my immediate partners and my children had no shares in Riverhouse, and that my wife had shares in nothing.

I explained that, but Senator Cook turned around like a coward and left the chamber, refusing to apologise. He has not apologised to this day. A lot of things have been said about me, Mr Deputy President, and you know it, but I have never had my honesty questioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: I think Senator Panizza is pushing the indulgence of the Senate to the limit by referring to Senator Cook as a coward. I ask that he withdraw that comment.
—I do withdraw that.
—Order! In fact, what you said, Senator Panizza, was `like a coward'. I also was rather uncomfortable with that expression and I am delighted that you have withdrawn it.
—All I can say in this place is that he acted like a coward that day. I cannot see there is any objection to that.
—I think Senator Panizza should bear in mind why he is speaking and the fact that the government allowed him an indulgence. He is abusing that indulgence.
—You have withdrawn it, but you might find another set of words to describe it.

—I want to finish it off; I withdraw it. Senator Cook refused to withdraw any imputation and left the chamber. Time and time again over the past few years he has been called on by Senator Kemp to withdraw the imputation. As I was saying, I have had a lot of abuse in my time one way and another, but I do not think until that day I had ever had my honesty questioned. Fortunately, the people I deal with in business have taken very little notice of the statement Senator Cook made that day. They know about it; I let as many people know as possible. What he said was public knowledge. To this day he has never made any apology. Senator Kemp reminds him time and time again, but he has never apologised.

PARA.TAB: I had forgotten about Senator Cook not apologising, but he now has the gall to ask Senator Kemp to make an apology. It is up to Senator Kemp to decide what he wants to do, but I suggest to Senator Cook, if he is in his office, that before he demands an apology from Senator Kemp he ought to look at the intended damage he did to me at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for inquiry and report by the last sitting day of December 1994:

(1)The accountability of Commonwealth, state and territory authorities for the expenditure of Commonwealth funds under the Schools Program, including general recurrent grants, capital grants, targeted assistance and national priority programs, with specific reference to the appropriateness and effectiveness of current accountability mechanisms.
(2)The implications of Commonwealth funding arrangements for schools for the quality of, and equity of access to, primary and secondary education.
(3)The extent to which the Commonwealth's role in post-compulsory education and training could be strengthened to enhance national economic and social objectives such as:

TAB.TAB: (a)the achievement of full employment;
(b)the development of a more flexible, highly skilled and productive workforce; and
(c)the development of a more literate, articulate and democratic society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary government response to the outstanding recommendations in report No. 325 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the Midford Paramount case, together with a press release relating to the matter. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Government Response to Outstanding Recommendations in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' Report No 325 (Midford Paramount Case)
1The defendants in the Midford Case and others be compensated for their unrecovered material losses and legal costs.

On 10 November 1993 Senator Chris Schacht, the Minister for Science and Small Business, announced government approval for approximately $25M in compensation payments in response to this recommendation. A copy of the Minister's media release is attached.

3The Government establish a dedicated unit within the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office to investigate individual complaints made against Customs. Additional resources should be provided by the Government to establish this unit. It should report to Parliament through the Ombudsman's Annual Report. The Committee considers that the present practice of Customs officers being seconded to the Ombudsman is unacceptable.

The Committee has recommended both that Australian Customs Service (ACS) officers no longer be seconded to the Ombudsman and also that additional resources be provided to the Ombudsman to permit the establishment of a unit dedicated to investigating complaints against the ACS.

The Ombudsman's office policy is that secondees do not handle complaints about their `home' departments or agencies. That policy applies to ACS staff as it does to staff seconded from any other department or agency.

The Ombudsman's office has, from its inception, entered into secondment arrangements with Commonwealth departments and agencies. Seconded staff from a number of departments and agencies, including the ACS, have made a valuable contribution to the work of the office over the years. Staff who spend time in the office gain an increased appreciation of the principles of administrative review and the operation of the administrative review system which is likely to be of benefit not only to them, but also to their `home' department and its customers.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration considered the general question of secondments to the Ombudsman's office in the context of its 1992 review of that office's operations. It favoured the continuation of efforts to encourage secondment arrangements.

Within the office of the Ombudsman there is already a degree of specialisation in relation to the handling of complaints. Although no one area of the office is exclusively devoted to the investigation of complaints about a single department or agency, one of the investigation teams has a particular responsibility for ACS matters. The office has established a special investigation unit (as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration) to conduct major investigations. The unit has a different purpose and broader focus from that envisaged in Recommendation 3. Where appropriate, however, it would deal with complaints about the ACS.
While some of the benefits sought by this recommendation are already in place, the Government is unable to provide extra resources to be dedicated to investigation of complaints against the ACS.

64The Government conduct a review into the operation of the Proceeds of Crimes Act to establish whether its application by the Director of Public Prosecutions is consistent with the intention of that legislation.

The recommendation appears to be based on the assumption that the Parliament did not intend the Proceeds of Crimes Act 1987 to be used in non-narcotics related offences. It was always the intention of the legislature that the Proceeds of Crimes Act 1987 apply to all indictable Commonwealth offences and this is reflected in the Second Reading Speech.
This recommendation is rejected.

76Where Cabinet documents are likely to be of importance to intended Commonwealth prosecution proceedings, the Australian Government Solicitor or Director of Public Prosecutions be permitted to access and copy those documents so that adequate legal consideration can be given to their contents and relevance. By this the Committee does not, however, wish to preclude the placing by the Cabinet Office of appropriate restrictions on that access by the Commonwealth prosecuting agencies preventing any wider dissemination of the material so obtained.

The Cabinet Office, as a matter of course, provides Commonwealth prosecutors with access to requested Cabinet documents relevant to particular prosecutions. This access is provided on a confidential basis, and the procedure was followed in the Midford Paramount case. Should the Director of Public Prosecutions require an appropriately secured copy of a relevant Cabinet document for use in his or her office for a time, the Cabinet Office could provide the copy.
This recommendation is sufficiently met by current procedures.
77The Cabinet documents pertaining to the Midford case be released into the public domain.

In the circumstances of three of the Cabinet documents having come into the public domain by order of the Magistrates Court, those documents are no longer regarded as being appropriate for the requirement of confidentiality. Other Cabinet documents should be governed by the conventions of confidentiality which apply to those documents and which would make them subject to release to the public only after 30 years, under the provisions of the Archives Act 1983.

All governments in Australia, both Federal and State, and all nations with a similar system of government observe the convention that confidentiality properly attaches to the deliberations of Ministers in Cabinet. The convention recognises that it is necessary that there be a forum (Cabinet) in which full and frank discussions by Ministers can take place, uninhibited by the need to temper debate to meet sectional interests or media pressures, and in which individual opinions may be expressed freely among colleagues without public comment and exposure. If this were not so, the effectiveness of the policy making process (and therefore of government) would be significantly impaired. The High Court gave independent confirmation to the importance of the convention of confidentiality for Cabinet deliberations in its 1992 judgement in the Northern Land Council case.

A further reason for maintaining the confidentiality of Cabinet deliberations is that such confidentiality is necessary for the preservation of the principle of collective responsibility which requires that decisions, once arrived at in Cabinet, be supported by all Ministers whatever their personal views or the arguments they had put forward in Cabinet.
In relation to Cabinet documents not covered by the order of the Magistrates Court, this recommendation is rejected.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) for his response on behalf of the government, being a response to the outstanding recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, report No. 325, regarding the Midford Paramount case. Throughout that two-year inquiry, I was the deputy chairman. I must say I was somewhat ashamed of the treatment by a department of state of individuals and the harassment that followed.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators would be aware that this response arises out of a failed prosecution by the DPP, and that the case was subsequently dropped. Arising from that, and from questions asked in the valuable Senate estimates committee process, the issue was taken up by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which, over a two-year period, examined the matter in great detail. A great majority of the recommendations were accepted by the government. However, the $25 million in compensation was a small price having regard to the suffering of individuals and the loss of the businesses involved. We hope that, because of this particular case and report, such things will never happen again.

Officers within the departments of state have a great deal of power. The abuse of that power is a matter of concern to this parliament. It is appropriate and significant that we do have these sorts of inquiry mechanisms to act as a check and a balance.

A disturbing feature that has come out of this inquiry arises from certain comments made by the chairman at the time, Mr Punch, when he indicated that Customs' handling of the investigation into the shirt manufacturer was, at best, incompetent or, at worst, conspiratorial and deceitful. Therefore, it came as something of a surprise that when Mr Kelly, the head of Customs, handed in his resignation, he was given another job on the same salary. The feeling in the outside world is that that could never have happened in business. Why should the taxpayers have to pay this price, when there is overwhelming evidence in terms of difficulties, maladministration and incompetence?

The participants in this inquiry, particularly those who are the recipients of the benefit, will be ever grateful for the attitude taken by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, because without that inquiry this compensation would never have come to hand. I note that Senator Schacht is in the chamber. I would like to pay a tribute to him for the inquiry he instigated and the calibre of the people who were appointed to the committee that made its investigation. I now look forward to the report of that committee in the long term, and to the government acting on those recommendations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I did not hear all of Senator Watson's remarks, as I have only just entered the chamber. The government's supplementary response to the outstanding recommendations of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the Midford Paramount case has now been tabled. There is still one recommendation to be dealt with, that is, the joint committee's recommendation that the Comptroller-General of Customs report to it about the positions now held by various officers in Customs who were involved in the Midford case. That is still being dealt with, and a report will be forwarded to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the very near future. The government itself has asked for a report on the circumstances of the positions held by officers in Customs who were involved in the Midford matter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson may appreciate that tomorrow, at the hearing of the supplementary estimates committee that covers my department, approval will be sought for the allocation of money to pay the $25 million in compensation. During the estimates committee hearing some people will obviously ask further questions; I would be staggered if they did not. Other questions will be asked, I suspect, in view of present debates in the Senate and elsewhere about the Conroy review and its recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you be disappointed if they weren't?

—In a sense of expectation, Senator Harradine, it would be almost anticlimactic for me not to have questions asked because, as one would imagine, a considerable amount of my time and energy as minister with responsibility for Customs is being taken up in handling the aftermath of Midford and the recommendations of the Conroy review. For example, since the report of the review was tabled just over two weeks ago, I have had meetings with SES level staff of Customs here in Canberra. I met all the state collectors, as they are called.

PARA.TAB: In the last week I have also attended meetings of general staff in Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane and Adelaide. Some of those meetings were attended by up to 400 or 500 staff members. I have discussed with them the Conroy review and its recommendations. I pointed out to them, as I have to the parliament, that I accept the general thrust of the Conroy review, but I am taking under consideration all specific recommendations. I have also made it clear, not only to senior management of Customs, but right through the service, down to the most lowly position, that I want all of them to participate in a consultative process with management regarding how they respond to the thrust of the Conroy recommendations. I have said to them, as I have said publicly, that we will get major change in the culture of Customs only if it is driven from the bottom up. We will not get the change that I think the parliament desires vis-a-vis the Midford report and so on if it is driven only from the top down.

I am reasonably optimistic, after having these meetings with a total of well over 1,000 staff across four different states, that there is, amongst many of those staff, a real willingness to get on with the job of accepting the need for change and reform in Customs. They may disagree with individual recommendations, as is only natural, but they do understand that there is great concern in the parliament, the government and the community about the performance of Customs with regard to the Midford debacle.

I will continue those consultations and meetings with the general staff. I have already had meetings with union representatives in Customs. I have met with representatives of the PSU at both the officials level and the job delegate level, and those meetings will continue.

I have emphasised to senior management of Customs that the consultation process for all staff is to be open, transparent and vigorous and that there is to be no sense of people not being encouraged or feeling inclined to censor themselves at the officer level about their contribution and comment in response to the Conroy review. I believe that if that takes place, it will be the first step towards getting a culture change in Customs so that staff at all levels throughout the organisation will have a sense of participation in and constructive contribution to the management and a sense of ownership about the changed process.

I appreciate Senator Watson's kind remarks about the review committee. I think it was a very well-balanced committee in relation to the background of the people involved and that is reflected in the report. Even if we might not accept every one of the committee's recommendations, the thrust of the report is in the right area.

When I get the considered responses from Customs and other government departments and prepare a submission—I hope I will be able to do that within six to eight weeks—I will take it to cabinet to get authority on the way we will restructure Customs and deal with those issues. Therefore, I will be able to make an appropriate statement at that time which will include, I trust, a timetable for dealing with the change in the structure and legislative requirements. It is quite clear that, if we make any move to change the structure of Customs, it will require legislative action. I am aware, as are other honourable senators, of the very heavy government business agenda over this year, but I hope that legislation can be introduced this year to give effect to the reform process.

I emphasise again that, whilst I have not yet accepted or rejected any of the specific recommendations, I do accept the general thrust of them. So far, I have been more than encouraged by the response of the staff of Customs. Though they have many concerns about some of the recommendations, they understand the need for change and want to get on with the job of being a top-class service to the Australian public. I appreciate Senator Watson's remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Women's Action Alliance (Australia) Inc.
7 April 1993
Hon. Paul Keating,
Prime Minister,
Parliament House,
Canberra. A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Keating,
Women's Action Alliance would like to extend to you and to all in the government congratulations on your success in the recent election and best wishes for a fruitful term ahead.

We also congratulate you on converting the Dependent Spouse Rebate to a direct payment to women who are caring for children at home. Women's Action Alliance has called for this measure since our inception in 1975 because in your own words it will "recognize the important role played by women who choose to stay at home while their children are growing up". This is an important breakthrough for-those women because for too long they have been defined as out of the `workforce' when in fact they are performing vital work in our society.

The ending of the reduced level of fee relief which applied to occasional care is also welcome as it disadvantaged those women not employed in paid work—in many cases the very women who could least afford the higher fee.

However, the DSR was introduced as a recognition of the living costs of the non earning spouse. It was never intended as a child care payment. The one income family incurs child care costs these being the totality of its foregone second income. Women in the paid workforce are not required to surrender their tax free threshold to become eligible for the new child care rebates but women at home have virtually had their DSR removed in order to fund the Home Child Care Allowance.

It is unfortunate, too, that the increase of $150 in the Dependent Spouse Rebate, now to be called the Home Child Care Allowance, compares so unfavourably with the assistance extended to women in paid work via child care fee relief and the new cash rebate. We understand that, under the new arrangements, it will be possible for a mother with two pre-school children in care to receive up to $63 per week extra no matter how high her income while a mother at home caring for her two pre-schoolers will receive only $2.88 per week extra no matter how low her income. Can you confirm that this is the case?

As the new child care rebate is to have no means test at all why is it that the Home Child Care Allowance is to have one applied at a level as low as $282? These features of the child care funding arrangements seem divisive and do not sit easily with the concept of One Nation and Labor's ongoing `quest for social equity' of which you spoke in the policy speech.

Mr. Staples when introducing the review of the government's Children's Services Program last year said that the primary objective of the program was to "support labour market participation by parents with young children" and in your policy speech at Bankstown prior to the election you referred to women's participation in the workforce being required for the future growth of the economy and to maintain living standards. Women's Action Alliance feels that the primary objective of child care programs should have something to do with the welfare of children and fears that little children will become the pawns in the service of the economy and of employers' labour requirements instead of being given stability and the best possible care which, we are sure you would agree, is provided by their parents.

Surely our standard of living has dropped if it requires one and a half or two incomes to feed and clothe a family and service a mortgage today while our parents were able to manage on the income from one 40 hour per week job. This change has meant that an increasing number of women have had little choice about their lifestyles and have been denied the choice to be with their children full time in their early years.

The government spends large amounts to enable other dependent people such as the elderly and the physically and mentally disabled to be cared for at home. It would therefore seem illogical to heavily subsidize the transfer of young children from home to substitute care especially when the best research available from the Australian Institute of Family Studies shows that 62% of parents of preschoolers would prefer the mother to be at home full time.
Women's Action Alliance believes that:

1.The Home Child Care Allowance should be increased to a level where it equates the tax advantage gained by having access to two tax free thresholds. Currently this would mean increasing the previous DSR level by $640 pa. rather than by $150 pa. In the long term all workers, paid and unpaid should receive a tax free threshold in their own right and child care payments should become a separate item.
2.The means testing of the Home Child Care' Allowance in the hands of the dependent spouse at $282.00.pa. should be abolished in line with the absence of a means test on the new child care rebate.

PARA.TAB: or

SPEECH.PARA: 3.The new Child Care Rebate payable to women in paid work should be means tested and the funds thus saved be equitably distributed to all families with children.
4.While the Home Child Care Allowance retains some of the functions of the old DSR it should continue to be paid out via the tax system as it is in fact a tax rebate.
It is not special treatment that we seek for women at home but merely equal treatment so that the aim of the National Agenda for Women to offer women a choice, a say and a fair go will be achieved.
In summary could you please answer the following queries for us—
(1)Do you agree with Mr. Staples' statement regarding the primary objective of the Children's Services Program?
(2)Could you please explain the rationale behind the disparity between the funding support to parental child care as compared with alternative care.
Yours sincerely,
Pauline Smit
National Secretary
Women's Action Alliance (Australia) Inc.
8 February 1994
Senator Brian Harradine,
GPO Box 8961,
HOBART TAS. 7001
Dear Senator Harradine.

We understand that the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill has now passed through the House of Representatives and has been referred to the Senate Committee on Community Affairs.

The two accompanying letters which we have sent to the Prime Minister and other Federal Members, plus our recent submission to the Australian Law Reform Commission, cover most of our concerns regarding the proposed Home Child Care Allowance.

Having read the Bill, we believe that the "ordinary income free area" (Page 11, Division 5, Section 927) should be raised to the level of the tax free threshold. Failing this, it should at least be indexed. This level has not been raised for many years and allows a current Dependent Spouse Rebate recipient the magnificent sum of $5. 40 income per week before the rebate starts to cut out.
Ideally, for equity reasons, we believe that the Home Child Care Allowance should not be means tested, as is the case with the new Child Care Rebates.

There is considerable discrimination in the handling of women's choice in the Home Child Care Allowance, compared with the new Child Care Rebates. We believe the following matters need to be addressed:
(1)Gross disparity in the level of payment.
(2)Means testing of the Home Child Care Allowance in the hands of the recipient—no means test of the Child Care Rebate.

(3)Discrimination in the method of payment. The Home Child Care Allowance to be paid as a welfare payment—the Child Care Rebate to be paid via the Children's Services Program and redeemable at Medicare Offices. (This is insulting to women in the unpaid workforce and makes the allowance vulnerable to means or assets testing at the whim of Governments).

The A.C.T.U. at its most recent National Convention adopted a policy that the Home Child Care Allowance should increase in amount with the number of dependent children. This too would be consistent with the arrangements for the Child Care Rebates as those using non parental outside child care can qualify for a rebate of up to $28 for one child and $61 for two, whereas Home Child Care Allowance recipients will receive only $30 per week no matter how many children they are caring for.

The enclosed material will at least provide some ideas that you may think worth including in the debate, as the Government certainly needs to be challenged to explain why it treats one type of family so shabbily, while treating another so handsomely when it comes to supporting the model of child care they choose. In its rhetoric surrounding International Year of the Family, the Government purports not to favour one family model over another, yet here we see actions which fairly blatantly contradict that claim.
Yours faithfully,
Pauline Smit (Mrs.),
NATIONAL SECRETARY.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also sorry that the Australian Democrats are not here because I think it is important for them to understand what is happening with this particular measure, particularly in relation to some of what I believe to be the unintended consequences. Before I get on to them, I wish to give the chamber an example of how this measure discriminates against mothers—or fathers, for that matter—caring for their children at home compared with those who put their children into institutional care. The Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill will result in the following: as we know, under the Child Care Rebate Bill, which was presented to the parliament by the government, a double income couple with each partner on $20,000 per year with two children in child care get $61.20 per week through the child-care cash rebate scheme plus the low income rebate of $150 each—that is, a family on $40,000 is getting $300 per annum plus $61.20 per week.

PARA.TAB: We should compare that with what the government is doing in the case of families where one parent is caring for a child or children at home. A one income family on $25,000—$15,000 per year less than the family I have just described—with two children at home gets no low income rebate to offset the indirect tax increases and gets a mere $2.60 per week towards caring for its children. How can that be justified? That is a clear case of discrimination against such a family.

A family with two incomes—a family on $40,000 a year—can receive an extra $300 per annum with the low income tax rebate plus $61.20 a week while a one income family on $25,000 a year—$15,000 less—with the same number of children is discriminated against. That family receives no low income rebate and a mere $2.60 a week. I want the Democrats to hear that. Can they justify it? How can the government justify that sort of discrimination? It is a disgrace.

There are consequences—probably unintended—to this bill which need to be looked at. In fact, they constitute the reason for this legislation needing amendment. To begin with, the home child-care allowance will not be available where a child is a student over 16 or living outside Australia. That has been pointed out by other speakers in the debate here and by Mr Ruddock in the House of Representatives. Since the existing dependent spouse rebate is available in all of those cases, families will be worse off as a result of this measure. Did the government realise that? If it did, it did not tell those families—certainly not before the election.

If a family has a student child on Austudy, it receives the spouse rebate of $1,425. Why should it now lose $237 by being cut from HCCA down to the spouse rebate rate payable to a childless couple? Does a child cost $237 less once it becomes a student? Do the parents of that child pay less in indirect taxes in respect of the food and services purchased? At the moment, couples with student children up to the age of 25 get a spouse rebate of $1,425. With this bill, they are denied the home child-care allowance once the last child is over 16 and leaves school or turns 18.

Some years ago—I hope the Democrats are listening because they will see how unjust this is—the government abolished the dole for 16-year-olds on the basis that their parents, not the taxpayers, should look after them. Now it is saying that those children do not even exist for the purposes of a home child-care allowance. However, should parents kick their child out because they are too broke to pay the bills any more, the government will fork out the young homeless allowance. So much for looking after families, so much for care; that is what this bill does. In those respects, it is a no care bill. While I hope that those consequences are unintended, amendments need to be made to overcome them.

As has already been mentioned in this debate, it is quite common for Australians to be posted overseas for a period while remaining legal residents of Australia and paying full Australian taxes. The examples are endless: diplomats, soldiers, business people, and missionaries. At the moment, they receive the higher level of this spouse rebate of $1,425 where there are children. Now they will have $237 ripped off them. Why is that? The government has not explained it. Why is it that a family cannot go overseas for more than 13 weeks? Why is it that a family cannot leave a child overseas with a relative for a few months to complete a year of schooling while the rest of the family, in the case of diplomatic service, returns from a posting to Australia? What legitimate reason does the government have for using this measure—the so-called home child care—to rip off those families?

The home child-care allowance is not really $1,560, as the government has suggested. The dependent spouse rebate, which remains for childless couples, is $1,188. The existing dependent spouse rebate for those with children is $1,425. So the net increase is a mere $135—$2.60 a week. I correct what I said before lunch. Before lunch it was $2.85, so it has gone down by 25c to a mere $2.60 per week. That is an insult. Most women—or men—at home are staggered to know that the government thinks they are worth only an extra $2.60 a week for raising the Treasury's future taxpayers.

I have pointed out the inconsistencies contained in this measure—the discrimination meted out to parents who are caring for their families at home. Other low income earners receive a $150 rebate to compensate for the indirect tax increases announced in last year's budget; dependent spouses get nothing. I want the Democrats to understand that. The $135 so-called increase is really a decrease when one allows for the increased indirect tax burden on one income families. The home child-care allowance does not allow for the number of dependent children, unlike the child care rebate scheme which increases to a maximum $61.20 for two or more children. Any logical system of child-care assistance should increase according to the number of dependent children.

This bill should be revised and revamped. If we are to have justice, the home child-care allowance should be calculated by adding the low income rebate of $150 to the basic spouse rebate of $1,188, giving a basic amount of $1,388 per annum, and to that should be added the sum of $30 per week.

I am not proposing to push that by way of amendment. However, I believe that some of the anomalies that have been pointed out should be subject to amendment. Once this legislation is put into effect, workers are going to be knocked off. Workers will think, in effect, that their wage rates have been cut. Then a cheque will come in the post to parents who are caring for their children at home. They will work it out. They will say, `We are worth $2.60, and it is from the Department of Social Security'. That amount is going to be targeted in future because in this bill the means test is much harsher than it is in respect of the dependent spouse rebate. That is another anomaly that needs to be attended to. All of these matters need to have proper examination.

I do not deny that there is a need to make sure that the money gets into the pocket of the carer. That was my view as well in respect of the tax concession for children, but we have seen what happened to that. Unfortunately, it has been eroded over time, and I believe the same could well occur in this case. The amount has to be adjusted realistically. This discrimination against parents who care for their children at home must be reversed.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I want to make a few remarks about the position that the Australian Democrats have taken on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill. The Democrats have refused to support the coalition's sensible approach to handling the anomalies which have already been brought to our attention. Senator Harradine has in some detail gone over some of those anomalies. From what he has said, I am sure he would support our move to delay the committee stage of this bill so that some of the anomalies that have already come to light can be dealt with by way of amendment.

PARA.TAB: Earlier today Senator Patterson moved an amendment to delay consideration of the bill in the committee stage until these anomalies can be dealt with by way of amendment. The Democrats have said it is urgent that the bill be passed today. However, we can see no reason why this should happen. The start-up date of the legislation will not be until September 1994, so there is a great deal of time for the legislature to deal with the anomalies. We have already raised quite a number of the anomalies about which we are all concerned. One would think that the Democrats and the Greens in particular would have some specific concerns about some of them.

I certainly hope that Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts are listening to this debate, even though I would not want to inflict myself too heavily on them. Groups such as World Vision, with which I am sure the Greens and the Democrats would have some empathy, have already raised concerns about the impact this bill will have on their aid workers overseas who work for the good of humanity. As Senator Harradine has said, they will be very badly affected by the provisions of this bill. Parents who work for a range of international aid organisations will be badly affected by the provisions of this home child-care bill.

Individuals who work for Care Australia and other good Australian and international aid organisations that provide assistance, particularly in Third World countries, and who commit their lives and time, often for relatively low amounts of remuneration, will be affected by the provisions of this bill. That is only one area that certainly needs to be addressed by amendments. I cannot see why the Democrats—and I presume the Greens—are so keen to see this bill pushed through.

I should mention the approach that Senator Denman took in this debate. I think Senator Harradine has already raised what a sick and sad joke this $2.60 a week support is for home child carers. When doorknocking during the last federal election, I took a particular interest in the electorate of Canning—an area in which a lot of average Australians are struggling to look after their children. I would see 100 people a day while doorknocking and one of the issues that came up all the time was assistance to single income families with children. I was told that all of the assistance went to people who had two incomes—and, of course, people who have two incomes are better off financially. Clearly, this would have been shown in the polling that the government had conducted. Of course, the promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his election speech of $30 assistance to people at home had a tremendous electoral impact. It really was an election gimmick. But sadly, like just about every other promise made during that election campaign, one had to read the fine print.

If Mr Keating is still the Prime Minister at the next election and Mr Crean has not knifed him in the back and taken over by then, which I am sure is what he intends doing—and I predict that Mr Keating will not be the Prime Minister because he will become so unpopular—or, indeed, if Mr Crean is the Prime Minister because people like Senator Gareth Evans and Co. back his leadership push, we should insist that the leader of the Labor Party, whoever it is, provides an appendix to the policy speech with all the fine print, all the `cross your fingers stuff' such as the promise of $30 by Mr Keating. But people will not get $3 or even, as Senator Denman said, $6 a fortnight.

All of a sudden Senator Denman has increased the amount from $5.20 to $6 a fortnight, so we had better watch what she says. She has misled the Senate by saying it is $6 a fortnight, so we are being misled again by another Labor Party senator. We can check Hansard on that. Even that is a sick joke; it is an absolute insult to mothers who stay at home and look after their children. But the reality is, as Senator Harradine said in his speech, that it is actually $2.60 a week. That is the value. They were promised $30 a week by the Prime Minister. Electors in marginal seats who were sitting at home watching the television and trying to make up their minds on how to vote would have seen this promise of $30 a week and said, `My God, the government has finally recognised the value of my work. They will give $30 a week in assistance'. But, of course, the reality is, as has been explained over and over again in this debate, that it is $2.60 additional assistance. As Senator Harradine and a number of other speakers have said, it is far more tightly targeted. All sorts of anomalies arise in relation to people working overseas and people in other sorts of categories.

It is also worth looking at the plight of families on average earnings in terms of the present taxation system. An interesting study carried out by the OECD was reported in the 4 December edition of the Economist. This study compares the taxation circumstances of two-child families earning, as the OECD calls it, average manufacturing wages. That is a category that would include a lot of average Australians—the sort of people who will have seen that promise of $30 a week in the Prime Minister's policy speech and who will receive only $2.60 when this bill goes through with the assistance of the Democrats and, possibly, the Greens. They are so keen to see it go through today that they will not even allow some sensible consideration of the bill at the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think the Greens want it through today.

—If they do not, I stand corrected. I have not heard their position. I am glad that the Greens may well be supporting our move to have a sensible consideration of possible amendments at the committee stage. I hope that is right, Senator Harradine. I am sure the Greens will let us know.

PARA.TAB: I will not seek leave to incorporate this table because the quality is probably not good enough for publication in Hansard. It is fascinating to study an analysis of OECD direct taxes, which we know are high in this country, covering an average two-child family earning average wages. It shows that Australian families suffer some of the highest rates of taxation in the Western world.

The Prime Minister when on roster in Parliament on Monday—he has had a couple of RDOs since then—told members of the other place, and anyone who was listening in, that Australia was a low tax country. And today we had all this debate about the burden of taxation. The burden of taxation as a percentage of GDP is a statistic that actually does not affect the lives of average Australians very much. It certainly does not affect the lives of wealthy people who have investments in things like piggeries and can claim massive depreciation and massive write-offs. It certainly does not affect the lives of those who can invest money for tax free capital gains in things like antique French clocks. But it does affect people who live in suburban Australia, who have a couple of kids and who have only one income. These are the sorts of people whom this study affects and it shows how income tax falls on them in comparison to some of our friends and neighbours around the world.

Australian families face higher tax rates than families in Norway, Ireland, Italy, Britain, Canada, Belgium, the United States of America, Holland, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, Spain, Japan, Portugal, France and Luxembourg.
