I reiterate, at the threat of boring the chamber, that this is a study of average families across the world which have two kids and an average manufacturing salary—the sorts of people who need the most assistance through home care, taxation and social security. The only countries that have higher tax rates on families are—and this is no surprise—Denmark, Sweden, Finland and New Zealand. Out of the OECD, four nations beat us. So this is the burden of the tax system falling on these average families.

We have a Labor government that keeps insisting in this International Year of the Family that it is helping families. We must remember that in the International Year of Indigenous People, the Labor government passed the Native Title Bill which will do more damage to the Aboriginal cause in Australia than anything that has happened in 20 years of recent history. In the International Year of the Family the best thing the Labor government can come up with is $2.60 a week. As a number of colleagues have said, it is an absolute disgrace.

It is more disgraceful that the Democrats have said, `This bill has to go through today'. We cannot have any sensible consideration of possible amendments to overcome anomalies in it because we have to get it through today. Like the Native Title Bill, a disgraceful piece of legislation that will ruin the lives of Aboriginals and Australia's economic development, here we have the Democrats doing it again. The attitude is, `Let's get the bill through today. Let's not have consideration of sensible amendments. Let's not allow the opposition and people like Senator Harradine a bit of time to put some sensible amendments together to make this a better bill'.

We must remember that the report on this bill by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which contained a minority report, was tabled only a couple of days ago. In the building today and in the gallery this afternoon we had former Senator Chipp, the founder of the Democrats—a man for whom I had enormous respect in the years that he set up the Democrats and who put into the Australian political lexicon the words, `Keep the bastards honest'. Here we have a government that has deceived the people and deceived Australian families into voting for the Labor Party—costing the Liberal-National party coalition the seats of Canning and Swan. That was based on the sorts of deceits we have seen in the sports rorts affair and this promise about $30. Yet the Democrats are not even prepared to allow honourable senators to come up with sensible amendments for consideration by committee.

It is a great shame that the Democrats have become so much a part of slick, political deal making. I have respect for many members of the Democrats, and Senator Lees is one of them. The Senate can be a very positive place for legislation if honourable senators do not get tied up in the slick political process which the Democrats, particularly under the leadership of Senator Kernot, seem to be embracing. There is absolutely no need for this legislation to be rushed through. There is no need for the committee stage to be dealt with straightaway. We plead for some time to put together some sensible amendments to overcome these anomalies. That will take time. It cannot be done in an afternoon or a night, as was done with the stupid amendments that were put up to the Mabo bill. It needs to be done so that we can look at the consequences, unintended or otherwise, and deal with them properly.

I plead with the Democrats to be more constructive and positive in their approach to this bill and to support Senator Patterson's most sensible amendment which would delay the consideration of the bill in the committee stage until amendments can be brought forward.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell referred to me and suggested that in some way I had made some sort of a slick deal with the government. I can assure him that is not the case. Indeed, I have not even discussed with the government these amendments that were put before us by the Liberal Party, as they came at such short notice. I did not see them until I arrived in this chamber this morning. I want to make it very clear to Senator Campbell that presumably we are to have a new pattern of behaviour by the Liberal Party which, it seems, is calling upon the government to make amendments for the Liberal Party.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order. I did not object to leave being granted to Senator Lees to make a personal explanation. However, I think she is now debating the issue. If she has not spoken already, I am sure she can put her name on the speakers list and put all those points at the right time.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Lees, would you please confine your remarks very strictly to where you have been misrepresented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order. This may be a debating point, and if it is I will speak after Senator Lees. I certainly made no reflection on Senator Lees. I made a reflection on the tendency of the Democrats as a party to become part of slick, political deal making. There was absolutely no reflection on Senator Lees personally whatsoever.
—There is no point of order, Senator Campbell.

—It certainly was a reflection because I was the one who was handling this bill. No other member of my party has been involved in any way in the dealings on this bill other than through consultation. So it is very much a personal reflection on me and I take it as such. I again stress that these amendments are late. This bill has been before us for weeks. It was in committee stage the week before last. There has been plenty of opportunity for the Liberal Party to have amendments drawn up if it is so wished. It cannot in any way blame the passage of this bill today on the Democrats.
—I seek leave to make a statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I want to make a personal statement in respect of the comment made by Senator Lees. The report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was only tabled in the Senate on Monday.
—That is right. We have had two full days.

—Well, we have had two full days. As an Independent, I have a whole range of matters to attend to, and I hope Senator Lees understands that because she and her colleagues are in a similar position. On two occasions I had sought discussions with Senator Lees, and there has been no real reaction to that.

PARA.TAB: I am now actually getting amendments prepared so they can be circulated. Senator Lees should know what those amendments will be, having read the report of the standing committee and having heard what I have said. I hope that they will be here in time. If not, I hope that people will vote for Senator Patterson's amendment; that is, to defer the bill and to get the government to look at it. I hope that if it does not come up with amendments to overcome what I believe are unintended consequences—I hope they are unintended—my amendments will be prepared by that time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to comment on this matter, as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in any way reflecting on Senator Harradine. This is the first time I have heard that he is indeed drawing up amendments. I am commenting on what Senator Campbell said previously about the Australian Democrats and the government.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Lees has sought leave to claim she has been misrepresented by Senator Harradine. She is certainly not doing that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Lees saying that Senator Harradine misrepresented her? She has just said that he is not, so Senator Lees should sit down and get on with it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—What is the point of your personal explanation, Senator Lees?

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is that I was in no way reflecting on Senator Harradine or his amendments. I do not believe that it is fair of him to make comments to the effect that in some way the Democrats are preventing Senator Harradine from moving amendments. We are certainly not doing that.

—I congratulate Senator Campbell who gave a very good delivery, considering I agreed to let him go ahead of me if he spoke for only two minutes. I would say that in the six-and-a-half years that I have been in this place, this is definitely the first social security bill that I have ever spoken on; but for the people who think I am softening, a tax bill will come with it later to remove that spouse rebate for those with children. So I feel free to speak on the legislation.

PARA.TAB: But I speak for other reasons as well. I do believe that this was a two-card trick during the last election. I can remember Senator Crowley, I think as minister at the time, making a big deal during the election about this $30 that was going to be handed out to carers at home. I used to yell out across the chamber to the honourable senator and say, `Tell us about the spouse rebate with children and how it is going to disappear', but she would never take up my invitation.

So I invite Senator Crowley to explain, when she sums up, why she did not tell us during the election that that was going to be removed as well. We read the fine print somewhere along the line. I do not know how long it took to get through, but I did a lot of doorknocking around the place, as did Senator Campbell—only I was in the seat of Brand. It was brought up time and again that this government was going to throw around $30—just like that. There was no mention of taking it off the spouse rebate.

This allowance will replace that dependent spouse rebate, and it is available to couples with children, and at a maximum rate of $1,560 a year—if I have read it correctly. This will not have an effect on couples with no children. They can still claim the spouse rebate. I hurriedly rang home to check our wages books. The rebate, I believe—there are other figures quoted—is $27.10 for a married couple with children, and $22.50 for a married couple with no children. By my calculations it means an extra $2.90 to the child via the social security office. I will come back to that later on. The administration there is going to take away far more than that.

The main reason that I speak in this debate is the effect that it will have on employers, and especially small employers, say with five, six or seven employees. I will explain later why I have used those figures. This is only the bill to set up the mechanism to pay this child-care home allowance. The taxation amendment bill to deal with the levy will come later.

I was wondering whether the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has given much thought to the fact that a lot of couples with children are quite happy with the present situation. Most of them have never had anything to do with the Department of Social Security or the social security office. A lot of them do not want to have anything to do with it, because when they go around to the social security office they feel as if they are being pushed into the social welfare state.

I believe that whatever they did they would be pushed into that situation. As far as I am concerned, the people who have had nothing to do with social security or social welfare will create some problems. I can see problems coming—Senator Harradine mentioned this on the way through—for employers with five or seven employees, as I have. Such employers are very close to the employees. As Senator Harradine said, in September—not the last Saturday in September, an earlier one—those with children, on my figures, will get $27 a week less. It will not affect those with no children. There is no argument about it.

Those people affected will say, `Where is the rest of my wages?' That question will certainly come. I will have to say, `Your wife, or whoever is the carer, will have to go to the social security office and get that'. They will say, `No, I want it from you. I work for you; you should give it to me'. I will say, `No, you have to go down to the social security office'.

The demand will come; they will say, `No, I want it from you'. All I can advise these employees to do is to fill out a spouse rebate form without including children. There is nothing wrong with that. Then they would still get the rebate of $22.50. Then muggins here, to keep the peace in the camp, will have to put the balance in. So there will be a demand in increased wages, and the best that I can make of it will be to make up the difference, which is $5—less 40 cents—on my figures. That is the best that I and most employers will be able to get out of it.

Then there is the other situation. If the wife can go to the social security office and pick up that $30, the employees can and will legitimately say—and I wish the minister would listen to this because even if the minister does not employ people, others do; and these problems will arise—`No, the government gave me that. It promised that $30 to me during the election. The government said nothing about taking the spouse rebate away—that is correct. They will say, `The social security office gave me that $30. That is mine. That is my wife's. You have to give me the same wages'. In that case there will be a demand for increased wages of $27. Most of us who have employed people know that is going to happen.

I would like to hear the minister's explanation on that. If the bill is taken seriously at face value and people do get that extra $2, that is an insult and a joke. I know there will be recipients who are not already in the system and getting it, but they could have been dealt with in a different way. The ones who want to go along with the scheme will accept the fact that they will lose their spouse rebate of $27.10 and the wife will go to the social security office and get $2.90—and look at the extra amount of administration that will involve, rather than having the employer pick up the administration costs. I believe that the government sold us a pup—not me, but the rest of the community in Australia—in the last election.

This is only the bill setting up the scheme. When the tax amendment bill is put into action, and the levy is taken away, the government will have to think very seriously about it. The minister has disappeared again and is not listening; her advisers can probably listen and take the point. I believe that if an employee and his spouse both agree that they want to remain in the same system they should be given the option to do so and still get the spouse and children rebate of $27.10. As I said, I have employees with no children who already get $22.50 and for whom it will remain the same. They have no option. I believe that if the government is dinkum in what it is doing it will give the option to remain as they are to the people who are happy with the situation.

I know that there are cases where the husband picks up the pay and he might not pass enough to the wife—although these days most of the average pay packet goes to keeping the household and there is nothing left over for anything else. I know there are deserving cases. But where the couples are happy with the present situation, if the wife wants to stay away from the social security office and the husband does not particularly want his wife receiving social security, they should be given that option. I want the minister to take that on board. Even though she is not listening, perhaps someone else is.Senator Chris Evans might like to comment on his idea when he speaks.

In conclusion, I question the financial impact that is given in the explanatory memorandum. It says that the estimated total outlays for these measures is $4.25 million in 1993-94—it seems a bit low to me—$576.06 million in 1994-95 and $346.49 million in 1995-96. It mentions that the outlay is an extra $230 million in total. I would like the government to explain whether it has allowed for what it will forgo in tax with the spouse rebate to tie these figures up. If not, would it give the total figures? I want to know the balances and the credits.

Like other honourable senators, I ask the Democrats and the Greens, who are having a private conversation with the minister, why they think that we cannot wait another week or so to put this bill through. There are plenty of reasons from Senator Harradine, Senator Campbell, Senator Paterson and others who have spoken on this bill as to why we should suspend it for a week. It does not start until September, and there is plenty of time. After all, the tax bill which will provide the money and take away the levy is nowhere in sight. If that had already gone through and we were just waiting for this bill to fire up and get everything going, I would agree. But this bill is useless without the tax amendment bill to come with it. I cannot see that the Democrats have a valid reason—I do not know what the position is of the Greens—for not postponing the bill until we can look at it properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in rising to support the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. I do so because one feature of this legislation is that it fulfils exactly an election promise made during the last federal election.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to hear the criticisms from those opposite regarding this legislation because they are usually haranguing us for the alleged failure to deliver on election promises. But this is in fact the government delivering on the promise we made prior to the election. It is also a further plank in the government's family policies. It is but one plank in a whole range of measures designed to assist families and not a measure to be looked at in isolation. I think that is one of my main concerns with the way some of the other speakers have addressed this debate.

Importantly, it also marks a philosophical change in the approach to providing support for carers of children in non-paid employment. It is a recognition of home care as work and is a payment direct to the carer. It is a recognition by society of the importance of that work and the contribution to society of carers and, therefore, it marks an important philosophical change in the approach reflected in this legislation. As I understand it, that general philosophical approach is endorsed by all groups, but the opposition's arguments tend to go more to questions of detail.

The detail of the legislation has been adequately canvassed. I do not intend to go chapter and verse through what the bill achieves, but I do want to comment on a number of the key issues and address some of the criticisms and concerns that have been raised both in this debate today and by members of the community. The first point I want to make is that the bill will increase the total payments made to families. There has been some suggestion that somehow this measure is revenue neutral. That is just not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you said during the election.

—No, what we said was that this measure replaces the dependent spouse rebate and provides for an increase in the total payment. The total payment increase quantum has been argued about today. Whether it is $5.90 or $5.60 a fortnight—I do not really want to get into the semantics of that—it is not a revenue neutral measure. It is an increase in the payments made to families which we believe will cost the government approximately $230 million per year. So there is a net increase of $230 million a year being paid to families.

PARA.TAB: People have found it easy to ridicule the amount of the extra assistance provided. I think that is a cheap shot. But there are a couple of points I want to make about that. Firstly, the day after the election policy announcement it was made very clear what the real increase was. Suggestions by the opposition that somehow this was another lie, that it lost the election because it was all our fault and that we lied, are just a sign of its own inadequacies. It is nothing to do with the GST; it is nothing to do with the opposition's inadequacies; it is because we lied.

That is a nonsense.I can show those opposite all the editorials and all the comment pieces in the newspapers and on the television, after the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of the policy, that were very keen to point out that the net increase was more in the order of $5 to $6 a fortnight than a full $30. It was well explained and detailed throughout the election campaign. Those opposite cannot hide behind that argument. I am the first to admit that it would be better if we could afford more—if we could pay a greater amount. We are saying that this is an incremental increase that is an improvement on the previous situation and that it will increase the total revenue going to families. It is easy to dismiss it and say it is a sleight of hand and ridicule the amount, but the reality is that it is an increase, it is being targeted to families and it is the start of a whole new approach to the way we direct support to those families.

I was actually quite concerned about the criticisms of the bill raised by the Women's Action Alliance, and I genuinely responded to them. The alliance supported the general thrust of paying the allowance direct to the carer, but raised some concerns, as has been pointed out in the debate, about the approach adopted in the bill. I have satisfied myself that those concerns are not well founded. The mistakes that the Women's Action Alliance made in analysing the bill have been repeated in today's debate by some honourable senators opposite. We have to address some of those concerns and put the whole debate into its proper context.

I have made the point about this measure not being revenue neutral and that there is an increase in funds going to families. There is no doubt that we would prefer to do more, but, as I think Senator Lees made the point quite validly, the debate must be held within the constraints of the whole budget process. We need to find a balance between the competing demands on the taxpayers' dollar and the demands of other people in society who require assistance from the government. All those issues have to be taken into account. The other issue that has to be considered is the question of interaction with wage levels and benefit levels. The whole context has to be examined.

This measure also has to be examined in the context of all government programs. There has been a tendency to pull this legislation out and pretend it is the only government program targeted at families and that it can be examined in isolation. This is quite wrong. The government went to the last election with a range of commitments which have been implemented and a range of continuing policies which go to helping families. They are the taxation policies and the tax cuts which we have delivered on: family payments and the family income supplement, rent assistance, Medicare and a whole range of other social wage policies. If we are going to talk about this measure, it has to be in the context of all those other things that have been done for families. We cannot pull out

SPEECH.PARA: one measure and try to argue about the government's family policy without considering all those things that constitute the whole government approach to providing assistance to families.

PARA.TAB: The other issue that I want to address is means testing. There is a superficial appeal in the Liberal Party's argument about means testing on all these issues, but we really have to work through the implications. Senator Harradine made some comments about the replacement of the DSR that do not tally with the information that I have been provided with about the income test that applies. As I understand it, the income test that applies to the DSR has not been changed and it is reflected in the income test that will be applied to the home care allowance. There is no asset test or income test on the employed spouse. There is an income test on the carer. If we think about it, it is only natural that that be the case because the very character of the home child-care allowance is one designed for those caring for children at home and who are not in paid employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not have one for the child-care rebate?

—I will come to that. I want to make a point about means testing. It is merely a transfer of the DSR income test. The logic of the whole allowance is that it is an allowance for those not in paid employment and who are not earning income from paid employment. If they work, then the allowance is phased out so that if they are earning a reasonable income or reasonable part-time income, they are no longer eligible for the allowance. The whole logic of the allowance is consistent, and the question of income testing of the carer, as I say, is a logical consequence of the whole approach.

PARA.TAB: I do not understand those opposite to be suggesting that the allowance ought to be paid to two-income families at any level of income, but if they oppose the income test, that is the logic of their position. They must then say that it must be paid to two-income families regardless of their income. The other point I wish to make is that the home child-care allowance, like the child-care rebate, does not have an income test on family income. The income test is purely on that of the carer.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not part of the family income? That is splitting hairs, and that is a bit silly.

—Senator Newman has to look at and analyse the whole, not just try to pull out arguments that suit her. What happened here today was an inappropriate comparison with the child-care rebate legislation. Great play has been made of it. People have plucked out the child-care rebate legislation and this home child-care allowance and said, `Direct comparison of the two means you ought to discredit this legislation and the approach by the government is inconsistent'. I reject that because the evidence does not reveal a conflicting approach; they are not directly competing alternatives, and we are not treating families differently, as has been alleged.
—Family A and Family B are treated differently.
—Senator Newman will get her chance to speak after me. Can I speak now?
—Where is your explanation?

—If Senator Newman stops interrupting, I will do my best. I think the opposition's approach is a nonsense. The two pieces of legislation reflect the Labor Party's support for the reality of Australian family life. There are not competing objectives contained in those two pieces of legislation; they are both supporting choices made by Australian families. On the one hand, the child-care rebate legislation seeks to support families who have made a choice to place their children in child care because both parents are earning an income, undertaking training or searching for a job; and, on the other hand, this legislation seeks to support those families which, for whatever reason, have one of the parents or carers at home not in paid employment. They do not reflect competing objectives, they are not conflicting approaches; they are each supporting choices made by Australian families, choices that are the reality of Australian life.

PARA.TAB: For Senator Minchin to say we are pitting mother versus mother and to make those sorts of ludicrous suggestions is really beating up the issue and misrepresenting what is occurring. The reality is that most of the opposition speakers have supported the general approach and they have gone to questions of detail rather than the philosophical approach that underlines our position. Some honourable senators—and I say only some—have reflected a view common in the Liberal Party of opposition to the provision of paid child care and the families which choose to use that option.

A number of points in relation to this comparison argument between the child-care rebate and the home care allowance need to be made. First, the debate has to be put in the context of other measures. The taxation regime, the rent assistance, the family payments, the family income supplements, are all measures that go to supporting families depending on their circumstances, and some of them are income related. We have to look at the whole package provided to families by the measures that government provides, not try to pull out these two separate measures and say, `This is how the government treats families. This is the only thing the government does for families. One family is getting $60 a week and one is getting $30'. It is superficial, it is shallow and it is just not right. We cannot make those direct comparisons because it is a much more complicated picture.
Secondly, the child-care rebate is just that—a rebate. It is paid only to families which pay out more than three times the amount of the rebate in child-care fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good point.

—I thank Senator Crowley. It is a partial reimbursement for the costs incurred in earning an income. It is not an allowance paid; it is a rebate for costs incurred for those families which have to provide child care when both partners are out earning an income. The home child-care allowance is an allowance paid in recognition of the opportunity costs of people not being able to earn an income by virtue of their caring for dependent children. These are two quite different approaches. As I say, to try to make the argument that they are directly comparable is just not correct. Given the history of the DSR and its evolution, it is just not a fair comparison.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to make the point that one of the reasons why the government has adopted a flat amount rather than a per child amount in the payment of the allowance is that it too follows the logic of the allowance. The existing DSR compensates for the opportunity cost of the parent at home at the same rate, whether the parents is caring for one, two, three, four, or however many children. The fact is that that parent is not able to earn an income, and this is in compensation for not being able to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is harder the more you've got.

—I find caring for my one two-year-old more than enough. I would not like to be caring for more children than that. I agree that the costs of caring for and raising more than one child are obviously higher. But the allowance is not a social security payment. It is an allowance made recognising the opportunity costs of the carer's inability to earn income. If people are trying to say that they want a social security measure that addresses the costs of raising children, then that again ought to be adopted or approached through a different avenue.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I think the legislation is a significant step forward in the treatment of these matters. I think it is an important philosophical step that we take and it does start to recognise the role played by carers of children at home who are not able or choose not to go out into the paid work force. This legislation is part of a balanced approach to supporting families and the choices that they are making.

I hope there is general support for the philosophical approach adopted in the bill because I have been a bit concerned by some of the comments made during this debate today. I think there have been a number of issues raised in the debate that are worth considering. I do not think that there is any attempt by the government to rush this through. I am sure all parties are willing to examine arguments that go to making sure that we get good legislation. Some of the arguments raised in the debate really reflect the opposition's difficulties in coming to terms with the reality of Australian society. The government's approach in supporting families and their choice of how they raise and care for their children is the appropriate one. I support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. There has been a great deal of debate on this subject today, and rightly so. It is very important that debate on Australia's families and their needs takes place in the parliament of Australia. I am very glad to hear the previous speaker, Senator Chris Evans, talk about choice. To me, choice is really at the base of the things that we should be doing for families.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker was somewhat misguided in how he reads choice. Perhaps choice is in the eye of the beholder. I recognise that these days—when we educate women to the extent that we do, as compared with past years—it is a case of how we are going to keep them down on the farm now that they have seen Paris. It is inevitable that women will want to be in the work force. They will want to follow careers when they have had a quality education.

They also recognise that with the totally unsatisfactory level of marriage breakup these days, it is good financial management, and good career and life planning, for women to maintain the skills that they may have achieved because they will, only too likely, need them to support themselves and perhaps children too in years to come if they are either widowed or their marriage breaks up. Sadly, that is the reality for far too many people. For other women, there is the need to simply keep the heads of their families above financial water.

People come from their own perspective in this discussion. Sometimes it is from a comfortable middle-class perspective where they have not seen how hard it is for people coping with poverty. Sometimes people come at it from other perspectives. But, whichever perspective we come from, we must acknowledge that parents deserve the right to choose how they will rear their children. That should not be dictated by unacceptable financial pressures. It should be a real choice, not just a choice in name only.

I am concerned that when the government talks about choice, it looks at this in a fairly uncaring sort of a way. I do not think it recognises the reality that so many young parents want to have one parent stay home with their children while they are young. Yet those same young parents are saying, `But we cannot afford it. We would be doing it if we could, but the reality is we cannot afford it'.

Unfortunately, the cashing out of the dependent spouse rebate does nothing to enable those parents, who would like to have one parent staying home with their small children, to make that choice. It is simply the cost of a couple of minor grocery items. It is not even the cost of a packet of cigarettes. I am not suggesting that they should go and spend it on that.

But the reality is that that $2.85 will not do anything for the living standards of the families we are talking about and for whom that second income has become a necessity. Of course, part of the reason it has become a necessity is that the great Australian dream of owning one's home is now so difficult to achieve, especially in some of Australia's cities. Without that second income, it will never be achieved. When a couple have a baby and they are full of joy at the thought of that baby, the next thought that comes into their heads is, `How are we going to cope with the mortgage?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope they plan better than that.

—Unfortunately, they do not always plan as well as Senator Crowley might think they should in a good socialist society. Love comes first and perhaps calculation comes afterwards in a good many families. Maybe it did not come in her's, but it does in plenty of Australian families. But the joy of realising that they are about to become parents can be somewhat tempered, at least, by the reality of how they will survive on one income. All too often young couples with a brand new baby are faced with the reality that they must first of all find child care, then afford child care and then spend the next few years verging on the edge of guilt because they would like to be staying at home with a young baby. As I say, this cashing out of the dependent spouse rebate and turning it into the home child-care allowance will not make the slightest difference to maintaining that mortgage or putting that couple into a different financial position.

PARA.TAB: A number of people have spoken about the financial position of Australian families today and I want to put a few facts on record. It is true to say that the great majority of Australia's families have suffered worsening economic conditions over the past decade. In 1982-83 the income of the top one per cent of income earners equalled the total earnings of the bottom 11 per cent. But by 1988-89 the top one per cent was earning an amount equal to the total incomes of the bottom 21 per cent. That is something to contemplate.

Work by the Social Policy Research Centre has demonstrated that families earning between $20,000 and $40,000 a year have been big losers. They have suffered a 20 per cent drop in their share of national income since 1975. Even the research of the Department of Social Security has shown that, since 1983, a single income couple with two children on average weekly earnings is nearly five per cent worse off. Research studies have shown that there is no net assistance from government to families with dependent children. Families with dependent children enjoy a real standard of living about three-fifths of that of the rest of the adult working population.

Many of my colleagues have already highlighted how the government policy clearly discriminates against the one income family. I was interjecting on Senator Chris Evans a few minutes ago about that and, clearly, we will not agree. He addressed the issue of means testing. Of course, it is true to say that one is means tested and the other is not. It is also true to say that one pays a maximum of $30 a week and the other pays up to $61.20 a week. He talked about the reality of family life. The reality of family life is that where there are two parents in the work force, there are two tax-free thresholds available to that family—meaning, in effect, that that family has considerably more disposable income, even when compared with a one income family on a substantially higher income. So the difference in the presence or absence of the tax threshold is one very big reality in the lives of Australia's families.

The non-means tested child-care rebate makes two parents in the workplace—getting their two tax-free thresholds and their means test free child-care rebate—a logical option from a financial point of view. So it is not really just a question of what families would like to do; it is a question of where their financial interests lie if they are going to achieve for themselves and their children what they want in life. It is, if you like, government policy driven, not driven by the wishes and personal needs of the family. Sometimes people are doing something because they want to do it; sometimes they are doing it because it really is the only sensible option.

As I said, that discrimination shows up in the taxation system as well because single income families pay up to 40 per cent more tax than two-income families earning the same amount. A family earning $50,000 a year from one income pays $13,646 in tax, and a family earning the same amount from two equal incomes would pay $9,593, or $80 a week less—that is, $80 extra of disposable income.

Over and over again we come back to the question of choice. Until we address that properly, until it is a real choice for families, as a nation we have not done our best by the developing families in our country. We all recognise the need to raise our children in the best way possible for their sakes and for the sake of the future of our country. Where parents would like to have the opportunity of continuing personal contact with their children, watching the developmental stages bit by bit as they grow, responding to their children, stimulating their children, helping in the real development of their children yet are deprived from doing so on purely financial grounds, we have not served Australia's families well.

In case it should be thought I am looking only at what is a family's income, there is more to it than simply what is the total disposable income. As we all realise only too well when we have raised a family of our own, the one income can be a very different kettle of fish in one family's hands when compared with another family with the same income. I am here talking about the question of dependency—the question of mouths to feed, shoes to buy, children to raise.

This not only applies to children, of course, but also to adult disabled family members, for example, or chronically ill family members and elderly family members who may be dependent upon the younger generation. A family with an income of $40,000 which has two dependants to keep is in a very different position, and as a result their choice is a very different matter from the family with $40,000 which maybe has four, five or six dependants. So when we look at family policy issues, when we are trying to do our best as a nation for Australia's families, we should not only focus on the income available to families but I believe we should also be looking at the question of dependency and the needs of Australia's families as they vary from one to another.

Before concluding, I would like to make particular mention of some of the families who will be excluded under the government's legislation. Having formerly had the shadow portfolio of defence science and personnel, and knowing only too well how many families in the defence forces must go away from this country for prolonged periods because the nation requires them to do so, I was very alert to the fact that the government has excluded these families from coverage of the home child-care allowance. I find that extraordinary, because in the past those families would have been entitled to the dependent spouse rebate. As I understood it, the government's promise was that these families would simply be exchanging the dependent spouse rebate for the home child-care allowance and would be given the price of a McDonald's hamburger to go with it.

But it seems that some people are less equal than others. Defence Force personnel, public servants, people in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs or the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, people from our universities who go overseas to work or to do further study—some of the top medical people in our country are only as good as they are and are only available to us for our health care because they too have spent prolonged periods overseas acquiring further skills in their profession—are the people who are excluded under this legislation. I find it quite incredible that the government is bringing to us what purports to be the implementation of an election promise which in fact excludes a number of people who, for no good reason, are being cut out altogether. The very fact that they are overseas for periods of time does not mean to say they are not Australian citizens. They may well be paying Australian taxes.

If the dependent spouse rebate had remained, these people would still have been entitled to it. I find it quite incredible that this action is being taken against them. I can only be charitable and suggest that it is an unintended consequence of the government changing this entitlement, but I do urge that action be taken urgently to reinstate the position for these families who are overseas, but not permanently.

The coalition is currently working, and will be spending a great deal of time during the International Year of the Family, on producing policies which are family friendly in a number of policy areas. We believe one of the most important areas is in this inter-relationship between the taxation system and the social security system; how best to help Australia's families, how best to provide them with real, genuine choices in the life decisions that they make, and how best to help and support them in rearing the next generation.

Of course, while the opposition is not averse to the cashing out of the dependent spouse rebate, and while we recognise that many women's groups have wanted that to happen for a great many years, we are concerned that the government does have such a blinkered vision, shall I say, about the needs of different kinds of families and how unwilling it is to recognise that there are stages in a family's life where it may well wish to be a one-income family if it could afford it, even though it had previously been a two-income family, will probably later become a one-and-a-half income family and will probably eventually end up being a two-income family again.

That is a profile of a pretty typical Australian family. We move in and out of these various stages in our lives. Surely to goodness while we are in the stage of raising the smallest members of our families we should have a real choice of being able to live on one income without being discriminated against as compared with other families which may have both parents in the work force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how many speakers now there have been; honourable senators from the opposition kept adding themselves to this debate on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill. I found it a very depressing debate in some ways because the opposition very clearly conveyed that it prefers to understand women as though they belonged in the 19th century. The opposition's view as stated is evidence of its thinking, and those opposite do not like having to face up to the fact that the world has changed and that their view of women is always 10 years behind.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman said in closing she had some difficulty—knowing that a whole lot of women's organisations have fought for years to have the cash rebate cashed out, the dependent spouse rebate cashed out—with that being done. What grudging, miserable, mean-spirited little support for this comes from the opposition. Those opposite do not want to realise what an extraordinary achievement this is; they do not want to listen to what we are saying. They want to actually contrast A to Z as though there is some kind of relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are dishonest.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much.
—Senator Newman, I think you said that Senator Crowley was dishonest.
—She just heard me. She knows I did not say those things. That is unfair.
—If Senator Newman called me dishonest I would be very pleased if she withdrew it.
—I would ask you to withdraw that, Senator Newman.
—What am I withdrawing?
—That Senator Crowley is dishonest.
—Then she must be deaf. I withdraw `dishonest'.

—Thank you. It is very interesting that I rise to speak and suddenly there comes a cacophony from the opposition. It would be appreciated if opposition members could give me the same kind of hearing that I gave them. That is why I know what those opposite said.

PARA.TAB: A number of errors were made by speakers in this debate, and I would like to correct some of them as we go through. I will address those errors first, and I will come back to talk about the huge benefits of this bill and to refute some of the more ridiculous nonsense from the opposition.

At one stage it was claimed that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had never made it clear that this was to replace the dependent spouse rebate. Let me read from the policy launch address by Prime Minister Keating at the Bankstown town hall:

SPEECH.PARA: This allowance is more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it will replace.
The opposition does not want to hear or know that since this policy was established it has been put on the record that it was a cashing-out of the dependent spouse rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't mention it.

—Of course, Senator Panizza, I have mentioned it and everybody knows it. Everybody knows that it is the cashing-out of the dependent spouse rebate, but it does seem that the women who are so interested in supporting this payment to women have understood the detail of it far more than some of the men who have spoken. I am not at all surprised by that because, as I say, thousands of women in this country have been fighting for this huge, significant, great achievement that we have in the principles of this bill—a payment directly to the spouse at home, recognising the great contribution the spouse makes to the care of children, instead of by way of a claim for 12 months at the end of each year which perhaps does not come to them until 18 months later.
—What do you mean? It comes every week.
—I will not refer Senator Panizza to the number of times women actually get their hands on a tax deduction which comes to their spouse.

—It has a whole lot to do with that, Senator, and that is one of the reasons we would like to do it. The child-care rebate has been trawled across this debate as though it is a case of `compare and contrast'. The facts about the child-care rebate have been grossly misrepresented by the opposition. Senator Chris Evans made a great contribution in trying to make it clear to the opposition that one does not get the $61 child-care cash rebate unless one has spent nearly three times that amount on child-care expenses. That seems to be lost on those opposite. They rush around the place saying, `If you go to work the government will give you $60'. That is not the case until one spends well over two and a half times, nearly three times, the amount.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make a point on behalf of Senator Lees, who was very grossly misrepresented by Senator Campbell. I was listening, and I am glad Senator Lees spoke for herself so that I do not have to cover that ground again. But there is a suggestion that Senator Patterson wants the government to write the opposition's amendments. It is a first time, as Senator Lees says, and I am certainly not persuaded by it.
If it was a question of timing, I believe that the clerks are more than capable—on previous occasions they have certainly shown this—of getting those amendments written.

Let me remind the Senate that this bill was introduced into the House of Representatives in December 1993. Coalition senators have had more than three months to study and draft amendments, yet they are precious enough to say that it is only a week since the report of the committee was handed down. That also mucks around with the facts of the matter, as it is 10 days since the committee met. Time has been available to the opposition, so I find it pathetic and certainly not persuasive.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did the report come into the parliament? Monday, the report came into the parliament.

—Senator Patterson was at the hearing. She knows what it said, and she shaped the report. She was part of these deliberations and she had all of her questions and answers ready before she went to the committee. She should talk to the clerks earlier. In fact, she does not have to; the clerks can do it on the run. So do not use those specious and curious arguments. They do not count at all. She has had plenty of time.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that the Democrats, and Senator Lees in particular, were talking about the need to get this bill passed. As I understood it, she never said it was a matter of absolute urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —She said it had to be done today. Read the Hansard.

—What she said was that the opposition has had a stay of execution a number of times and that there is a good reason why it has to be done. I will tell the honourable senator what that is: it is to get the computer systems up, to make sure the eligible families, 840,000 of them, are incorporated into the system.
—She said today.
—I will hear Senator Patterson at estimates hearings soon, saying, `Well, why didn't you allow more time?'.
—She said today.

—She said there was no reason to delay it, and she is quite right. She has had three months to get these amendments through this place. She has known what the questions are; she knows want she wants to say. Her arguments are not persuasive.
—You are the government. You fix it up.

—We do not see that it needs any fixing. It is she who wants to argue for the changes. There are a number of arguments that the opposition has put up, but before I deal with them I would like to highlight some of the huge advantages of this bill, because they have been deliberately ignored and not stated in the debate by the opposition. I have said already that this cashing-out gives due recognition for the first time to the valuable work done by the spouse at home in caring for children. Also, it is paying—albeit a modest amount, one might say—money directly to that spouse who is now not able to continue earning income in the work force. It is paid straight away. If the person's income is below $10.50—and we have had the figures spelt out—up to $250 per fortnight, they are entitled to this payment straight away. They do not have to wait until the end of the tax year.
—You're wrong.

—They do not have to wait to get the benefits. Not everybody is a PAYE taxpayer. Many people do not get access to the dependent spouse rebate until 18 months later. I am advised it is about 50 per cent of people, Senator Panizza. So I am not wrong. I make the point again that immediately those people stop work to have a child, they have access to this cashed-out home child-care allowance, which is of massive benefit. Also, about 55,000 families who have not been eligible for the dependent spouse rebate because their tax liability was so small are now eligible. Nobody in the opposition told us about that great benefit.

PARA.TAB: There was no breaking of hearts by those opposite for all those people who have not had the dependent spouse rebate to this point. There was no telling us the facts of the matter as to the huge gain to all those families at the lowest end of the income scale who will now be able to get the home child-care allowance. And what a benefit it will be to them. If those families are ones whose taxable income is not sufficient for them to get the full dependent spouse rebate, then one is, by definition, talking about people with a very modest income, and they, all 55,000 families, as estimated, will now benefit to the full amount of this home child-care allowance. That is a very, very big gain for those families. It is curious that nobody from the opposition wanted to talk about that or put those facts on the record.

It is also interesting to note that the income test for children will be expanded so that it is not $1,785 a year as it is now, but $5,860 a year. That is more than three times as generous as it is now. With regard to those children over 18 years of age, for whom the caring spouse will not qualify for the home child-care allowance, there are not likely to be too many of those children in the category that seems to be one that is upsetting Senator Patterson. I would submit there are very few children over the age of 18 whose income is below what is currently $1,785.

There are some very great benefits regarding this payment that were not told to the Senate by the opposition and which, very importantly, need to be added. This is a watershed piece of legislation, coming into existence as it does in the International Year of the Family. This was a promise made before the last election, and a promise kept.

TALK.START.PARA: —A deceptive promise.

—I note the opposition is not referring to broken promises regarding this piece of legislation; nor is it opposing the promise that we have kept about the cash rebate. But what it has managed to do is get itself so knotted up that somehow it seems to be opposed to the cash rebate. It must get clear what its thinking is. It should be congratulating the government on this piece of legislation. As the women's organisations are saying, this is a great achievement.
—Thimble and pea trick.
—Senator Patterson knows it is a great achievement. She has spoken and listened genuinely to a number of women's organisations. They love it.

PARA.TAB: I thank Senator Lees for her contribution. As I say, I think she was misrepresented. I think she covered her own misrepresentation very well and made the point very accurately indeed about the opposition amendment, which I have to say is bizarre. Her comments are on the record, and I note and appreciate them.

Senator Minchin introduced me to a new concept which is called the housewife syndrome. The housewife syndrome is apparently what happens when people are sitting down at dinner somewhere and a gentleman—Senator Minchin called him a man—turns to a woman on his right or left and says, `What do you do?', and she says, `I am just a housewife'. He then turns around to talk to any woman who is working—any woman except a woman who is just a housewife at home. Senator Minchin calls this the housewife syndrome. Why does he not call it the boring man syndrome? It has nothing to do with the poor housewife. This is a disgrace. We have heard of `Blame the victim'; now it is `Label the victim'. This indicates what is in Senator Minchin's head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since when did you take up psychiatry?
—Good interjection there. I interpret what people say from their own words. I do not actually impose intentional motive on the opposition. I am referring to what Senator Minchin said.

PARA.TAB: Senator Minchin also got the facts about the cash rebate and the home child-care allowance very muddled. He keeps saying it is $30 paid out if the parent is at home and $60 paid out for two children if they are in child care. People do not get $60 unless they spend at least 2 1/2 to nearly three times that amount on child-care expenses in the formal or informal area.

According to Senator Minchin, he was appalled that we want to encourage women into the work force with the cash rebate for child care but that we then want to give women only what he called $30 to stay at home. But then he went on to say that of course the opposition would have done it too. So I really do wonder about Senator Minchin's view. Is he for it or against it? Does he somehow think that if the opposition wanted to give a cash rebate for child care it would be all right, but that it is not all right for the government to do so? He then spent a lot of time adding to confusion.

I am very interested to hear from opposition members on these things because, in all the years that I have been in here, I have never heard them get up to speak about the income test on the dependent spouse rebate. I have never heard them say that it was unfair for the spouse at home to have an income test to be eligible for the dependent spouse rebate. I have never heard Senator Patterson say that. Exactly the same income test applies now, so why was the outrage not heard before? What is the difficulty?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what you're talking about?

—That is exactly right; Senator Patterson had better find out. There is also a suggestion that the cash rebate is just some kind of payment by government and that there is a failure by the opposition to recognise that that is also a milestone in legislation on behalf of women. Another thing for which women have fought for years is the recognition that child-care costs are a legitimate claim against earning an income. This government has recognised the legitimacy of those costs against income and has targeted the payment so that it is most equitable. That is what the cash rebate is about. This is not a war between cash rebate and the home child-care allowance. These are two splendid advantages for women and families of Australia as we recognise that women sometimes choose to be at home and sometimes choose to be in the work force. It is entirely as a result of recognising those options for women that this government has introduced these two benchmark pieces of legislation.

PARA.TAB: I have to make some comments about Senator Panizza's statement that he could be accused of going soft if he spoke about social security. That is another attitude that is very worrying. I do not judge that anybody who speaks about social security is going soft. I do not believe speaking about social security is a soft option but, unfortunately and sadly, Senator Panizza does. I find that very disappointing. Having said that, I ask what else can one say about anything he has to say?

I think Senator Newman trawled across the same ground, adding nothing new to the arguments. The opposition is very confused about its policies for women, and it is certainly very confused about its policies for families. I suppose I could suggest, somewhat facetiously, that the opposition could form a good little committee to examine family policies. Two first players might be Mr Howard from the other place and Senator Vanstone who, so far as I can read in the public press, are very diametrically opposed to income splitting, tax-free thresholds and so on. But that might be a good thing to start with.

If those opposite do not want to start with a committee, they at least provide clear evidence of the deep divisions in the opposition about policies for families. They are not agreed about their policies for women because they are very confused. Opposition members are not at all able to say that these are two absolutely great achievements for women, which are therefore achievements for families. They have got themselves so muddled and so caught up on the idea that somehow women at home are at war with women in the work force that they have failed to understand that these policies assist women in making choices. They assist families in moving between having a spouse at home and having two spouses in the work force.

I wish to assist the Senate with a couple of figures. First of all, there is a claim that we are spending far too much money through cash rebates for child care and child-care assistance and that this amount is far larger than that which we spend on the home child-care allowance. I will shortly seek leave to incorporate a table which makes comparisons of outlays of programs. It shows quite clearly that, in the year 1994-95, the expenditure on the home child-care allowance and the rebate for dependent spouse with child will be $1,313 million, compared with the total outlays for child care of $860 million. The figures are also there for other years. I think these are most important figures that might assist honourable senators in looking more factually at these matters in this debate.

I have said that we will not accept Senator Patterson's amendment to the second reading motion. I am not at all persuaded by any of her arguments about pressures of time or lateness. I think the achievements of this legislation are absolutely remarkable. I note that the opposition is qualifying its support. But that is all it is doing because it knows that this is a great achievement on behalf of government. I seek leave for this document to be incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't seen it, so it can be tabled but not incorporated.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not become Senator Patterson to be so snitchy, but I hope she will have a look at the document. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
