TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That consideration of the bill in the Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, at this point we would normally move to the committee stage of debate. However, the government is facing a difficulty with the timing and production of amendments. I am only very lately advised that Senator Harradine has amendments which go very much to the amendments Senator Patterson had proposed but said she could not get written in time. I had earlier been advised that Senator Harradine had amendments but was not proceeding with them because of his understanding that those opposite were proceeding with theirs. I find that an amazing way to proceed.

PARA.TAB: I would advise Senator Harradine that, if he has amendments, he should announce them and be absolutely clear about what he wants to put forward for debate. He might have to rely on himself in the future because the opposition has been of no assistance to him this time. It certainly does not assist us to manage the flow of business through this chamber if amendments are not ready for debate. We are very willing to go through amendments with all the parties—the Independents, the Democrats, the Greens and the opposition—but we are not interested in writing amendments for the opposition.

I have not seen Senator Harradine's amendments but I believe that, in substance, they go to the points contained in Senator Patterson's amendment. I therefore believe that it would be fair to defer the committee stage to give the Senate time to see the amendments and to prepare for any necessary consequential discussion.

The Senate is not assisted by Senator Harradine producing amendments from his back pocket as we approach the final stages of this bill. That does not assist the government and we in turn cannot assist others in those circumstances. I urge Senator Harradine to rely on himself in future. We will then be able to proceed with business in a more thoughtful and constructive way. If Senator Harradine is proceeding with those amendments—I understand that he is—then we should all have the opportunity of looking at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take objection to the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) having said on at least one occasion that I had said that I could not get the amendments done in time. I did not say that at all. If she can find where I said that in the Hansard, I will stand to be corrected. We have raised some concerns which Senator Crowley can address. We gave her the opportunity but she failed to do it. It will be interesting to hear what young academics, aid workers and missionaries say. We have had some groups come to us who are working as medical missionaries—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We have had it discussed a number of times in this place. Senator Patterson is now debating the issues and straying far away from the point of misrepresentation. I ask you to call her to order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order. Senator Crowley is out of court here because Senator Patterson is explaining quite clearly where Senator Crowley misrepresented what Senator Patterson said. Senator Patterson should be allowed to finish.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Patterson, would you keep to the subject of where you were misrepresented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will keep to the point. Senator Crowley said that I said that I did not have time. I did not say anything of the sort. She also said there had been some misunderstanding or that I had played some trick on Senator Harradine. I believe that is not the case either. Senator Harradine was fully informed of what I was doing. He can explain whether he has had amendments hidden under his desk, as Senator Crowley seemed to intimate. As far as I was concerned, Senator Harradine had intimated to me that he might have an amendment in another area. He then intimated quite clearly to me that he was not going to proceed with that amendment. I have been fully informed by Senator Harradine, and I do not believe there have been any untoward, strange goings on between Senator Harradine and myself on that issue. Senator Crowley intimated there had been, and I find that objectionable as well.

—I am sure that nobody would believe for a moment that there would be strange goings on between Senator Patterson and myself. I think there has been a great misunderstanding here. I do believe that Senator Crowley's comments were, to say the least, ungracious. I do not think they were churlish, but she was slightly ungracious. Possibly the reason for that is a misunderstanding. I did indicate that I might well move amendments in respect of the quantum of payment of the home child-care allowance. That would have been a group of amendments that I would have moved. There were other amendments which I will put into the category of, I hope, unintended consequences; they may well have been intended. They were identified in the minority report of the committee which was only tabled on Monday.

PARA.TAB: I assumed, and obviously incorrectly, that the opposition was going to move those amendments. It is true that I then indicated that I would not be proceeding with my amendments because of a number of factors. I suppose it would have been difficult to get support for them at this stage. I do hope that the government at some stage will be looking at that question. I heard what Senator Crowley said. This legislation is setting the system up and there is no reason why substantial improvements could not be made to the home child-care allowance in future budgets. The opposition needed time to consider those questions, and no doubt also the Democrats because of their consideration of budgetary items. In those circumstances, I indicated that I would not be proceeding with the amendments. They were not these amendments that we were talking about.

When I got to my desk this morning I noted that the amendment that was to be moved by the Opposition at the second reading stage called upon the government to amend the bill to achieve certain objectives. Obviously, when I heard that the government, and possibly the Senate, would not be supporting that second reading amendment, I had then to hurry to try to get amendments prepared. I hope Senator Crowley will kindly accept that explanation. I agree with the motion as moved by Senator Crowley.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.3) 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to telecommunications there are two very minor changes to the legislation. One is to recognise the name of Telstra, which has become the offshore trading arm of Telecom Australia, and indeed the name of the holding company. Telecom remains the domestic trading arm. That name change has simply been incorporated in legislation. In so far as the application of Telecom's universal service obligation is concerned, it has always extended to the islands and territories of Australia, but until now by regulation. This amendment simply incorporates that extension into the legislation and brings it within the same framework. There is nothing contentious about those two amendments, and the opposition will be supporting them.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the transport aspects of the bill are concerned, the amendments do not introduce substantial new policy schemes. Certainly, in respect of maritime legislation amendments this is true, but in the case of the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981, and the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 there are issues of concern to the foreign flag shipping industry. Those are matters that I think will be dealt with by the appropriate standing committee. That aspect of the bill will be referred to the committee after the second reading stage.

As far as Telecom is concerned, there are a number of ways in which I think its operations could be made more efficient. Obviously the name change is part of its strategy for coping with increased competition with Optus. If Telecom is to seriously attract more customers or retain those it has, it would be well advised to pay a lot more heed to the complaints it receives from many of its customers.

Indeed, the fact that it has been necessary for a Casualties of Telecom—or COT cases—group to arise in the community is testimony to the fact that it has not been handling customer complaints in the manner that it should. In many respects, it has been aggravating the situation by its conduct. One does not want to say those things lightly, but from the very many complaints my office has received—a figure in excess of 250 to date; and I will put aside any other complaints I might have—it is true to say that Telecom's response in many instances has been very slow, in others misleading and certainly not to the satisfaction of those who have, on the face of it, very serious grievances. In some instances people have gone out of business as a result of complaints about the telephone service. Whilst we welcome the name change, we hope that there will be a little more accompanying it in terms of substance and I look forward to further progress on that front.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is a brief bill which seeks to amend seven other acts of parliament; the Air Navigation Act 1920; the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Act 1991; the Navigation Act 1912; the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act 1993; the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981; the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983; and the Telecommunications Act 1991.

PARA.TAB: As mentioned in both the second reading speech and a moment ago by Senator Alston, in the main these amendments are relatively trivial and in the nature of tidying up. I refer in particular to two of the acts which are amended by this legislation, namely, the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 and the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981. A situation which has affected this country, and doubtless other countries, in relation to pollution relates to the discharge of ballast water. I refer to the discharge of water which has been taken on by ships in some other part of the world and then discharged into our region, either into our harbours or into regions near the shore and which in the case of Australia has, in at least two instances, resulted in the introduction of species which are quite damaging to the marine environment.

It is the belief of the Australian Democrats that, as these acts are now being amended, this would be an appropriate opportunity for the parliament to pass further amendments which would have the effect of ensuring that ballast water was either not discharged or was sterilised in some way in its journey, usually from the northern hemisphere to the southern hemisphere, or discharged ashore and sterilised in some way, so that it is not then passed into the marine environment. Accordingly, I foreshadow that in the committee stage the Democrats will be moving such amendments.

The two organisms to which I refer are a starfish and a seaweed which have been introduced into the southern New South Wales coast and also into the region around Hobart. In both instances these organisms are very damaging to the local environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Did I understand Senator Coulter to indicate that he would be moving amendments? If so, have they been circulated in the chamber?

—I understand that we are not dealing with the committee stage tonight. I am foreshadowing amendments when we come back to the committee stage. As Senator Alston said in his speech, at the end of the second reading debate this matter will go off to a committee, so there is plenty of time for amendments to be circulated.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—The bill is to be referred to a committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to you for that, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think we were all assuming that something had been done to ensure that happens.
—I thank Senator Alston for drawing attention to the fact that he is having early notification that we will be moving amendments in this area.
—We want to see them though.
—I know that Senator Ian Macdonald would be equally concerned about the introduction of exotic species, say, into the Great Barrier Reef, which could create enormous difficulties in that area.

PARA.TAB: At this stage I do not want to detain the Senate any further, but wish simply to indicate that this is and has been an area of concern for some considerable time. It is one that we have raised on a number of occasions in the Senate. We feel that, given this opportunity to amend this legislation, this is an opportunity which we will be availing ourselves of and, consequently, will be bringing forward amendments at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague Senator Alston in the coalition's approach to the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Senator Alston mentioned several aspects of the bill. Briefly, I want to talk about the amendments to the Air Navigation Act and to indicate the coalition's attitude to that aspect of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The stated objective of the amendments proposed by the bill to the Air Navigation Act is to allow the government to ensure that any Australian carrier seeking designation or already designated on an international route can demonstrate its compliance with bilateral requirements that it is substantially owned and effectively controlled by Australian nationals.

In February 1992 the government decided that Australia should introduce a scheme of multiple designation of Australia's scheduled international air services. Bilateral arrangements govern Australia's rights to designate Australian carriers for scheduled international air services. These bilateral arrangements require that Australia's international carriers are substantially owned and effectively controlled by Australian nationals. For a carrier to be designated as an Australian international carrier, it has to meet certain designation criteria.

The government has announced new designation criteria. In accordance with these criteria the amendments to the act allow for the minister to require information as to foreign shareholdings from Australia's international airlines. It will further allow the minister to take all necessary action to ensure that the articles of association of a designated airline company comply with the stated foreign ownership limits; that equity held by foreign airlines in aggregate does not exceed 35 per cent of the total value of issued share capital; and that equity held by an individual foreign airline does not exceed 25 per cent of the total value of issued share capital. The articles of association must also empower the directors of the company to take whatever measures are required to enforce these limits.Further, the amendments allow the minister to apply for an injunction in the Federal Court requiring that the directors act in compliance with the articles of association such that the foreign ownership limits are met.

This is a fairly sensible piece of legislation required for Australia to meet its international commitments in the airline industry. It is a shame that there have not been similar pieces of sensible legislation for aviation, air safety and regulation. One can understand the government's inability to manage the aviation portfolio properly when one considers that the position of minister in charge of aviation has been held by 11 different Labor ministers over a 10-year period and there have actually been 16 appointments.

First, we had Mr Kim Beazley; then Mr Peter Morris, who held transport in the early days and then took on aviation; then Senator Gareth Evans held transport and communications; Mr Clyde Holding was involved in transport and communications as minister; Senator Robert Ray was at one time minister assisting the minister for transport and communications; Mr Morris then again held transport and communications; Mr Gary Punch held telecommunications and aviation support; and, Mr Acting Deputy President, would you believe, Mrs Kelly held telecommunications and aviation support from April 1989 to April 1990. One wonders if all of the directions on aviation support were written on the whiteboard in those days, as they seem to be these days.

Mr Ralph Willis also held the portfolio. Senator Collins held the shipping and aviation support portfolio from May 1990 to December 1991. He then held the different portfolio of shipping and aviation from December 1991 to May 1992. Mr Beazley had transport and communications in this period. Senator Richardson also held transport and communications. Senator Cook held shipping and aviation support from May 1992 until the March 1993 election. Senator Collins came back as transport and communications minister in charge of aviation from May 1992 until very recently, when mercifully we got a more competent minister.

But it is no wonder the government is in such disarray with its aviation policy, with a total of 16 appointments in just 10 years. It is an amazing record of ministerial and portfolio reshuffling. It is no wonder that our aviation policy is in such a mess, and some of our air safety records are in such a mess. I have to say that Senator Collins excelled himself in his inability to properly get on top of that particular portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —And others.

—And a lot of other portfolios as well; but my brief today is in the aviation field. But it does seem unfortunate the way Senator Collins actually handled that portfolio. I had a considerable amount of difficulty in getting any sensible assistance from Senator Collins. In fact I asked a continuing set of questions about the CAA and air safety. These were asked over a period of time since I became very interested in this, following an air crash at Young in which a friend of mine was killed.

PARA.TAB: Since that time a lot of people have been giving me tips and information about the atrocious state of air safety in our community, and I have tried to follow them through in a sensible way with the then minister, but it has not been easy. A series of questions that I asked at the last estimates committee hearing back in November were not answered until just a couple of days ago when the estimates were coming up again. They were all questions about air safety.

It seems appalling that the members of this parliament cannot get sensible answers quickly on matters of air safety. Honourable senators will recall that last year, as part of the questions I was raising, Senator Collins was reported to me—and I mentioned it to the Senate—as having changed minutes of a CAA meeting as they related to some answers he had given at estimates committees, and on some matters relating to air safety.

The fact that it has taken me this long to get answers—from one estimates committee to the next—just shows what a state this department is in. Although just two days ago I received a huge sheaf of those answers from the previous estimates committee, several questions were not answered at all.

I suspect that either the minister or the department hoped that, with the effluxion of time, senators would forget the questions they asked and that they would not be followed up. That can be the only explanation for questions having taken this long to be answered. I look forward with some relish to being at the estimates committees when we get to transport, to find out why it did take so long for those questions to be answered, to pursue the ones that have not been answered and also to pursue a lot of other information that people who are genuinely concerned with air safety in Australia keep giving to me. I keep getting reports—some anonymously—about the maladministration of the CAA and the department generally.

I do not know whether it is unfair to blame Senator Collins for all that mess. As I say, there has been such a range of different ministers and a reallocation of the portfolios over the past 10 years. It is a wonder anyone in the department knows anything that is happening. Certainly none of the ministers appears to have got on top of it. Senator Collins was not a good minister for aviation or aviation support or transport—whatever it happened to be called. His great claim to being the greatest minister involved in shipping and waterfront reform is something that he has been preaching for many months. But we have seen the results of Senator Collins's efforts on the waterfront in the last few days, when certain parts of Australia have been crippled by waterfront strikes.

Again, this government is simply unable to manage the waterfront, and certainly not able to manage aviation and air safety. As I said, this legislation does contain some sensible amendments to the Air Navigation Act to enhance Australia's position in international air travel. All that very much enhances our position as one of the major tourist destinations of the world.

I am particularly pleased to support any legislation that will mean a boost to our international tourism. International tourism is perhaps the fastest growing and most efficient and progressive industry that Australia currently has. It is certainly one that has gathered us an enormous amount of foreign currency revenue. It is one which, I am very pleased to say—and always proud to mention—is being very greatly expanded in the Townsville region and particularly the Cairns region of Far North Queensland.

This legislation, enhancing the ability of Australian carriers to move into the international market, can only indirectly at the present time—but I have no doubt it will be directly in the future—enhance tourism in that area of Australia where the tourism industry has really taken off, and continues to expand very rapidly for the benefit of that part of Australia and Australia generally. As my colleague mentioned, the coalition will be supporting the bill. I confirm that we will certainly be supporting that part of the bill which deals with those aviation matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to make lengthy comments in my response. Firstly, I thank the members of the opposition for their support of the legislation. I will not go so far as to extend that to Senator Ian Macdonald for his comments. I did prick up my ears when I heard he was supporting a piece of government legislation, but he did so in his typically ungracious fashion. He got onto issues that are not relevant to the legislation. He made an attack on Bob Collins, which I will pass on to the minister, about his allegedly changing minutes and allegedly having been a failure in the waterfront reform process. In due course he will answer those unsubstantiated and ridiculous charges.

PARA.TAB: I am glad that Senator Macdonald read out a list of the ministers who have held the portfolio responsibility, because that is an impressive list of ministers with lengthy achievements in the area. I look forward to the new Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) making a very significant contribution in this area. For evidence of that we have only to look at the significant industrial relations changes that were passed and that bear testimony to his sense of vision and accomplishment. I look forward to working with that minister in this particular area on future occasions.

The matter will be referred to a committee. The Democrats' concern relates to issues on the pollution of the sea and some quarantine issues of which I do have some first-hand knowledge, particularly the starfish problem in southern Tasmania. I do not intend to comment on that matter today. I think we should wait and see what the Democrats are pursuing via amendment in the senate committee. In concluding my remarks, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1994 is a very important bill for people such as Senator Schacht because it concerns his pay rise. It is a machinery bill which seeks a further appropriation of $77,000 to be made available for an increase in ministerial salaries.A number of concerns were raised by my colleague the member for Bradfield, Mr Connolly, in the debate in the other place on 21 February. I hope that the minister dealing with this bill may be able to provide us with some information about some of those concerns. Rather than repeat what Mr Connolly said in the House of Representatives, I will quickly recap those concerns.

PARA.TAB: The effect of this bill is that it appropriates $77,000 to cover a salary increase of 1.5 per cent in the ministerial salary component of ministers' salaries. The 1.5 per cent increase which is coming through as a result of the increase in SES salaries during March 1994 is automatically paid to other backbenchers, office holders and so forth. But because of the provisions in the constitution that the parliament provide for ministerial salaries, it is necessary to pass these ministers of state amendment bills from time to time when the ministerial component of salaries is increased.

The point made by my friend and colleague Mr Connolly in the House of Representatives is that the $77,000 represents more than a 1.5 per cent increase. It was represented in the second reading speech by the person handling the bill in the other place that a contingency allowance needs to be made for this appropriation for a range of circumstances, including when there are Acting Prime Ministers and ministers acting in other capacities. However, it seems that the amount that goes into what is probably called an imprest account could indeed be distributed at the discretion of the Prime Minister. I ask the minister to explain to the Senate why the amount of $77,000 was chosen when that amount would cover well in excess of the 1.5 per cent salary increase to ministers.

The other point is that there are a lot of people in the community at the moment who would find giving pay rises to people such as Minister Kelly at this particular time quite abhorrent. In fact, many people in the community would think that Ros Kelly, the minister for sports and whiteboards and various other things, should not receive any ministerial salary at all. They probably hope that Mrs Kelly might go away and think she should never have been given a job as a minister. The sports rorts affair that goes on day after day would reaffirm in people's minds the fact that she is not performing her duties as one would expect. Most people in the community would see the giving of a pay rise to Mrs Kelly, for example, as quite repugnant, after her performances.

I am one of those people in the parliament who thinks that most members of parliament and senators on both sides of the chamber and also ministers are not remunerated highly enough. I think it was my friend Peter Shack who told me a couple of years ago before he left this place that the remuneration of members of parliament had decreased by something like 24 per cent in real terms since he was elected as the member for Tangney in 1977. You would remember that better than I, Mr Acting Deputy President.

If we are to attract people to the important business of politics, people from either side of the chamber should never take cheap shots at remuneration for MPs. I am prepared to put that on the record. If indeed Mr Shack was right and remuneration has fallen by 24 per cent in that time, that is a matter of regret because slowly but surely the sort of people who make the sacrifices that are required to come into the parliament will not be there to make those sacrifices, and the quality of representation of the people will slowly but surely fall. I think that would be most regrettable for the good governance of Australia.

Regarding perceptions within the community of giving pay rises to people such as Mrs Kelly and our Senate colleague Senator Collins, the minister who was responsible or irresponsible for the pay TV fiasco, one has to wonder just what the electors of Australia would think at the parliament granting these people pay rises. If we criticise the pay increases on the basis of performance and start picking off individual ministers we can get into some trouble. However, we would not have the opportunity to pick on pay rises for people like Mrs Kelly and Senator Collins if the Prime Minister enforced what are sound and sensible assessments of ministerial responsibility and ministerial competence.

If the Prime Minister had done what he should have done, he would have got rid of Mrs Kelly when it became quite obvious to everyone else in Australia that she had failed as a minister, and Senator Collins, who promised to resign if he failed on waterfront reform—and he has demonstrably failed on waterfront reform. We have a perfect example in my home state of Western Australia where the whole of Fremantle closed down for 10 days over the last couple of weeks because of a fight over on the Sydney waterfront. If that is what Senator Collins calls waterfront reform, and he promised to resign if he did not get it through, then he will not even stand by his own standards.

It might seem a politically cheap shot to pick on Mrs Kelly and Senator Collins and say that they do not deserve their pay rises—of course Senator Schacht deserves his. But if the Prime Minister really deserved his pay rise, which I am told is in the order of $5,000 or $2,700, and he had done his job and stuck by the levels of credibility that one would demand of a Prime Minister, he would not have Senator Collins still on the front bench and he would not have Minister Kelly on his front bench. We would have people who were doing their jobs properly, who were not bringing the entire business of politics into disrepute, and we would not even be having to raise these points on this sort of bill.

If the minister could answer those questions in relation to why it is $77,000 and why that is much more than the 1.5 per cent, I would be most appreciative. I know that Mr Connolly has sought that advice from the department previously and it has not been provided, to the best of my knowledge. That would be helpful, it would be of assistance for the future and I would appreciate it. Otherwise, the opposition will support the passage of this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the last point that Senator Campbell raised, as I understand it, the $77,000, not just the 1.5 per cent this year, covers last year's as well.
—That is not true.
—That is what I am advised.
—Is it backdated?
—I am advised that it does cover it.
—Are you getting a pay rise and then backdating it?

—I do not think it is backdated. I think we were eligible for it but the bill was not put through. I am advised that the first pay rise was for March 1993. This bill covers that plus the future increase. That is why $77,000 adds up to more than the 1.5 per cent applied across all the ministerial salaries.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I wish to state that this document hints at some of the medium and long-term policy issues that should be of great concern to this parliament. The first issue I wish to raise on this occasion is the question of the independence of the Nuclear Safety Bureau, which monitors the activities of ANSTO. Many of the staff at the Nuclear Safety Bureau are on secondment from ANSTO with the right to return to ANSTO, and the Nuclear Safety Bureau itself operates from premises adjacent to the ANSTO premises at Lucas Heights. As the report of the Safety Review Committee states:
The SRC considers this to be a less than ideal situation in regard to the perceived independence of the NSB . . .
I trust that this matter will be addressed by government as a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—Good. The residents of the Sutherland shire in particular have justifiable concerns about the safety of the Lucas Heights establishment in their neighbourhood and need assurance that the organisation monitoring the safety aspects of the ANSTO operations is independent and reliable.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I wish to raise some concerns about the accumulating level of waste that emanates from the operations of ANSTO and the other nuclear waste that is stored at Lucas Heights. The greatest problem that this operation faces is the limited storage space at the site and the ever increasing storage requirements due to the continued operations of the reactor and associated activities. The SRC report acknowledges this when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . accumulation of ANSTO wastes will eventually strain current storage facilities if no progress is made on a national repository.

This is the crux of the issue. One of the key reasons why we have not established a national waste repository is that there are substantial and justifiable community concerns about the safety of any waste disposal options proposed by ANSTO or the government. We should not be continuing to produce nuclear waste when we have no acceptable disposal or storage technology available.

PARA.TAB: The related question of the 10,000 drums of contaminated soil from Fishermans Bend in Victoria is also of great concern. There is a requirement that these drums be removed from the site by February 1995, but there are no acceptable alternative storage options available.
The continuing safety of the HIFAR reactor is also of great concern. The Acting Director of the Nuclear Safety Bureau points to concerns in this regard, and states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . NSB agreement to the continued operation of HIFAR beyond 1995 will be conditional on the completion of current upgrading work . . . and that the remaining life of HIFAR should not extend beyond ten years without major safety upgrading.

In addition, the SRC report points to problems in relation to the seismic safety of the HIFAR reactor. It appears that `the issue of the seismic resistance of HIFAR remains unresolved'. I trust that the residents of Sutherland shire are given solid assurances in this regard as a matter of urgency, given the proximity of the reactor to residents in that locality.

PARA.TAB: I would like to point out that the Greens are not convinced about the cost-effectiveness of a nuclear reactor in this country and have great concerns about the ability of any nuclear facility to guarantee safety standards. Therefore, we will be strongly opposed to either a new nuclear reactor or the upgrading of HIFAR.

The medical uses of nuclear technology could be satisfied in this country through the construction of cyclotron facilities in strategic locations combined with the import of longer term isotopes from existing overseas reactors. The best way to avoid concerns about safety or to avoid waste disposal problems, however, is not to have a nuclear reactor in the first place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the same report in view of Senator Margetts' comments. I am the minister responsible for ANSTO, as she is obviously aware, and I am also responsible for a number of related matters.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts raised the question of the Nuclear Safety Bureau being positioned within ANSTO. I want to point out that I do not have all the details with me because I was unaware that this was coming on for discussion. Moves are afoot to rectify that and there are changes being made. I hope that the matters that Senator Margetts raised will be able to be dealt with in the near future.

There are other changes being made to the operation of the Nuclear Safety Bureau itself. Those arrangements will ultimately lead to the Minister for Health having responsibility for the regulatory functions. I have always had a view that the minister for industry or the portfolio minister in the industry area, such as me, who is responsible for ANSTO itself should not also be the minister responsible for the safety regime because quite clearly from time to time there can be a conflict of interest. For example, if there were a difference between ANSTO and the Nuclear Safety Bureau over some safety issue, at the moment I would be answering within the parliament two different sets of advice, and I do not think that would be appropriate. That was one of the decisions taken by the government last November on nuclear matters—the decision to have the regulatory function and the safety aspects transferred to another ministry. I welcome that, and that was my recommendation.

With regard to the general issue of the future of ANSTO, the government has decided that there will be no need to make a decision for another five years on whether we need to have a new reactor in Australia. That will be a matter of considerable public debate because it would be a major expenditure if the government did agree to build a new reactor. At that time, I am sure Senator Margetts or others will enjoin that debate, as is appropriate and proper.

I also want to point out and place on the record that the McKinnon review of the operation of the HIFAR reactor at ANSTO gave a clean bill of health as far as the management and the safety of the functions of the reactor are concerned. McKinnon's recommendation was that all the issues raised by the local community and others were being adequately dealt with.

The last issue that he raised, which is a proposition now before government, is to have a probabilistic survey of the reactor itself. That is to determine how much longer the reactor can be considered to safely operate. It is not, in any way, to be taken as an indication of alarm that there is anything wrong with the present operation of the reactor. After a very extensive review, with a wide range of evidence taken, Professor McKinnon said that the reactor is safe and is being properly managed in accordance with the highest levels of safety standards in Australia. I want to put that on the record so that there is no misunderstanding, particularly for the local residents in the Sutherland Shire Council.

The final thing that I want to say—particularly to Senator Margetts, in view of her interest—is that in the near future I will be convening a meeting of senior management from ANSTO and senior councillors from the Sutherland Shire Council to establish an ongoing mechanism whereby issues of dispute between ANSTO and the local council, representing the local population, can be dealt with across the table in a dialogue rather than in confrontation. Obviously, they will not always agree; but we want to establish a better mechanism than has been operating in the past so that both sides get a chance to talk directly with each other, and not past each other, about the issues relating to the operation of ANSTO at the Lucas Heights site in the Sutherland Shire Council area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to continue the remarks made earlier today by my colleague Senator Woodley. I guess we could broadly describe the question as: is there a future for farm families in Australia? Tonight I want to talk specifically about South Australia. In the Adelaide Advertiser yesterday there was an article written by Ed Rush on poverty which particularly looked at the enormous number of South Australians who now rely on charity for basic essentials. The article states:

PARA.TAB: Adelaide's welfare agencies are handing out more than 8000 meals, food packages, vouchers and cash payments every week to destitute South Australians.
The weekly cost of the effort to feed desperate families and individuals has soared to as high as $68,000.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on, in particular, to quote from the South Australian Farmers Federation. The article states:

PARA.TAB: According to the South Australian Farmers Federation, more than one-third of the State's 14,000 farmers were living on or below the poverty line late last year.
And many were finding it increasingly difficult to buy food and other essential household items.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are calling for from government is not a series of handouts; indeed, it is for no more tinkering around the edges. It is for a commitment from government that there will be a change of political will—in other words, a political commitment to actually do something about the problem.

PARA.TAB: To give the Senate an example of the depth of this problem—and I am only talking about one specific aspect tonight—I will read some figures from the rural counselling service in South Australia. These are only for the period from January to June 1993. In other words, these are dealing only with the clients that the rural counselling service in South Australia was assisting during that period. If we look first at the statistics for total debt, we find that in the Barossa and Light regions, for the clients the service was helping, it was $18,666,000. For the eastern Eyre Peninsula, one counsellor was handling families with total debts of $36,391,000 and another counsellor handled families whose total debts were $27,578,000. Perhaps one of the grimmest statistics is from Kangaroo Island where the total debts, just for the families supported, were $23,140,000.

If we look at the average debt per client, we see how serious this is. On Kangaroo Island the average debt per client is $335,374. If we look at eastern Eyre Peninsula, we see that the average debt is somewhere between $176,000 and $246,000. If we move on to the upper and mid-north areas, we find that the total debt for families was $47,247,000. The average debt per family was $218,736.

If we look to the Riverland we find that just one of the counsellors there had clients with total debts over $16 million, and the average debt was $151,837. In the south-east, the clients assisted there had total debts around $50 million, with the average debt around $320,000. Just in that one period—January to June 1993—the total debt of clients of the rural counselling service was over $303 million. The average debt of clients of rural counsellors was over $25 million. The average debt per client across the state was $242,000 and more. This is totally unsustainable. We need policies now that address this issue. It is an issue of equity. No, we are not talking about debt write-off; we are talking about constructive schemes to support farm families. There have been three or four schemes that certainly deserve consideration.

When we look at the average equity figures we can understand the depth of this problem. The average equity in the far west, for example, is only 17 per cent; the average equity on Kangaroo Island is 36 per cent; and the average equity in the Murraylands is 39 per cent. Indeed, across the state the average equity in farms now is only around 50 per cent for those being supported by the rural counselling service.

In that period of time 112 families were adjusted, if I may use the term, out of farming. In other words, there were 112 family units whose skills are now lost to us and to the land. Generally they have had to relocate themselves, often right out of the district, away from friends the kids have made and away from the support services formerly enjoyed by the family.

When we turn to look at the workload on the rural counsellors themselves, the hours worked per week range from, for Barossa and Light, 65 hours a week, to 48 for those in the Broken Hill region, to 64 and 56 for the two counsellors on eastern Eyre Peninsula, to 47 in the far west and to 53 on Kangaroo Island. The average per rural counsellor is 53 hours per week, yet we hear rumours that in this year's budget there will be a decrease in the level of funding for rural counsellors. The average number of kilometres travelled by each counsellor is over 24,000.

Again we can look at the whole issue of debt with another set of figures; we can look at debt in arrears. Some 15 of these farming family units have major problems with being in arrears with debts. Indeed, only 10 of those families being supported had no debts whatsoever. Indeed, if we look at 50 per cent equity, some 650 families out of the 1,314 owed more than they actually had in equity in the farm—in other words, they had over 50 per cent of debt owing compared to the value of the property.

They are just a few figures I can give in the time available to me tonight. We are now asking government for real commitment. Yes, there have been specific measures, and one went through this chamber today that will be of benefit in a small way. The child-care cash rebate for women staying at home is about to become available to these families. Previously these families missed out on that because they did not have a taxable income, and therefore could not take advantage of the dependant spouse rebate. People were only able to get that if they were at a sufficient income level to actually pay tax. So one of the groups that will benefit from the way that dependent spouse rebate will be cashed out will include, I would say, virtually all the families that I am talking about tonight.

Those little bits and pieces around the edges are not enough. Even an increase in funding which I hope we will see for rural counsellors is not enough. We need real political commitment from this government. We now have a new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, but I suspect that as yet he does not realise the extent of the problems he is now facing in his new portfolio, and I certainly wish him well. We certainly need a minister who is prepared to travel, who will not rely on reports or second- or third-hand comments but who will actually go out and meet farm families and who will travel in rural parts of Australia. Obviously he will still need to meet with industry representatives, the National Farmers Federation, for example, but he should not leave the matter there.

I invite Senator Collins to travel in South Australia, in particular to Kangaroo Island, to the south-east, the mid-north and the west coast. I ask him to meet with rural counsellors and their clients to discuss what the government plans to do right across the board, not just in bits and pieces around the edge, to keep farming families on their farms. Hopefully we will see a real commitment by government and a real acknowledgment that we need to keep people in rural Australia. We should not simply be prepared to sit back and see a further deterioration in the quality of services and in the numbers of people living in rural areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having been a Liberal Party state director for about eight years, I am not the unduly sensitive type, but I took great exception to the very nasty and vitriolic remarks made by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) in her comments on the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill. She attacked not only me but other opposition senators, my colleagues Senator Campbell and Senator Patterson, in a way that was unduly personal and did not stick to the issues at all.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley sought to suggest there was something wrong with my head in regard to the remarks I made when I thought I was doing something that I thought she would applaud when I drew attention to the very significant problem we have in this country in regard to the very substantial lack of valuation of the role played by homemakers and full-time carers of children at home. This is a major social problem, and I was drawing attention to it, but Senator Crowley in her quite vitriolic way imputed to me thoughts and motives which are completely the opposite of the point I was trying to make. It was quite unwarranted, unfair and unfortunate.

This is a major social problem, and tonight I take the opportunity to reinforce what I said in my speech during the second reading debate. The nurture and care of Australia's young children is the very future of this country. Whether we are to have a productive and positive work force—stable families, young children and young people prepared to make a commitment to this country and its future prosperity—depends very much on the upbringing they get in their young years.

It is extraordinary that Senator Crowley should seek to attack me for making that point. Only today in the Advertiser, Ita Buttrose, one of Australia's most eminent professional women, drew attention to this problem when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: We've been brainwashed (because) we believe a woman who wants to be a complete woman must be in the workforce, otherwise she is considered as dumb, incompetent and insignificant.
The report went on to say:
Ms Buttrose said people needed to make supporting the family unit a priority, to help families fulfil their roles as nurturers, providers and protectors of their children.

A woman as distinguished as Ita Buttrose has drawn attention to this problem only today, and that is all I sought to do. I think it was absolutely pathetic of Senator Crowley to impute to me notions which were not there, which she knew were not there, and to attack me for drawing attention to this very significant problem in the way I did.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley was indeed splitting hairs when she sought to attack me for calling it a housewife's syndrome and by then saying it should be the boring man syndrome. Of course it is the boring man syndrome; of course it is the housewife syndrome—that is the whole point I was making in my comments. I would have thought she would have given credit where it was due, that she would applaud the fact that at least one male on this side had the wit to acknowledge this very significant social problem.

This would suggest to me that Senator Crowley does not really appreciate the problem that we were drawing attention to. It was evident in my remarks that I think there is a significant lack of government attention to this problem and that the government should in fact be acknowledging the importance of the role of the full-time mother and homemaker in bringing up the next generation of Australians.

After all, is Senator Crowley so anti-male that she will not acknowledge that males can draw attention to this problem on the part of males? Why will she not give credit to the opposition when we draw attention to this problem? It is simply the case with people like Senator Crowley that males simply cannot win. I would have thought she would welcome our comments.

Senator Crowley is presiding over, and is partly responsible for, an unholy mess in the way in which the government is dealing with the whole area of assistance to young families and young children. We have had a complete and utter shemozzle with the child-care accreditation guidelines. There has been an enormous community reaction to those. I congratulate Senator McGauran for drawing attention to it. I have had petitions numbering in the thousands coming into my office over this whole issue of discrimination against mothers who choose to stay at home to look after their children compared with those who go out to work. It is about time Senator Crowley focused on the problems she has in her area and ceased her vitriolic personal attacks on members of the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to briefly draw the attention of the Senate to a matter which was featured on the Sunday program on 20 February, the Starcke land sale in northern Queensland. Honourable senators will recall this has been very much in the news for quite some time now.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I placed on notice a series of questions asking the minister representing the Attorney-General about a number of serious matters raised about the proposed sale of the property known as Starcke on Cape York Peninsula. I understand until yesterday the land was owned by George Quaid Holdings of Cairns, but that yesterday the Queensland government acted to acquire the land.

To refresh the memory of honourable senators, Starcke was assessed as being of high wilderness value in the 1992 national wilderness survey. On 26 February 1993, Quaid Holdings advertised the property for sale in the Wall Street Journal for $US18 million or $A26 million.

Naturally, there was outrage at the prospect of such a sale from many quarters, particularly among the traditional owners of the region who were relocated in the 1930s, and from environmentalists concerned that the property would become a frontier game park or even a residential area. The Sunday program highlighted the complete lack of regard the developer had shown on a previous occasion when he built a series of lakes and destroyed millions of trees in the process, eventually clogging the catchment of Australia's second longest river system with the resultant forest debris. Honourable senators would recall the construction of a road through the world heritage area north of Cairns without permission. The Queensland Government acquired Starcke yesterday from George Quaid Holdings in order to have it declared a national park.

I raise this matter this evening because the Commonwealth government is likely to become involved in the question of compensation. Some senators here will be aware that recently in matters regarding compensation and handling of moneys the Commonwealth government has not been particularly diligent in the way it has distributed those funds and the way in which they have been spent. Clearly, this acquisition is likely to be followed by a lengthy inquiry to determine exactly the amount of compensation likely to be payable to George Quaid Holdings.

I refer briefly to a legal opinion given by Mr John Greenwood QC to the Wilderness Society in relation to George Quaid Holdings and the failure of that company to uphold the conditions of its previous lease. He says, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems fairly clear that whatever other conditions have been broken, the fencing requirement of 150 miles of stock proof fencing has not been met. The total claimed spent by Quaid on fencing (and other items) in Cockrell's figures was only $65,722. This certainly is at odds with the $120,000 given to Allen.
On the next page he talks quite specifically about the issue of whether fraud had been involved in the breach of conditions. He says:

In addition to the provisions in Section 295 of the Act which allows the Crown to forfeit a lease if there has been a breach of condition by the lessee, Section 296 allows the Crown to forfeit a lease if the lessee is shown to have `acquired or held' (the lease) `in evasion of or by fraud upon this Act'. A forfeiture under Section 296 can have far reaching consequences on the lessee.
I seek leave to table this legal opinion by John Greenwood, and I can assure the Senate it has been cleared with both the whips.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claim by Quaid in advertisements was that the land area was worth $26 million on the overseas market. There has been the subsequent acquisition of this land by the Queensland government and involvement by the federal government in relation to compensation; the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has offered to contribute to that compensation. There is the question of whether George Quaid Holdings has upheld the conditions of the lease and is or is not, therefore, liable for forfeiture of the lease in any case without any compensation. The question of the extent of the compensation—whether it relates to money actually spent or forgone future profits had the land been allowed for subdivision or tourist development—is very relevant. I would enjoin honourable senators to look at that opinion because it contains a lot of very interesting material which relates to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to follow my colleague Senator Minchin in his comments regarding Senator Crowley. He so rightly put in perspective Senator Crowley's prejudices. She is a man hater, giving no credit to any man, no matter how sensitive he may be when speaking on women's issues. But it is worse than that; it extends to other areas of her prejudices, and I can give evidence of just how selective Senator Crowley is.

PARA.TAB: Two days ago in question time I asked Senator Crowley, as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, what action the Office of the Status of Women had taken to redress the slurs directed at Australia's nuns through the publication of certain definitions in the Macquarie Dictionary Thesaurus. This was a very serious question and it has yet to be answered by the minister. It is 48 hours since that question was asked. It was a matter which received broad media coverage—on television, on the front page of the Herald Sun, in a major article in the Australian and in an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald. I quote briefly from the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 February where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Why have the lives of nuns been exposed to the terminological abuse and other groups spared?

That is basically the question put to Senator Crowley about which I have yet to receive an answer. The various women's groups and the Office of the Status of Women have shown in the past that they are aggressively sensitive to insults of a gender based kind directed at women, and rightly so. They have been very quick off the mark to defend the interests of other women offended by what they claim to be community based, gender driven attitudes. The debased and derogatory slurs printed in the Macquarie Dictionary against the gentle, female religious orders of nuns are no different from past outrages. But why has the minister not seen fit to reply when she gave an undertaking to do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because very few nuns are radical feminists.

—Maybe so. Let us hear from Senator Crowley why the Office of the Status of Women has not intervened in this matter, or at least what is their opinion on this matter. We cannot even get an opinion from them. Why has she dismissed the query I directed to her? The matter has been raised in the national media. What is the Office of the Status of Women doing now that the nuns have been slurred in such a vulgar and distasteful manner? We cannot even get an opinion from Senator Crowley.

PARA.TAB: The only conclusion is that the Office of the Status of Women and Senator Crowley are not interested in these types of women, in this sector of women. As Senator O'Chee pointed out, perhaps they are not radical feminists. The Office of the Status of Women and Senator Crowley are only interested in the political attitudes of certain women, not in defending the cause of women as a separate gender; just a sector of women, not women in general. Otherwise, they would have sprung immediately to the defence of the nuns regarding such vulgar language. They are only interested in the Labor politics of some women. The total silence of the Office of the Status of Women and the female ministers has proven this to be very true. I call upon Senator Crowley to at least answer my question, as would be the normal courtesy in the Senate. I challenge her to give her own personal view on such slurs against nuns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to make some brief remarks by way of response to Senator Coulter's discussion as to the acquisition of the Starcke properties. I think it is highly unusual for someone in the parliament to discuss the compulsory acquisition of properties. I understand, having seen part of the Sunday program last Sunday, that a portion of that property is leased and a portion of it is freehold. We can talk as much as we like about the history of those properties and the way they have been developed. That is not particularly germane to the point that Senator Coulter made this evening.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that an acquisition process is going on. We are led to believe by Senator Coulter and, I presume, that part of the Sunday program that I missed, that a portion of that acquisition is freehold. I presume that acquisition will take place under the land act as it applies to Queensland. I assume it is a Queensland government acquisition and not a Commonwealth one, although I understand that the Commonwealth may get involved by making a contribution.

Firstly, the price that Mr Quaid advertised the property at in the Wall Street Journal is probably quite irrelevant to what valuers would apply under the normal acquisition process in terms of value of the property. Whether Mr Quaid thought it was worth $A26 million or $US18 million when he advertised the property in the Wall Street Journal a number of years ago is probably quite irrelevant. Normal compulsory acquisition processes usually require a valuer to go in and make an assessment. Then, if the vendor of the property—in this case, Mr Quaid and interests associated with him—disagree with that valuation, they seek a separate valuation. In the end, there would be some form of arbitration on the matter.

In some ways it is most unfair and just cheap, political point scoring on the part of Senator Coulter for him to come in here and try to say that the Commonwealth should not pay very much for this property because Mr Quaid and his interests should not have owned it in the first place because—

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't like Mr Quaid.

—As Senator O'Chee says, perhaps it is because Senator Coulter does not like Mr Quaid. It is an abuse of the federal parliament and the Senate in particular. It really is a matter that needs to go through due process. Trying to interfere by alleging that Mr Quaid's leases were not valid for some reason shows what little understanding Senator Coulter has of these issues. If, as has been alleged here tonight, certain conditions of the leases had not been fulfilled, the Queensland government of course would not have to go through the compulsory acquisition process.

PARA.TAB: If Mr Quaid had not fulfilled the conditions of the lease, I am quite sure that the Goss government, in looking after the interests of the taxpayer of Queensland, would say, `Sorry, you haven't fulfilled the conditions of your lease, we will take it back, and it will revert to the Crown'. But that is not the case, as I understand it. I assure the Senate that I do not know much more than what I heard on the Sunday program, even though I have visited the area with my friend Senator Ian Macdonald on a couple of occasions. Of course I support what Senator Coulter says about the area and its beauty.

I am firmly of the view, however, that we do not need to create world heritage areas or publicly-owned national parks to preserve the heritage features of areas. I am a strong advocate of ensuring that significant incentives are put in place for people who own private property to ensure that conservation and other values are protected. We have a number of very good examples of that very close to home here in Australia with people like Dr Walmsley in South Australia who are creating privately-owned sanctuaries.

There are much bigger examples in the United States where a number of massive national parks and conservation zones are owned by private companies, private operators and, in some cases, conservation groups which manage those conservation areas for profit and ensure that the community gets maximum use out of them. I have never advocated that the only way to save a wilderness area is for the government to draw a line around it, call it world heritage and then try to manage it from miles away in Canberra.

Senator Coulter has made a serious criticism by coming in here and trying to get himself involved in the compensation process of the Starcke properties. In fact, it is interesting to note that, in our debate last Thursday on the lease that has been granted to Malcolm Douglas in Broome to expand his crocodile farming operations—a development that has now been destroyed, at least for the next 30 days, by the unheralded, unnecessary intervention of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, by placing a Federal Court order to stop the project on 4 February—Senator Coulter did not express, so far as I can remember, any views on that process and that intervention in relation to a lease.

As a result of the Native Title Act—or the national land rights scheme, as I like to call it—which passed through this Senate chamber last December, we will see an enormous number of compulsory acquisitions of pastoral leases throughout Australia. In Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia, we will see this land acquisition fund put towards purchasing—in some cases, compulsorily, I presume—thousands upon thousands of hectares of pastoral country which will then be handed across to Australian Aboriginals and will have an enormous effect on the pastoral industries across those states.

None of us will know the effect that that land acquisition and those compulsory acquisitions will have until they take place. But one only needs to look at our experiences in Western Australia—experiences that I am fully aware of, and I am sure there are other examples in South Australia and northern Queensland—to find out what can happen when pastoral leases are not managed in a way that takes into account the very fragile nature of the environment there.

One of the very sad things about the handing over of pastoral leases on the basis of race, which will occur under the Native Title Act—the national land rights scheme—is that these pastoral leases will be handed over, not because the managers of the land, the custodians of the land, are good at managing pastoral properties, but because of ideological and other motivations of some Canberra-based politician. It worries me that unless appropriate support mechanisms are put in place, the processes that will take place over the next five or 10 years as a result of the native title legislation will wreak havoc on the environment in the remote areas of Australia which I have referred to.

I will be interested to link Senator Coulter's comments to future ones he may make to see how often he involves himself in the compulsory acquisition processes and the land acquisition processes that will take place under the national land rights scheme, which he was so fervent in his support for. Senator Coulter has focused very narrowly upon this particular acquisition taking place in northern Queensland. He has probably done so for the reason that Senator O'Chee mentioned earlier—that is, he has a personal dislike for Mr Quaid and his modus operandi. It would be far more fair and even handed if Senator Coulter involved himself in land management issues in a far more balanced way and did not approach them in a narrowly focused, personality-driven way. I think it is an indictment upon his getting involved in a process that should go through due process to ensure that all parties leave the negotiations with a fair result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to my colleague Senator Campbell for raising this matter in the adjournment debate. I did not hear Senator Coulter's speech to which Senator Campbell was responding, but I do not think I needed to. I am pretty well aware of what the Australian Democrats think about things like this. The fact, as Senator Campbell says, that the Democrats are not really interested in due process when it comes to resumption of land does not surprise me at all because the Democrats do not have much regard for ownership of private property. It suits their socialist left view on life about private property.

PARA.TAB: I simply wish to draw the Senate's attention to some other matters in relation to Starcke Holdings. I have just heard that an announcement was made earlier this afternoon that mining exploration was continuing on Starcke Holdings. Apparently, there have been some discoveries of valuable minerals there. The Queensland minister for mines has been speaking to the media about them this afternoon. It is an interesting development on the Starcke Holdings, and one wonders what that might do to the value of any compensation.

I also want to draw to the attention of the Senate that last night in the estimates committee hearing we inquired into the funding of the buy-back of Starcke Holdings. I agree with Senator Campbell that, whatever it is, it should be a proper and legitimate price. Failing a negotiated result, it can be determined in the land courts as a resumption matter but, hopefully, it will be negotiated between the current owner and the other party.

The Queensland government has said that the buy-back figure will be in the single digit millions—figures ranging between six and 10 million have been mentioned—and some months ago on national television, Mrs Kelly said that the Commonwealth government would provide the Queensland government with matching funds for that buy-back. However, when Mrs Kelly was subsequently questioned at the last estimates committee, it appeared that, according to her department, `matching funds' did not mean dollar-for-dollar funding but joint funding. When we inquired into the meaning of `joint funding', we found that it meant that the department would talk to the Queensland government about it.

I was keen to pursue the matter a bit further at last night's estimates hearing. From evidence given, it transpired that the department of the environment will now be contributing no more than $1 million to the buy-back price. Even that is dependent upon, firstly, putting a management regime in place that is suitable to the commonwealth government and, secondly, the purchase price being, in the view of the commonwealth government, a reasonable one. There are lots of ifs and buts.

Of course, since this comes from Mrs Kelly's office, one wonders how she reached those figures. I guess she wrote them on a whiteboard as well and came up with the fact that $1 million was the right amount to offer. However, it is a betrayal of the Queensland government and the people of Queensland that Mrs Kelly's promise of matching funding turns out to mean a maximum of $1 million from her department.

The area of Starcke Holdings—the northern Daintree area of Cape York—is an area of heritage and environmental value, as is the Great Barrier Reef. I also draw to the attention of the Senate evidence given at last night's estimates committee meeting about the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The authority has indicated that 10 per cent of its resources—it only has a fairly small budget of $24 million for both capital and recurrent expenditure—is currently used to deal with Aboriginal and Islander issues. That means that resources that should be used for the purposes of the authority are being diverted elsewhere. I am not saying that it is improper for it to deal with Aboriginal and Islander groups—it is essential that it does—but it must be properly funded to do so. It should not be required to use its existing budget for those sorts of things.

The director of the authority, Professor Kelleher, also said last night that he was concerned by the amount of his budget that would have to be spent in the future on legal costs because of the many Mabo type claims that will be made in relation to the Great Barrier Reef and the marine parks. He pointed out that the authority was recently involved in a court case to defend one of its decisions and ended up with a bill of $1 million for legal costs. That was just one court case.

Professor Kelleher indicated that Aboriginal groups have made a claim with respect to the whole of the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef. Whether those claims are substantiated or not, they will interfere with the work of the authority, which is to direct how the reef should be dealt with. If the authority makes a decision that goes against a developer, a reef operator or marine operator, it could expect Aboriginal groups with a claim to appeal the decision. If it is made against a developer and in favour of Aboriginal groups, it could expect the developer to appeal. The authority is therefore very concerned that its budget will be gobbled up by its becoming involved in Mabo type claims.

This morning in the Senate I mentioned that the authority is really strapped for cash. I do not have time to elaborate on that but it is to such an extent that the Great Barrier Reef Wonderland at Townsville—that marvellous world class aquarium that transposes the Great Barrier Reef onto the mainland for everyone to see—is in danger of closing down because of lack of funds.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association (AVCA) publish in its pamphlet entitled Farm Chemicals Today (Issue No. 22, Winter 1993, p. 3) the view that `the existence of an MRL [Maximum Residue Limit] does not signify that higher levels would necessarily give rise to toxic effects in man'.
(2) Is this view correct and appropriate; if so, does it imply that MRLs are not really relevant.
(3) Is the AVCA currently providing advice on any issues relating to agricultural or food policy; if so, what are the details.
(4) What is the reason for and relevance of MRLs.
(5) How and by whom are MRLs set.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The views expressed by the AVCA are, of course, its own. I understand that their statement is correct scientifically, but it does not imply MRLs are irrelevant. MRLs are established to keep to a minimum the human intake of chemical residues. They are set as low as possible, consistent with the effective use of a chemical under field conditions and so that the acceptable daily intake of the chemical is not exceeded.

(3) The AVCA, as one of the many key representative industry bodies relating to the agricultural sector, is routinely asked to provide advice on issues affecting its members. As such, it is impossible to provide the details of its views on the broad range of matters regularly dealt with.
(4) As per answer 2.
(5) Maximum Residue Limits are set by the Chemical Safety Unit within the Department of Human Services and Health. MRLs become legal standards when adopted into State/Territory food laws.
Maximum Residue Limits are established following a review of toxicological and residue data and the use pattern of the chemical product.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that mining industries are eligible for the diesel fuel rebate but quarrying industries are not.
(2) Is the Minister aware that his department has been examining the anomalies that exist in the operation of the diesel fuel rebate between the mining and quarrying industries for over 12 months.
(3) Has a recommendation been put to the Minister to the effect that a review of the diesel fuel rebate scheme should be held to formally examine these anomalies.
(4) What impact will this anomaly have on the cost of roads built and/or maintained by local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The legislation specifically excludes, from eligible off-road mining operation uses, quarrying operations carried out for the purpose of obtaining stone for building, road-making or similar purposes.
(2) This matter has not been under examination for over 12 months by my Department.

In May 1992 a submission was received by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce requesting an extension of the eligibility criteria under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme to include the quarrying industry. The submission was lodged by KPMG Peat Marwick on behalf of major operators within the quarrying industry.

In August 1992 the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce wrote to KPMG Peat Marwick and advised that the then Government was committed to a broad-ranging review of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme in 1993 or 1994 and that the issues raised in the submission could be considered within the context of that review. KPMG Peat Marwick was also advised that in the meantime it was not proposed to make ad hoc additions to the scheme's eligibility criteria.

(3) In November 1992 the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Hon Senator John Button, advised the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon Simon Crean, MP, that he was of the view that the distinction between the treatment of mining and quarrying industries should be considered within the general review of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme in 1993 or 1994. In May 1993 Minister Crean wrote to my predecessor the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, the Hon Alan Griffiths, MP, drawing his attention to Senator Button's correspondence of November 1992 and supporting a review of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme.
My predecessor had discussions with a number of Ministerial colleagues to seek their agreement to a broad review of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme and to determine the details of that review.

(4) The KPMG Peat Marwick submission suggests that, were quarrying an eligible use for diesel fuel rebate under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme, there would be significant cost savings on quarrying operations undertaken by Government at all levels. Annual savings, to both State and Local Governments, are estimated in the submission at $8.5 million per annum.

The above savings, in the absence of additional revenue collections, are naturally offset by reduced revenue to the Commonwealth Government and a commensurate pressure on Commonwealth spending elsewhere.
