TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 14 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to concerns expressed by the Indonesian Human Rights Centre about Australian Government support for the Indonesian Government-sponsored trade union Serikat Pekerja Selurah Indonesia (SPSI):

(1) What co-operation exists between the Australian Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the International Labour Organisation, the SPSI and the Indonesian Government in the provision of financial or technical assistance.
(2) How much, if any, money does the Australian Government provide either directly to SPSI or through the Indonesian Government.
(3) What is the purpose of such financial assistance.
(4) When have such payments been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In March 1993 formal agreement was reached between the International Labour Office and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) under which the International Labour Organisation's (ILO) Regional Office for Asia and the Pacific manages an AIDAB funded project titled Australian Support for International Labour Organisation Objectives in Asia (ASILO). This project assists the ILO to draw on Australian expertise to provide technical assistance to Labour Ministries, trade unions and employer organisations in China, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam. Amongst other ASILO activities an ILO consultant has held discussions in Indonesia with a number of organisations, including with the SPSI. A program of technical assistance is being formulated to assist in the development of effective enterprise and industry level trade union organisations. The details of this program are not yet available. The ASILO project also enables the ILO to provide technical assistance to the Indonesian Government, focused on certain aspects of occupational safety and health.

In November 1993 the Minister for Industrial Relations led a tripartite delegation to Indonesia which increased Australia's understanding of the labour situation in Indonesia and helped to forge new opportunities for cooperation between Government, employer and employee organisations in both countries. Mr Brereton and the Indonesian Minister for Manpower, Dr Latief, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on cooperation in industrial relations in a broad range of areas, including occupational health and safety, labour law and administration, collective bargaining, dispute settlement, workplace reform and industrial best practice. An Asia Desk is being established in the Department of Industrial Relations to coordinate such assistance and to oversee practical implementation of all aspects of the MOU.
(2) No financial assistance is provided directly to the SPSI or through the Indonesian Government.
(3) Not applicable.
(4) Not applicable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Employment and Unemployment: Far North Queensland

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the method used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) to calculate the figure of 68 500 employed people in far north Queensland in January 1991.
(2) What was the method used by the ABS to calculate the figure of 107 000 employed in far north Queensland in September 1993.

(3) Please explain how the number of people employed in far north Queensland has increased by 56.2 per cent between January 1991 and September 1993, when over the same period the unemployment rate has increased, and the population has increased, by no more than 6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The estimates of employed persons in far north Queensland for January 1991 and September 1993 were obtained from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) monthly Labour Force Survey.

The Labour Force Survey is a national multi-stage area sample of private dwellings (currently about 29,000 houses, flats, etc.) and a list sample of non-private dwellings (hotels, motels etc.). Some 65,000 persons across Australia currently take part in the survey each month. The information is obtained from the occupants of selected dwellings by carefully chosen and specially trained interviewers. More information about the design and conduct of the survey can be found in Information Paper: Measuring Employment and Unemployment (ABS Catalogue No. 6279.0).

The Labour Force Survey is designed to produce reliable employment and unemployment estimates for Australia and for each State/Territory. However, estimates for various regions within States, such as far north Queensland, are also available as a by-product of the survey.

(3) The increase of 56 per cent in persons employed in the Far North Queensland Statistical Region between January 1991 and September 1993 is derived from the Labour Force Survey. The estimate of employment growth is consistent with the other labour force estimates from that survey. In the same period the Labour Force Survey shows increases of 70 per cent in unemployment, 58 per cent in persons not in the labour force, and 44 per cent in the civilian population aged 15 years and over.

However, it must be remembered these estimates are only by-products of a survey designed to produce reliable labour force estimates at the national, State and Territory level. The sample at the regional level is necessarily small and the estimates are therefore subject to significant sampling error. The comparison of estimates over time may also have been affected by a sample reselection which followed the 1991 Census of Population and Housing.

The origin of the estimate of 6 per cent growth in population cited by the Honourable Senator is unclear. Official population estimates for Far North Queensland are not yet available for June 1993 (and will not be produced for September 1993).

(2) During 1993 the Department and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission entered into an agreement with the AFL to sponsor the half-time televised event at the Grand Final. It was part of the Department's initiatives to mark the International Year of the World's Indigenous People by promoting a greater awareness of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures and talents.
